12oz bottle.  Pours dark read with a long lasting, thick, off-white head and nice lacing.  Aroma is of toffee, bread crust, cherry and hint of noble hops.  Body is full and slightly crisp.  Caramel malt, grain, noble hops and alcohol fill the mouth.  Long drying finish.  Outstanding bock.

Pours a murky brown from the bottle with thin tan head and little to no lacing. Aroma of german yeast, caramel and toffee malts. Taste follows, more malty than estery though, with a slightly bitter finish and decently full mouth. Solid doppelbock for something mass produced.
Very faint aroma. Some fruit.  Thin tan head with dark amber nearly black coloring. Fruity taste to it but not overly sweet. Very decent dopplebock.
Great beer, this is my go to doppelbock. What this beer looks in aroma it makes up for in color and head. Great malty flavor with min bitterness.

Bottle. Aroma is of dark sweet fruit. Appearance is dark. The taste is of a yeast i can't put my finger on and dark fruit, plums. Palate is ok. Overall, a decent beer for a decent price. Will buy again if nothing better is there. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark copper color when held to the light with a tan head that dissipates quickly into a sticky lace. Smells of caramel, toasted malt and some spicy alcohol fumes. Big, viscous body with light carbonation. Taste of toasted, bready malt, caramel and a grainy cereal-like flavor. A light dose of alcohol and hop flavor in the finish. Not as sweet as a Paulaner Salvator and not as hoppy as Ayinger Celebrator; somewhere in between. One of the better doppelbocks I’ve tried.
Bottle.  I did not find this beer to be awe inspiring or worthy of a 90+% rating.  While it is a good DB its not a great DB.  Thin on the palate and not bready enough for my measure.

Excellent head. Silly smooth taste. Very little aftertaste. One of the better beers I've had in some time. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very delicious, great colder weather beer.  Sweet malt up front and full=-bodied, but stopping short of syrupy maltiness of say a scottish ale.  Drinkable, malty, not overly hoppy.  good stuff.

330 mL bottle. Pours black, like cola, with a very thin, off-white head that disappears quickly. Notes of dark fruits, caramel, milk chocolate, and black bread. Very sweet up front, with very faint bitterness toward the finish. Medium to heavy body, velvety, smooth, and clean. Overall, this is a malty, delicious beer.

Tulip pour of deep brown with full khaki head. Nose is slight roasted malt with mostly caramel and toffee, light stickiness. Flavor is a little nutty with toffee and chewy. Really a great beer and quite drinkable. Medium body with nice lacing.

Rating #66 for 2012. 6/22/12, 12 oz bottle cold from a stem glass. Aroma of molasses, brown sugar, and dark fruit. A dark copper colored liquid with a quickly fading 1/2 inch head, and no lacing. Tastes of syrupy dark fruit. Palate, medium carbonation with a medium body and finishes very smooth.
brown color transparent. Dark brown color but transparent. hint of the green bottle beer taste and smell.  taste is nice, Carmel and apples. Mouthfeel is a bit creamy.   nice sipping beer .

Deep mahogany, tan head.  Nose is pure dark roasted malt. Sweet on the tongue.  Cooked dark fruit, deep roasted grain, and alcohol through the middle.  Dry from hops and alcohol and the end.  Formidable
Not a big fan of this beer, too bitter, nothing really tasty about this...much better out there x2
My favorite doppelbock. Sometimes you just can’t top the original! Dark brown once poured, medium head. Nice roasted malt and caramel aromas. Nice and creamy. I like it with beef stew!

Pours a dark brown, almost a plum color, with orange-crimson highlights and a smaller khaki head that descends to a ring. Nose involves some burnt caramel, toffee, a touch of soy sauce and savory notes, some molasses, toast, and a bit of nuttiness. Taste is somewhat sweet, fairly roasty bitter. Palate is crisp, active, coating but not really very heavy, with a drying toasty finish. Pretty easy drinking, but one to take slowly. Pretty nice.

Definitely a traditional example of the style but not for everyone. Heavy malted aroma with tinge of sweetness. Nice dark brown color with substantial head. Roasted malts stood out and almost appeared burnt. Very strong presence with little else other than some sweetness. Strong and interesting beer, just not one I would go to regularly.

Nice German doppelbock.  I wouldn't ever turn one down, but there are a lot better options in my opinion.  Something about the flavor just doesn't do it for me.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clear dark brown pour with medium sized tan head. Aroma of fresh baked bread, roasted malts, and caramel. Taste of roasted malts, caramel, toffee, dough and yeast. Medium carbonation and creamy mouthfeel. Very good doppelbock.

Aroma is sweet bread, toasty like cereal.  When the head fades away it puts off more sweetness and caramel notes.  Dark brown but transparent color with tan creamy head.  Good flavor of grains, oats, and cereal with lager-like dampness.  Mild sweetness.  Finish is not so pleasant, and leaves a sort of spent beer taste in your mouth.

bottle shared and from VT. pours almost clear medium dark brown, red tint, with a small light beige cap, some retention. brown sugar, molasses, figs, dark and sweet candied and spiced fruits, fruitcake-like. some pepper. sweet,a lmost cloying. average to soft carbonation, medium to full body, short herbal-grassy finish. abv well hidden. not overly complex but good.

500 ml bottle shared with czar and friends. A dark, yet clear dark brown beer with a short lasting white head. Smell is ripe fruits, roasted bread. Taste is fruity, caramel, roast, brown sugar, red berries. Light earthy hops in the finish, cinnamon and cake spices. Some french toast in there, too. Light to medium body. Solid doppelbock.
Bottle - Dark brown pour, very little head.  Smells like Grapenuts cereal.  Little sour/bitterness in flavor, ok beer.

(old notes) Dark amber pour with a medium off-white head. Decent lacing. Aroma of dried fruit and brown sugar. Very sweet flavor, with a lot of caramel and roasted malts. Little bitterness to finish. A little thin. Nothing special.
Pours fairly dark with a off white quickly fading head. Carmel tones as well as malt and molasses. Strong finish just a little bitter. Nice experience
Bottle. Deep amber brown color. Clear. Brief off-white head. Aroma of dark roasted malts and raisin. Raisin and malty brown sugar in the flavor. Malty sweet finish.
Dark copper with a quick fading tan head. A roasted taste of malt, caramel, nuts. It tastes like other doppelbocks I’ve had. Pretty good
pours a beautiful dark copper. Thick dark of white head. Malt aroma. Light bodied, but not light in flavor. Lots of malt and finishing hop character.
Nice dark beer with a little bit of light tan head.  Some lacing.  Medium bodied.  Roasty beer flavor, slightly bitter finish.  Good beer.

Bottled 330ml. -from Billa Kiev, Ukraine. Brown coloured, medium sized pale beige head, dry malty nutty nose (not so pleasant actually). Sweet malty, caramel and strong dried fruits presence with not so strong alcohol notes. Sweet sticky finish. Bad batch or I just didn’t like it.
12oz bottle pours a dark reddish brown with a khaki head.  Aromas of caramel malts some bread molasses and honey.   Flavor is sweet and full body is medium and finish a bit sweet

12oz bottle. Pours a deep amber with thick tan head that reduces to a film. aromas of molasses, not overpowering. Malty, mollases, caramel taste. Real nice, thick mouthfeel. No burn from the abv at all. This beer is also surprisingly easy to have more than one or two of, even with its thickness. If it had a little nicer head retention and lacing, would be near perfect for me. great beer.
Pours a deep dark amber. Nice tan head that lingers for a bit, no lacing to speak of. Smooth, with a good amount of malty sweetness. Good stuff.

Pours a murky brown with minimal head and small lacing. Aromas strong caramel and bready. Hint of grassy hops but this is largely a medium sweet endeavor throughout. Moderate carbonation and full body. Chewy. Long moderately sweet finish. good dopplebock

Served in a 1 liter ceramic mug at Der Biergarten in Atlanta, making it hard to comment on the appearance (but see below), especially with the tan head covering it. The head is thick and creamy looking.

Smell is of a boozy dunkel, bit quite bready.
High ABV could be better hidden but unlike many higher ABV brews, this one improved with warming. 

(revised with on-tap tasting in August 2013)

Location/Date:Draft on September 15th, 2012.



Appearance: Pours a dark brown. 
 

Aroma: Aroma is of roasted malt.
 

Taste: Roasty, caramel, some faint hop.
   

Palate: Medium body.



Summary: Pretty tasty beer, that was way heavier in alcohol than my other beers at Biergarten Haus that night.

Hmm. On the bottle it says malt liquor. It however doesn't remind me of the flavor of those olde English drinking high school days. It has a rich malty good flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Appearance is a very dark amber with not much head.  Smells of sweet malt and maybe some metallic notes.  Tastes of sweet syrup/molasses and malt.  Very smooth, not too overly sweet.  Good one.

Pours a deep reddish brown. Initial smell is sweet caramel, malt, and coffee. Taste more of the Caramel, toffee, toasted barley, black strap molasses, licorice and prunes ( I mean dried plums). Overall a good beer a classic dark.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Roasty malt aroma yielding to toasted brown sugar and bock yeast. Taste is similar, but more rich and sweet raisin fruitiness than the nose emits. Good doppelbock yeast tang balances the sweetness of the malt. Not heavy or syrupy on the palate, so relatively easy to drink. This is about the nth time I’ve had this beer, but in tasting it for the purposes of rating, I’m noticing a slight sourness very near the end of the finish that I hadn’t thought about before. Not sure if the bottle (purchased at a Safeway grocery in California, USA) was mistreated, or if I just hadn’t noticed it before. Still, a standby doppelbock in the realm of easy-to-obtain.

Bottle 500ml.

[ Courtesy of saxo ]. Clear medium amber brown colour with a small, fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, bread, roasted, caramel, brown sugar, caramelized malt - brown sugar, alcohol. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, bread, malt bitter. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120817]
Two finger head, off white, creamy, mostly diminishing, black, sweet malt aroma, medium to full body.
Unexpectedly very nice bottle (0,3). Full, rich with medium bitterness.
Nice brown color, I smell malt, brown sugar and caramel. Taste is malty, caramel, med sweetness, med bitter on the after taste. Very good indeed...

12 oz. bottle. I was shocked I haven’t rated this yet. It pours a nice brown color with a shrinking off white head. The aroma is nice and malty with light notes of cocoa and heavier notes of raisin bread. The flavor is rich with melanoidins, cherry, raisin, and pumpernickel bread. The body is pretty full, but on the light side for a dopplebock. Easy to drink despite the high gravity. A really nice beer, if not as complex and refined as the top examples of the style. I give it extra points for it’s availability and affordability.

0.5L bottle, found it in the states!  I’ve had this beer before, and I like it a lot.  It’s not my favorite doppel, but it’s a distinctive, flavorful beer nonetheless.  Aroma is roasted nuts and malts.  Decent appearance, this dopplebock is the regulator.
Bottle.  Light aroma, medium carbonation.  Sweet, roasted caramel flavor, slightly sweet finish.  Very tasty.  Would definitely buy again.

Wrong, the title says not offered in Germany!  You’re crazy! I first drank this beer in Munich, also found it in Frankfort. Anyway, Delicious out of a bottle into a glass. Thin head that falls and ends up off white cream color and Dark red-brown color, very nice. Good legs.  Amazing dried fruits, figs, dates, raisins, and plums in a burst of flavor. Rich malty chocolate hints with lots of good dark toasty grains.  Great layering of mouthfeel, maltiness, and flavor. The aroma is not uber pronounced but its sweet PERFECT amount of grainy, sweet, very light hop back, and dark fruit. Overall a clear winner. When its chilled correctly and in a nice cold glass, I think this beer pairs well with everything you could have, a true universal delight. Loved it
The aroma is great it is not strong and has as a great taste that goes great if you are eating sea food

I love the brown, almost blood-red color of this one when it’s poured into a glass.  The malts are extremely prominent: rich and toasty, with caramel and molasses overtones, and a hint of dark, brown bread on the finish.  A moderate carbonation level doesn’t quite eclipse the dash of bitter that sets off the malty sweetness very nicely.  It’s very very assertive, but not cloying in terms of sweetness.  A hearty, solid German-style beer; a little too strong for a session beer, but a couple of ’em will weigh you down very nicely.
Bottle @ The 5th Danish Summer Gathering, Ulfborg, 2012. Pours brown with a small bubbly head. Brown sugar, caramel, nuts, bread and cookies. Fine depth. Medium bodied.

A very nice dark beer poured from bottle into a stem glass, pours with a thick head which dissipates at quick pace with residual lacing, dark brown color, aroma is malt, taste is a malty caramel, some sweetness, medium carbonation, mild bitterness on the back end. A very nice beer.

Nice, medium brown in color with a foamy, beige colored head.  Light malty aroma with a full bodied, lighly bitter taste.  Smooth caramel hits the roof of the mouth as it goes down.  Nice beer from my favorite beer city.

Bottle 500ml @ fonefan

Pours clear brown with a few off-white bubbles.
Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, dried fruits and hints of chocolate.
Taste is medium sweet and light bitter.
Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle. A clear, dark brown beer with a small, beige head. Dried fruits, lots of caramel, some notes of alcohol, and a hint of something roasted. Balancing bitterness in the flavor, with caramel, some alcohol warmth and dried fruits. Full-bodied, warming and soft. Lasting caramel finish with some dried fruits. A pleasant one indeed, tasteful, complex and well worth a revisit. 120817
Bottle. Brown/dark amber with small beige head. Aroma is malt, caramel, bread and light nutty. Flavour is malt, caramel, bread, medium sweet, light nutty, hops, little toffee and a little bitter.
Bottle @ pre-TFODRBSG, Ulfborg. Clear brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and dried fruit. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet finish. 170812
Nice dark amber color. Sweet malty bite with slight caramel notes...nice dry finish.
Classic standard if you ask me, and the ABV ain’t too shabby either. Long time staple.
Pours an extremely dark brown with almost no head. Awfully malty without much to balance it out. The malts provide a good flavor, but it’s a tad harsh.
Malty, somewhat thin with little hop presence. Caramel flavor with corresponding sweetness. Needs more balance. Not as full bodied as I would have preferred.
Dark brown pour with a thin beige had. Faint aroma of carameland bread. Taste is roasty with nuts and caramel. Decent bitterness.

On tap a The Ginger Man. Dark brown with a small creamy beige head. Aroma of caramel, dark fruits and malt. Taste is sweet with caramel and berries. Mouthfeel is oily and a bit watery. Good balance a drinkability. Nice dopplebock but far from the best of the style like Ayinger Celebrator.

Bottle. Skunky aroma. Dark brown with no head at all. Caramel, bread, rotting malts. Nasty lingering taste. Overall, u use green bottles, this is what happens. I will change my rating if I ever visit Germany and taste it the way it was intended

12oz bottle. Decent thin tan head. Clear brown color. Sort of a light body, lighter carbonation. Roasty malt flavor, but still a lot of thoroughly lagery qualities, some dark, fermenty fruit . Pretty thin body, bit watery. Light bitter taste. Little salty. Fine, but not really my kind of doppelbock.

16.9 oz bottle pours brown with a off white head.  Aroma and taste nice roasted malts.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are sweet with dried fruits, malt, caramel and hops.

Bottle. Pours deep clear reddish brown with a small beige head that slowly dissipates with good lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, caramel, a bit of grass. Flavor is roasted malt, medium sweet caramel, with a touch of chocolate. Finish has light grassy bitterness and lingering caramel sweetness.

From a bottle pours a dark ruby-brown with a slight head. Nice earthy aroma of grains with a hint of nuttiness. Sweet, rich, malty flavor with roasted characters of toffee and butterscotch. Very nice.

12oz bottle pours almost black with average carbonation. Heavy malt flavor with some chocolate taste. This could hold me over until their Oktoberfest releases.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nice nutty malt aroma.  Deep brown with off-white slightly tan head.  Taste of chocolate malt with the alcohol as well.  Slight cloying from the sweetness.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark brown with nice head. Taste starts out sweet ending a little bitter. You can definitely taste the alcohol. Drink would be paired well with pub food (corned beef & hash, stew, fried chicken & mashed potatoes).
One of my favorite beers. Looks dark, great smooth taste, high alcohol content. Get a good quality beer mug, keep it in the freezer and enjoy a froasty beverage in it.

Very dark amber color, flat head and sweet malty aroma.  Caramel malts give a sweet but slightly toasted flavor.  I am a big fan of maibocks and golden bocks, but this is perhaps a little too sweet and a little too dark for my tastes Probably better with food.
Great dopplebock.  Definitely like a meal in a glass.  For something produced by In-Bev, this was most enjoyable.

Pours a clear mahogany with a medium, tan head that stays. Moderate lacing. Malty aroma. Full, creamy mouthfeel with moderate effervescence. Malty but balanced taste. This remains my personal, consistent favorite. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500ml bottle pours a dark reddish brown color with a 2 finger off-white head that retains well but leaves little lacing on the glass.  Aroma is caramel malts with some roasted notes and herbal hops.  Taste is malty sweet with some roasted grain and herbal hop bitterness.  Medium bodied with some light carbonation.  Definitely one of the better German doppelbocks that I have sampled.

It poured a dark brown color with a light brown head. The aroma was of light chocolate and caramel with a hint of nutty malt and some roast. The taste was pretty similar with a slightly hoppy/bitter finish.
Dark reddish-brown pour with a decent tan head. Aroma is nutty and some yeast. Nice sweetness, balanced bitterness. Medium-bodied with caramel and malt flavors. Finish is slightly sweet and coffee.
Bottle.  Pours a medium-brown color with a tan head.  Creamy, nutty, malty aromas.  Caramel, malty, roasted flavor.  Not one of the better German Doppelbock, but it is still pretty good

Pours a dark ruby brown with a shot lived tan head and no lacing. The nose is malt and not much else. The taste is similar with some roasted notes present. There is a bit of a grainy aftertaste. The mouthfeel is medium and with a some what of a  silky tongue coating. Enjoyable. Would drink again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma is a little sweet but very slight. Color is brown-amber, with a thin, fizzy head. Fizziness carries through to the palate and gives the beer bite. Good balance of malt and hops, but definitely favors the malt. Toffee and roasted nuts at the front, slightly bitter finish from the hops. Overall, not enamored with this beer like its 96 score would suggest but then I don’t drink much dopplebock. Would drink in a pinch however.
Dark brown colour and thin, tan head. Nice, rich aroma. Medium body, slick mouthfeel with light fizziness. Tastes like malt. The taste not too strong so this beer is very easy to drink.
Tasty.  never disappoints.  so good I can take it for granted.  what a shame.  like a long suffering wife. Buy all the time.

Aromas amaderados, cebada y maltas  tostadas y con ciertos finales acaramelados.
Cerveza oscura con tonos pajizos y brillos rojos a la luz, cuerpo medio, ligera carbonatzación. corona de espuma media de absorción algo lenta la cual permanece hasta el final.
En boca la pirmera sensación es dulce y un poco acaramelado.
Al paladar se percibe un sabor complejo e interesante. Se caracteriza por notas de maltas tostadas y acarameladas, mismas que se perciben desde el aroma. Así mismo se encuentran sabores dulces y una carbonatación suave que resalta los finos sabores de la cerveza.
En general una sabroza cerveza, con caracteristicas interesantes, sabores dulces y acaramelados, que se nivelan con las maltas tostadas. Una excelente representante aleman de este estilo.

A classic that I’ve had many times, but never rated. From green 6-pack bottle into MH’s Deutschland dimpled mug. Pours pretty dark brown with a tan, frothy, lingering head. Nice. Aroma is expected doppelbock profile: big malt, alcohol, and some fruitiness. Borders on reminiscent of ice beer or eisbock, but stays good. Flavor is all malt sweetness. Very syrupy-brown-sugary sweet. Definitely biased towards sweet, even for the style. Always a classic, though.

Poured into a pint glass. Dark copper color with a tight, finger of off-white head.
Could smell it in the pour; a malty smell. Then once in the glass; apple, pear and raisin.
All malt, not a bit of bitterness coming through. Though, it is not "malty". The sweetness is restrained. There is molasses ending.
Crisp and bubbly, light to medium bodied and chewy at the end.
A very enjoyable drink.

Originally reviewed: 6/12/09. Had this on tap at the First St. Draught House in town on 6/19/09. Reviewed from notes.

Came out a deep chocolate brown with an inch-sized tan head. Retention was pretty weak, but it left some moderate lacing on the glass. Smells of brown sugar, cocoa, cream, and big time caramel. Very nice.

Mouthfeel was crisp, yet smooth. Easy drinker. Flavor was of sweet caramel, toffee, some coffee cake, fresh dark breads, and finished sweet as well. This is a very good Doppel, but may be too sweet for some. I, for one, enjoyed it.
Had this beer at the 4th Annual Casanova Beer Cave Festival. Pretty smooth, light scents and taste of coffee/chocolate.

Second ever doppelbock - tried this style again after a recommendation.  Pours dark brown/red, chestnut even, with a nice head that disappears almost completely and leaves solid lacing.  Smells malty and sweet, especially malty.  Taste is amazing blend of malt and sweet - aftertaste in particularly is slurpy good.  Bit of dried fruit and perhaps roasty brown sugar going on as well, but not syrupy or overly thick in the slightest.  Amazing mouthfeel, actually.  Great beer all-around.

Very good if you want a stronger (higher alcohol content) German beer that is also smooth and enjoyable. Like my review for Spaten Dunkel, I wish I had this before InBev invaded Spaten. Whenever a big conglomerate invades an otherwise good brewery, quality can only go down as they operate cheaper. This one still survives as one of the good ones.

Appearance was clear reddish root beer with diminishing off white creamy 1 finger head, no lacing.Aromas where sweet buttery biscuity toffee caramel malts. Hops are slightly present and no alcohol. Taste was sweet roasted chocolate, figs,cherries, smooth malts with slight grassy piney hops when cold, warm not so much hops present. Palate was smooth with light carbonation. Medium body with silky slightly caulking dry average length fruity finish. Smooth 7.6% alcohol...

A: Pours a dark brown color that turns ruby red when put up to the light. The head is a three-finger light mocha color with mediocre retention/lacing.

S: Honestly, it smells a little skunky. There is a bit of maltiness and hop character, but the skunk (sadly) wins out. Seriously, brewers, STOP USING GREEN BOTTLES!

T: Thankfully, not nearly as skunky as the nose. Opens up with flavors of toffee, molasses, and roasty malts, but finishes a zesty hop bite. There’s the faintest hint of booze on both the back end and going down the throat, but it’s well hidden otherwise. Not an easy beer to drink, but decently flavorful.

M: The carbonation starts off intense, but fades rather quickly. I’m only halfway through the beer and it’s already (nearly) flat. In addition, while it’s decently thick, it isn’t creamy enough to counteract the fading carbonation. Otherwise, it isn’t bad at all on the palate.

O: I’m a bit conflicted on this one. I like the way it tastes, but I don’t like the skunk profile I get on the nose. Eh, what the hell, give it a shot, it’s well priced for a rather big beer. This is a style I’ll need to get a better grip on in the future to see if it’s really up my alley.
A little sweeter than most but a pretty good doppelbock and you can find it most places for a decent price,
Great beer.  Strong sweat malt aroma. Dark rich aperaence.  Taste is full body rich malt.

Timid notes of dark fruits, toasted bread, earth, and molasses in the aroma. Mostly, though, it’s grainy and malty. The mouthfeel is medium-to-thin, dry, and properly carbonated. The taste is a bit more spirited than the aroma, with the sweet honey/molasses note from the malts being more perceivable and enjoyable. Quite serviceable.

6-pack from my bro in the States.  Can’t really find this here in Ontario, shame.  Pours mahogany with a nice tan head.  Aroma is quite nice and crisp; fruity & earthy at the same time.  Bold flavours with nice clean finish. Overall a solid beer.
Easy drinking, crisp palate. Balanced, dry malts with a clean finish. Nothing too special, but I could drink quite a few.

I love dopples and this one is no different, however still a ways from my favorite.  Gorgeous burnt amber color, however the gent pouring it left relatively no head.  Aromas killer, as is mouthfeel.  Though this isn’t my favorite dopple, I anticipate of few more long conversations with the Optimator.

Pours a dark clear amber with about a finger of light tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty with a bit of cherry to it. There are also some sour yeast esters peeking through. Taste is actually fairly mild and crisp. The light cherry sourness seems to linger on the palate which is quite nice. The yeast is also present largely at the beginning and then tapers off. Not too much malt body to this beer.

Bottle. The pour was a medium-dark brown with a large (2-3 finger) light brown head that diminished quickly and had poor lacing.

The aroma was of a toasted bread malt and a doughy yeast with notes of caramel, molasses, dark fruit (raisins and plums) and a slight metallic smell.

The taste was lightly sweet and malty throughout with a note of caramel early on and had notes of dark fruit and a mild alcohol presence at the finish. The flavor lasted an average time after the swallow with a slight metallic fruity flavor left behind.

Mouthfeel was light to medium in body and watery yet just a tad dry in texture with a medium carbonation.

Overall a pretty basic Doppelbock with a slightly bland flavor...
Pours a nice dark brown with decent head. This beer has a sweet spicy and malty taste, it has tastes of molasses and a bit of sour fruitiness.
Dark cloudy brown with a little head. The smell was of caramel and slightly yeasty, the taste is malty and nutty with a hint of sweetness that is very well balanced. The mouthfeel is full.

Deep brown with ruby, small tan head
Aroma is roasted malt, a little funk.
Taste is deep and roasted caramel, some heavy fruit.  very rich and slightly sweet. Alcohol is well hidden.
Pretty good stuff.....
dark brown color, aroma of toffee, caramel, molasses, flavor is the same with dark fruits, roasted malt, outstanding beer for the style
Caramel, mild floral and mild roast aromas.  Dark browh with creamy, beige head.  Mild lacing.  Caramel, roast, dark fruit, and mild alcohol.  Balanced, malt roast finish, and full bodied.

I’m usually not a big fan of the doppels, but I must admit this brew may have changed my outlook. Poured from a bottle into a goblet, the aroma was roasted hops and a hint of chocolate. Tasted exactly how it smelled. This is a doppel done right.

Faint toast malt aroma; some yeast as well. Very dark brown, clear. Short, dense almost white head. Taste: a bit of pleasant sweetness, light malts - not as "toasted" as I expected. Hops are faint. Quite drinkable and enjoyable.

Dark and inviting, poured from a bottle purchased at Oliver’s Beverage in Albany, NY.  The Optimator is glorious.  Molasses, malt, richness and spiciness in aroma and taste, this is one of the best doppelbocks you can find widely circulated.  5/5 on the palate/mouthfeel because each draw is smooth and inviting.  Often times, I drink these far more quickly than anticipated.  A stellar beer!

Bottle pour to stein revealing rich oxidate burgundy hue with a generous foam gathering to the fore. Plum raisin overtones emanate on top of characteristic malts. Nice body with sweet roast amidst light carbonate rounding out spicy backend. Creamy coat leaves palate eager for each successive swill.

500ml bottle. Pours a dark brown tea colour with a light brown head. Aromas of raisins and currants with a hint of toffee also. The flavour is strong with alcohol and also some christmas pudding flavours as well. BIg strong spices finish, this would be a good beer for a cold winters night.
A classic of the classics.  A dark rich spicy beer that demands attention.  Anyone who wants to begin a beer voyage into the dark world can start here.

From notes.  First reviewed 12/29/2010.  On tap in a pint glass.

At first glance, the color is black, but upon further inspection it is lightly transparent ruby throughout. Nice creamy foamy off-white head. Foamy lace drips forms and drips away down the glass.

Molasses, roasted malt, and ripe dark fruits comprise the aroma. A touch of spice wafts into the nose as well.

Molasses, plums, raisins, a light general spiciness - all spice or nutmeg maybe. Along with a roasted malt, these flavors form the basis of the flavor. Earthy hops sneak up on me, making themselves known as the sip comes to a close. Finishes lightly bitter. 

The carbonation fizzes and bubbles away in my mouth, eventually relenting to a creamy feel. Lightly sticky, with above average carbonation wrapped in a fuller than medium body.

Although I am not usually a lager person, I have been getting more into Doppelbocks recently, and this is a nice example of the style. Really drinkable at 7.2%. Definitely better as it warms.
This beer seems to combine dark fruits and sweet malts. First impression: Raisins, plums and related dark fruit flavors meet with gentle matly flavors. It is too sweet and too fruity for my taste.

Bottle at Bukowskis. Pours opaque, Brown ruby red tinged with not too much head light tan of whats left.. Aroma of prunes med caramel salt medicinal, albiet not offensive. Metallic sweetness from malt toffee med body, med-h carb. Finishes salty sweet lingering malty finish.

From a green bottle (WTF?) into a pint glass.  Not too much aroma.  Good amount of head which dissipates into a tiny bit of lacing.  Mouthfeel is very nice, rich and creamy.  Taste is pretty lousy.  Some dark fruit, mainly skunk and a metallic flavor.  Pretty lousy.  Probably the result of poor storage but that’s what you get for buying imports, especially in a green bottle.

Pours a ruby brown with a light head, no lace.  Taste begins with a roasted caramel malt that smoothly moves through a touch of earthy plums and cherries, then finishes with light carbonation bittering.  Not a lot of movement, but a solid taste, beginning to end.

Date: February 1, 2012 Mode: Bottle Source: Crown Description: Translucent brown with large amount of head that faded quickly.  Aroma is sweet malt.  Taste is consistent with aroma but with some roasted malt as well and a slight bitter finish.

Tasted at the 2012 St. Louis Centennial Beer Festival from bottle into sampler glass. Poured a dark reddish brown color with decent beige foam, some lace. Aromas of caramel, toffee, raisin brown bread, noble hops, faint fermentation esters/phenols. Rich malt flavor with a mildly tangy hops bitterness underneath. Medium body, low carbonation, bready and "chewy" mouthfeel, long-lasting complex aftertaste. Classic, true-to-style doppelbock. Very tasty.
10/03/2013 sampled again at the October homebrew meeting. Just as intense and tasty as before. Love these melanoidins: toast, caramel, toffee, slow-cooked pumpernickel bread. Chewy and malty and really, really good.
Bottle - pours dark (yet clear) brown with a cream colored head. Has a nice roasted malt flavor to it and a smooth finish.

Bottle. Pours a brilliant, translucent brown, with red (almost purplish) highlights when held up to light. Small head dissipated quickly leaving no lacing. Aroma of dried fruit and some spice. Very sweet smelling. Flavor is mostly caramel sweetness with some roastiness and bitterness on the end. Good body. More bubbly than expected. Very easy-drinking, but not nearly as nuanced and delicious as my favorite doppelbock, the one and only Ayinger Celebrator.
Pours amber.brown with a fairly big, tan head. Sweet malts with noticeable tangy hops. Well-made, tasty brew, but a bit sweet.

A favorite lager. Pour medium brown, disappearing head, light malt aroma with very slight hints of roasted grain and carmel. Taste follows through with the same tones. Moderate sweetness and complexities of carmel and roasted grain. This is really nicely balanced, and interesting enough to make me want it again. A winner.
Dark reddish brown colour with off-white head, nice retention. Aroma is malty and fruity. Taste is malty, sweet, bready, quite nice.

Smooth , solid, and satisfying. I was expecting a bit more body because of the color. Not as roasted as I was anticipating, howver rich bready mouth feel, and the text book Spaten glide down the throat smoothness. Flavor was less than I expected, but still tasty , would definatly have again if in the mood. Taste was front end loaded.

This beer next to the straight up Lager style Munchen Spaten has to be the most flavorful and aromatic. Though I have had many beers with similar types of builds and tastes this one had an intriguingly steak/beefy like taste. Truly a beer to satiate the hungry beer drinker, and the dark roasted color with the golden wrapped bottle adds to the ever admirable food beer it becomes.
Clear mahogany with a tan head.  Aroma of molasses and soy sauce.  Taste is sweet rich malt with burnt sugar and plum.  Syrupy texture.

Poured from the bottler. Color is a nice dark brown, hints of chocolate with a roasted nut taste. There is absolutely "no" aftertaste on your palate upon drinking. Has a definite European taste (obviously), good beer!
Very solid beer. Not something I want to drink in mass amounts, but I will definitely have one or two on any given night at my local German bar.
Poured dark brown. Nice biscuity aroma.  Taste is bread and a little bit of spice.  Smooth finish.  Good.
Bottled pours black with amber tones. Aromas of ripe fruit and raisin. Flavors similar sweet on the tongue. Lasting raisin flavor on the palate. Decent beer.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Appearance is a beautiful dark brown with an impressive khaki colored head of about three or four inches that prevails atop the beer for a very long time. Aroma is faint, but what I do pick up on is some malt. The first sip is quite shocking...its tastes like this beer has been setting on lemon peels prior to bottling. What the hell is this? At first I didn’t believe I had a good bottle. After sharing a drink of it with a friend, he confirmed that it was indeed how the beer has tasted every time he had it. I don’t get this beer at all. Drain pour.

Bottle pour. Body is dark brown with a nice light brown head that left some sloppy lacing. Nose is light chocolate and caramel with a hint of nutty malt and roast. Taste is pretty similar with a slightly hoppy/bitter finish. Nice dark malty characters and a nicely hidden abv. Good stuff.
Bottle to snifter. Pours deep brown with a small, dark, head. Lots of malt, all the character you would expect from a great dopplebock

Just tried my first Optimator, at Chicago’s Mirabell Restaurant.  The barmaid made a big deal over my order, pronouncing the name as if it was an Arnold Schwarznegger movie   12 oz bottle poured a clear dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is mostly malty with some chocolate and maybe raisins.  Much sweeter and boozier than I expected from a doppelbock.  It was a perfect end to a great meal. It serves its purpose quite nicely, thank you.

Pours a clear, dark brown with a large caramel head.  The aroma has a slight hops tinge, but it is mostly a coffee roast with a slight chocolate malt.  The taste with light bitter with a light to medium sweet.  A true medium body with a creamy and slightly oily texture.  The finish is a slight bitter, sweet.  This is a pretty good beer.  Much better than I expected and I would buy it in a bar if they had it in my area.
Deep brown beer with a frothy head that doesn’t stick around long.  Caramel aroma with flavors of raisin and sweet roasted barley.  Mild hop finish.
Pours a dark mahogany with very little head or lacing.  Nice nose with plenty of malty notes.  Pretty much a malt bomb.  Sweet malty flavors.  Very nice beer if you appreciate the style.

Appearance is dark ruby-brown, translucent and almost no head on the pour. Smells of caramel, malts, raisins and dark fruits.   Taste is a bit sweet with caramel malts, raisins, dark sweet fruit.  medium mouthfeel.  Quite tasty and light for the flavor it is pumping out.

Just tried my very forst Optimator. Once again I wish that American breweries could produce high volume beer with this good a taste. Micro breweries like Dogfish Head, 16 Mile, and Three Floyds can produce beers that even outshine these forgien beers, but mass produced? Budwieser is the bootm of the barrle, projectile vomit. Millers, Schlitz, Pabst? some what better. I love to buy American goods everytime I can find them, but when it comes to beer? Unluss it’s a good reputation micro brew, sorry, but the American mass produced, just don’t cut it.

Bottle-Pours a dark mahogany color with a small tan head and virtually no lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, caramel, with some spice and bit of sugar sweetness. Flavor of roasted malt, some dark fruit sweetness and bit of spice. Very subtle bitterness with a dry finish. Medium body, smooth and creamy. Nice touch of alcohol warming. Very well balanced.
 Very enjoyable. Nice offering of the style. Good beer to relax with.

Malty aroma, thin head with limited lacing. Dark brown / black in color with white head.  Very light carbonation. Complex malty character, with smoke and caramel in abundance. Thin mouthfeel.  Overall very good.
Deep chocolate malty aroma. Pours a deep clear brown with a tan head that fades quick.Sour with a hint of sweetness. The roasted malts are on the strong side.

Bottle

Aroma: dark fruits, malty

Taste: again with the dark fruits and huge maltiness

This is an amazing Dopplebock. I understand why it sets the standard. Had this at one of my top ten live concerts. What a great beer experience.

Gift from my brother-in-law. Beer pours a Dark mahogany-brown pour into thick tan head that quickly dissipates into a ring of foam around the glass. Aroma of malty roasted chocolate and sweet fruit. The aroma flavor of sweet malty caramel that fades into bitter dark chocolate with a smoky, buttery nut finish. This is a good beer i will drink

From a green glass bottle.

Smell is of a German hopped brew, nothing skunked

Looks dark brown, opaque.

Taste is sweet malts but lacking in the chocolaty roasted notes and full body you expect with the style. Slight sour note. Boozy/hoppy finish. Not bad, but a bit sweet and thin.

Reddish color in the glass.  Medium head.  Aroma is caramel and a little grass.  Taste is pretty mild.  Sweet finish due to the caramel malt.  Burns in your mouth with alcohol just a little.  It is slightly creamy too.

Nicely perfumed aroma with a yeasty undertone, and some metal in there also.  Nicely balanced, pretty easy DB.  The yeast shows in the flavor, and there is caramel in the finish.  It is a good brew, but a littler overrated.  I bet it would be better fresh.

A deep chestnut brown- it’s on the darker side for the style, but I like that (dark like the Korbinian, my favorite).  Aroma is equal parts pilsnery grass, lager yeast byproduct (sulfur..?), and caramel of medium darkness.  This beer was served a bit too cold so I suspect caramel will grow to dominate as it warms, but right now it’s quite a bit restrained for the style.  Medium bodied, moderate coarse carbonation in the mouthfeel.  Yeah, the caramel isn’t dominating the flavor either, its moderate and balanced with a considerable amount of easy-going noble hop flavor and bitterness.  Hmmm.  It’s good, but it doesn’t have the character of a great doppelbock.  It tries to make up for a lack of malt complexity with extra hops I think.
Pours dark reddish brown with big creamy off white head.  Aroma is roasted malt and earthy hops.  Taste is sweet caramel with some roasted character.  Not the best doppelbock but ok.

What an awesome German doppelbock!!  Once poured I knew I was in for a treat when I gazed upon that deep, DEEP dark brown/near black delicious body!  Taste and smell are dazzled by a grand balance between malt and hops; not too bitter and not too sweet.  The body is good and thick; I like to tease folks by saying it’s “thick but not too chewy!”  I think it’s time to go back and enjoy a few more!

Tap pours garnet like black, smell is porter like with fruit and roastiness. It is sweet with a punch of fruit, red grapes and some red apple with others. A touch of earthy spices from hops add a little balance. It does not hide strength but goes down pretty easy. Enjoyable for the style for sure.
Pours a small white quickly diminishing head aroma is of malt chocolate walnuts ,taste is smooth and highly drinkable with a clean finish would buy again thumbs up!!

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into clear mug.

Appearance: Dark chestnut brown with nice root beer float head at first, which dies down.

Aroma: Cherry, noble hops, caramel and chocolate.

Taste: Semi-sweet at first with cherry, caramel, molasses, soy sauce and chocolate. Turns drier and spicier at the end from a decent level of noble hops.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, medium-full body, nice dry finish. No cloyingly sweet at the finish like so many Doppelbocks.

Overall: Great example of a Doppelbock that manages to have a sweet malty taste while also maintaining a fairly dry and spicy palate. Not quite top tier, but well above average.
Bottle. Excellent!! Great caramel malt flavor. Toffee, nutty aroma. Deep amber-brown color. Great stuff!!
Pours chestnut with tan head.  Nose is flat with nut, bread.  Medium in the mouth with active carbonation.  Tangy and bitter moving to a smooth rye and caramel malt with some brown sugar.  Nice.

Pours a dark reddish brown. Small amount of white head that quickly dissipated. Aroma is mostly roatyness with some chocolate and smoky. Very malty, some caramel at first then some chocolate and  roastyness then it finishes with a slight smoky flavor. I got a small amount of metallic taste which kinda sucks, but its not that bad. Cant taste any hops really. Im not a huge fan of this style of beer but this is pretty good stuff.

Ar: Raisins and sweet malt, a touch of dark caramel.
Ap: Deep chestnut brown, very small head, but good lacing retention - crystal clear.
T: Deep toasted malt with rich rum-like alcohol flavor - medium-sweet, a rich and full maltiness persists - finish is medium-low bitter, with a touch of spiciness - warm caramel finish.
P: Medium carbonation, full mouthfeel - nice firm body with a fair bit of sweetness, but not cloying at all, well balanced with malt, alcohol and hops for a clean and firm finish.
O: This beer is a treat - rich, delicious, and so deeply malty - really a slam-dunk for the style.

Good cost effective dopplebock.  This beer is smooth and easy drinking for a 7.6% abv beer. Taste is malts like the style should be with very light bittering to balance it out and not make it cloyingly sweet.  Good work.

Great malty doppelbock, points for being easy accessible. Sweet aroma, no real hops are foward, enough to not make it a czech beer, balance out some of the malts. I like it but I really can’t drink to many of this style.
This is a good solid- Excellent Dopple Bock. Dark brown translucent color. Medium head with strong malts. So nice and smooth, weak head.

A dark brown beer with a reddish tinge and a lingering tan head.  The aroma is sweet malt, caramel, and a bit earthy.  The flavor is roasted and just a little lemony and sweet.  Not a bad beer, but not up my alley.

Pretty good brew.  Pours a deep dark brown, very little head.  Taste is nutty, sweet, with enough of a bitter bite at the end.  Medium to thick bodied, but goes down easy.  Good beer, opened up in the flavor as it warmed up.

A clear, reddish mahogany pour with an off-white head.  The aroma has notes of bread, nuts, and caramel.  The full body has a creamy texture with average carbonation.  The taste is moderately sweet until a mild hop bitterness appears in the finish.

12 oz. bottle from my local grocery. Perhaps one of my staples. Even at a not so modest 7.8%, I’d still consider this almost a session beer, but that session would need to end at the sixth one, max, for the sake of the next morning. Roasted malt, hint of caramel, slight bitterness up front, but a smooth finish. Great doppelbock, only falls short of the Ayinger Doppelbock, in my opinion, as best doppelbock I’ve had. Bring a sixer to your next social gathering to show your friends how much more of a bad ass you are for indulging in these instead of their anhueser busch fizzy, water. 
SKAL!

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep amber brown with a creamy thick light tan head. Aroma is nice and malty with plenty of caramel, toffee, nuttiness and a pronounced dark fruit character. Flavor starts with a strong sweet bready malt character, with lots of caramel and toffee, a bit earthy before the fruits really come out in the creamy smooth finish. Medium to medium full body and a soft carbonation. Really nice

Bottle-- dark brown pour with a slight red outline, the head doesn’t stick around.   Aroma is wonderful roasted caramel and toffee. The taste was a not quite syrupy caramel and hops.  An almost great brew. Produce place.

A great Doppelbock!!  Well balance of hops and nutty malts.  Good German style brew, better at room temperature (62 degrees).  Hides the 7.6% abv, but it will hit you.  Well balanced, It does have a strong bitter aftertaste.

What a surprise this was. Poured a nice amber and had a thick creamy head. Notes were very roasty; burnt caramel popcorn, hops and a lingering mellow sweet scent. The flavor was of hops, toffee and lightly roasted malts - just a tad bitter and spicy but VERY smooth. The best dopplebock I’ve had so far, and took me completely by surprise.

Gorgeous deep, dark brown with lush caramel notes. A mocha coloured head that subsided quickly. The aromas are all about the malt.It’s caramelly, chocolatey, roasty and nutty. Just sexy all over with mature character. The more you smell it, the more rich dried fruits you get: apricots, peaches and guava.
It’s those fruit flavours that lead caramel nto te palate. This is full bodied and very rich. Definitely a food rather than a drink this one. The finish lasts and gives a rather interesting bitterness. A classic. One of those beers that you have to try in order to compare others to.

Appearance: very dark ruby-brown, slightly translucent, thin head. Aroma: fresh-baked chocolate muffins, with hints of leather, wood, and raisins. Taste: rich and sweet. Mouthfeel: smooth, creamy, thick. Other notes: hardly any hops, somewhat decadent flavor, not very refreshing, heavy.

12 oz Bottle.  Appearance is deep mahogany with medium, off-white head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma is toasted malts with note of caramel.  Taste is heavily malt with roasted grains, toast, and a mild caramel sweetness.  Practically zero hop character or bitterness.  Palate is full-bodied, smooth texture, soft carbonation, and a long sweet finish.  This beer belongs in the upper tier of German Doppelbocks.

500ml bottle / $2.49 @ Whole Foods.  The dirty, sandy, head dissolves to lacing edge in no more than 20 seconds.  Clear body is the color of strong, pekoe tea.  Lacing goes from frosty or semi-frosty to nothing in four seconds.
Aroma is hoppy and hard wood, nuts and a little floral. 
Taste is a medium bitter and a mild salty with some distant sweet floral play.  One might characterize the taste experience as maple syrup or (floral) honey.  A little rye bread aroma carries in the tasting.  Tastes healthy.
Palate is medium full and creamy with good, mouth-filling carbonation and fairly abrupt finish.
A good deal on a good dopplebock.

Bottle.  Pours a deep red-brown with a pronounced cinnamon head. Nose is light and has notes of molasses and spice. Smoky on the tongue; not much sweetness, and there’s definite elements of nuts and roasted grain. Finishes clean, and has a creamy touch to the mouthfeel. One of the classics.
Pours a medium-dark brown with a slight red tint. Aroma is sweet with a hint of alcohol. Flavor is sweet and caramelly. Good, full bodied with a roasty finish. Solid.

Bottle in a mug - pours dark amber with little head. Malty aroma and I detect chocolate with a roasted character.  Taste is sweet. Aftertaste is long and leaves a coffee quality. Overall, a tasty brew that is not overpowering with its malts.

Pours a deep red-brown; tall foamy tan head.  Fragrant hoppy-sweet aroma.  Taste is rich toasty caramel malt.  Almost syrupy rich but balanced with a healthy amount of hops.  Taste is awesome but it’s as rich if not richer than a big belgian dubbel...a little on the cloying side.  Overall, it’s a top quality beer.

Notice: Not sure who else has discovered this but, Spaten Optimator has changed it’s label (again) and, apparently their formula. It’s now more sour, almost like a Belgian Ale.
I had a new one about a week ago and thought maybe it was skunky...or that maybe it was just my taste buds.
But then i noticed the label was different and had an older one at another location. Yep! They changed it.

AUG 21st, 2014 - On Tap @ Mr. Dunderbak’s, Sarasota Square Mall (in 1983).
The best beer i’ve ever had! It’s my absolute favorite.
 Dark, malty, nutty flavored, full-bodied...it’s delicious!
 Goes great with Thai curry, Gruyere cheese, just about any meats, bar-b-ques, sausages, brats...etc.
 Try cooking Nathan’s hotdogs in it...Oh yeah! ;p

Bottle/12oz - Pours a caramel brown in color with a small off-white head.  Aroma is medium skunky (green bottle), but really dominated by a dark roasted malty sweetness.  Flavor is also pretty malty and medium sweet... just a bit too for me.  Lingering sweetness and also a bit astringent in the finish.  The skunk is a major turn off for what should have been a fairly decent beer... green bottles SUCK!!
very good dopplebock; definitely a tier below celebrator but still good.  malty sweet; good palate not much hop at end

I don’t see how this is rated 97, its one of the cheaper imports at my local liquor store and the taste isn’t that appealing. It has a strong dark roasted malty taste that develops into a very strong aftertaste. I love dark beers but the taste of Optimator is just a bit too much to call it an easy drinking beer. Its good, has a strong taste, strong ABV, but after I’ve had one I don’t really want another.
Definate alcohol on the back of the throat, easy beer to drink. I don’t believe it does get better as it warms though. While a great example of the stye, is more average in the overall catagory.

A: The beer pours a caramel color with a small off-white head.  Not terribly impressive.

S: At first the nose is quite harsh.  Slightly burnt with a little bit of a funkiness to it.  However, as I let it warm up, the beer starts to come around and displays some nice caramel and dark fruit sweetness, as well as some toasted bread.

T: Similar story with the flavor.  The first few sips are harshly alcoholic and astringent with a little bit of cough syrup.  As it warmed up, some of that went away and some of the more traditional and pleasant flavors of caramel, raisin, and black cherry came through.

M: Medium in body with a medium level of carbonation.

O: Hard to rate this beer as it did have some good flavors, but it also had some bad ones.

a pint and a few extra oz bottle.  nice pour as dark as bottle, nice ivory head to add.  nose is thinly roasty, warm and bready.  tastes a nice warm "liquid bread"  nice rich malts, slightly so roasty, nutty.  decision; not a bad doppel.
Really crisp. It was a full bodied medium finish. Lots of carbonation. I bought a six pack and I am happy about it.

12 oz. bottle from HyVee Marion

Ar:  Strong cola aroma, classic dopplebock aroma that I can’t specifically describe.  Nice, as expected.
Ap:  Pours a deep ruby brown with a 3/4" manila head.
T:  Big malty body, lots of toffee and cola flavors.  A touch of hops on the finish.
P:  Thick, sticky body with a pretty solid carbonation load.

O: Typical doppelbock, thoroughly enjoyable.
Dark brown with reddish tint. Off white head, some lacing. Bread, malts and earthiness. thick, syrupy with crisp carbonation.

12 oz. pours dark brown with a small amount of head. Has a slight metallic smell along with caramel, nuts and just a hint of floral hops. Very nice roasted caramel notes, toffee and roasted nuts. Mouthfeel is medium and the finish is medium as well with a roasted bitterness that just comes through along with a little hops right at the end.

Reddish-brown with a thick head that tapered to a thin layer. Smooth entry with a malty, full mouthfeel and a raisiny, dark chocolate sweetness that pervades throughout especially in the somewhat bitter finish. Has some alcohol warming evident in the end.

Reviewed from notes. The beer that once disgusted Amyliz4 but that she now loves.

Pours a moderate brown caramel color win a light tan head with some good lasting power in my pilsner glass. Nose brings caramel, toffee, and some light drugs. The taste is a bit sweet with some caramel, though not too much depth. Nice body and carbonation. A beer I used to drink fairly often and don’t mind coming back to at all.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-26-2010
Poured from a 12oz bottle.  Pours dark brown with a bit of beige head.  Aroma is roasted malts.  Taste is pretty typical of a dopplebock....lots of toasted malt flavor and some sweetness.
Tasty beer. Full bodied but very drinkable. Has the classic Doppelbock aroma of fruits and molasses. Taste is very rich and smooth.

At a tasting at "The 1st beer festival at The Anchor Pub", on-tap, 7.2% ABV, pours very dark brown with a nice head that dissipates very slowly, fruity and sweetish aroma, chocolate, caramel and toasted taste, nice lacing, feeling dry palate, medium body, and overall an excellent beer and a great Doppelbock.

Spaten Optimator is a copper brown lager with a thin khaki head that fades to a turbulent film and leaves nice lacing.  It has a deep, malty aroma: bready and a bit sweet.  It smells grainy and spicy with a hint of apple, perhaps.  In the mouth, it’s full bodied and a little sharp.  The finish is a little sticky.  It’s pretty sweet and raisny, with notes of prune and maybe fig.  It’s very malty and bready.  The finish has a hint of bitter juniper and alcohol.  It’s a sturdy drink, too hardy to session, but it’s quite smooth.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown, opaque.  Aroma is almost non existent.  A little caramel and molasses.  Taste is mildly sweet.  Caramel, molasses, maybe even a little nutty.  Not a bad beer.  German beers can be pretty interesting.
Love me some cheap doppelbocks! This one is great for the money nice dark head a rich taste!

Aroma is sweet, almost corn malts. Taste is similar sweet malts, but with a bit of roastiness. Bitterness is pretty mild. Overall a little disappointing with an odd mix of taste, but still very drinkable.

The Optimator is really a great beer and at a great price.  The hints of nuttiness, lots of malt, and brown sugar flavors are great.  This beer is actually really sweet tasting when drunk with food.  Great beer!!
12oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours brown with a beige head.  Aroma of roasted malts, a little bit of nuts, and some toffee.  Flavor about the same.  Has an average texture.  A pretty good dopplebock.

Let me first say, for the money, this is probably the best imported German Doppel Bock you can get.  with that said, it is not the best beer in that category.  However, it is quite enjoyable.  
malty nose with some kind of fruity notes(grape, raisin, plum) I can’t really place it.  Very thin/to non-existent off-white rimming head, but a nice tawny brown(as per style); flavor drops at first, but feels smooth and silky on the tongue but finishes with a fizzy zing and a strong flavor in the finish balanced between the sweet malt/fruit(as in the aroma) but a note of some hop bite flavor.
Rich malty nose and taste to match.  Pours dark brown with a thin head.  Very rich malty flavor.  Hops are deeply buried.  Somewhat "salty" finish?  I enjoyed it a lot.

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of malt, & some spice; Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, and coffee; Slight alcohol at the finish; Nicely balanced; Overall, the aroma was lacking - but the flavor was good.
Dark color with a deep red tint. Aroma.. deep malt, taste is good, malty with a sweet taste then smokey with some fruity undertones. Enjoyable but seems to be missing something to be great.

Such a fun beer. Dark pour with a fluffy white head. Aroma is mild and warm, but doesn’t quite match the flavor, which is really great. Taste is subtly fruity and chocolatey. Not too sweet, bitter, nor complex.

Quick, highly-carbonated pour into a thin, bubbling head.  Dark red with a malty aroma.  Yeasty taste with malt undertones.  Slight hoppy aftertaste with a yeasty taste that sticks around quite a bit.  Maybe it’s just a class of brew that I’m not into, but not a fan.
Oily, brown color with no head. The flavor was kind of a sweet caramel with some raisen notes. Not too bad.
Little aroma, dark ruby color. Flavors of roasted caramel and some clove and anise notes, but still very balanced and palatable. Pretty good.

Bottle. Dark ruby, ultimately clear, with a nice head. Rich beer, although not syrupy (which I don’t prefer). I don’t get a lot of roasted out of this, but it is malty sweet. Slight alcohol  warmth. Not super tasty. Good, not great.
bottle. malty and chocolatey. Smells of maltand coffee> taste is similar with a mild hopness. Almost more like a stout. very good

ruby brown pour with a medium head.
aroma is dusty chocolate, roasted malt, toffee. slight nuttiness and dark fruit tones.
flavour is roasted malt and toffee sweetness with dark fruit, some woody bitterness .
Apparently I don’t agree with the masses because I really did not like this beer. It had a bitter fruit taste that just didn’t sit well at all. The alcohol content was nice, but thats about it.
Pours a red-tinged brown in the glass.  Aroma of dried fruits and roasted malt.  Nice roasted malt flavors.  Rich mouthfeel.  Lengthy finish.

Pours dark reddish brown, thin white head.  Aroma has notes of sweet caramel, dark fruit, some earth, and a touch of biscuit.  Taste is a sweet combination of caramel, touch of chocolate, leading into some earthy malt, biscuit, finishing sweet. Not bad.
A nice, robust doppelbock. Make sure you get a fresh bottle, they recently have come out with a new label, I’d suggest you get ti now.
Pours deep brown with thick foamy tan head and lacing.  Pleasant notes of malt and hops.  Initial taste is of malty sweetness, followed by a short bitter finish.
Pours dark with thick tan head.  I get lots of wheat and alcohol.  Slightly bitter, more so than other German dopplebocks, but it smooths out in its finish.  Nice warm "feel" from its alcohol.

What you would expect from a full bodied Bock.  Strong aroma, featuring malt, syrup and hints of fruit.  Pours a dark, dark amber with a tan head that dissipates rather quickly.  Taste is robust with a great malty finish. Full bodied in the mouth with a light sweetness and a little bitter.  Enjoyable and would drink again

Reddish brown pour with a light tan head. Smells primarily of dark fruits, caramel, toffee, and nuts. Taste is about the same, with more emphasis on the caramel and roast features, though still a fair amount of fig flavor. Palate is velvety smooth. Hard to pass up a classic German doppelbock like this. I go back and forth between which of the big three I like best (Spaten, Ayinger, and Paulaner), and this one certainly holds its own.

Appearance - little head that disappears quickly.  If it were in a mug, one might think it were coffee.

Aroma of molasses, caramel, and chocolate.  

Taste a light sweetness.  Unexpectedly sweet for a dopplebock.

Palate - light carbonation that adds a surprising bite.  A long finish that reinforces the initial aroma.

Overall - Dopplebocks aren’t my favorite, but this surprised me in how much I liked it.

bittke.
Dark mahogeny pour with a nice red hue - head dissapated quickly to the edges.  Lots of caramel malt flavor and aroma - this is a great Doppelbock!  Perfect for a cold winter day.

Pours dark amber with red and orange hues. Moderate loose head dissipates quickly, leaving no lacing. After a minute it looks like a glass of wine, clear and oily.
Smell of black bread crust, molasses, sweet malt, raisins, faint grassy hops.
Taste: again lots of molasses, raisins, black bread crust, very sweet and cloying malt, some caramel, alcohol is not obvious. Some lingering bitterness, not much hop character.
Mouthfeel is oily, dense. Sip beer.
Highlights: feels like drinking malt extract. too sweet for my taste and smell/taste is too overwhelmingly straightforward. Well made, bot not very interesting beer.

deep dark mahogany with nice dense off-white head.  Rich malty nose.  Full body and malty, what this style is all about but the hops do provide a nice follow up bite.  A great winter night brew.  A classic.

From 12oz green bottle pours vibrant ruby with quickly diminishing mixed-bubble beige head. Prominent Pils malt toasty-rich aroma in this medium-lean bodied, smooth lager. The Pils sweetness dominates the flavor. Also, there’s rich dark malt and cola notes, with a mid-palate noble hop bump followed by a balancing alcohol warmth that goes a bit towards fusel.
Good caramel malt flavor, could do without the green bottle, especially when I don’t know how long the bottle has been setting out.  Good doppelbock, probably better to have in Germany fresh.
bottle: medium brown pour. Roasty aroma of grain. Medium body, very slightly bitter stronger grain flavor.
one of my top beers. amazing doppelbock. alkfmasdlkfmdsfmdaamfffodfmfomnfdsfsf

Dark brown/maroon color with some ruby highlights when held to the light.  Also has some burnt orange and yellow highlights around the bottom and sides.  An off white head with average size and retention.  It settled to a decent film and left some pretty good lacing.  In the aroma, I picked up a dark, earthy, almost burnt grass or gain.  Never quite smelled anything like it thus far.  Not particularly my favorite smell, but I got used to it.  After a while it started to remind me of a more robust Dunkel.  The taste also has a very dark, earthy, robust type of flavor.  Reminds me fo a "Black" Lager as well as a Dunkel.  I picked up subtle hints of lard with the earthy grain.  A touch of sweetness even.  Just a hint of alcohol at the very end.  Medium mouthfeel.  Left adequate amounts of flavor on the palate.  Relatively smooth, but just a wee bit watery.  This beer would take some getting used to for me.  It’s nothing really bad.  It’s just different.  I do love the color of this brew, but I personally don’t think I could make a night of it.  Doppelbocks just must not be my thing.

Aroma is excellent.  Color is perfect.  Hops bitterness is subdued.  Alcohol flavor is mild, but plenty of malt on the tongue.  Hints of nuttiness, a little bit of acid and roast.

Sampled out of a bottle purchased at the grocery store, so probably not that closely related to the real thing as served in Germany.

Pours a clear, dark, cola red; good finger of fine off-white head. Smell is of sweet biscuity malts; not much variety, but enjoyable nonetheless. Taste is of sweet, caramel malts with a hint of black licorice. Somewhat watery and simple; not a big fan. Thin bodied with moderate carbonation, and a slightly syrupy/sticky mouthfeel.

12 oz. bottle poured to an SA lager glass with a clear, brown/mahogany hue, abundant, tan bubbles that morphed into a frothy, creamy head, and clingy bands & spots of etched-like lacing that spiraled down the interior of the glass. The aroma was some grain, light roast, caramel, rich malt and a hint of dark plum that shared the sweetness. The flavor continued the rich malt with moderate hop bitterness, well rounded alcohol warmth, a slight hint of cocoa, and a pleasant creaminess to the mouthfeel. Always a favorite dark Doppel, but please drop the green bottles so that I can cellar a few with no worries!
Pours deep red to brown with a medium cream color head, aroma of malt, caramel, honey, bread and cookies, flavor of honey, caramel and toffee, simple and nice with a medium to full body.

This beer surprised me.  I bought it in a Spaten mix pack, and I wasn’t sure what to expect.  Deep brown body with a thin tan head that leaves some spotty lacing.  Nice, sweet aroma of carmel, brown sugar and maybe a touch of smoke.  Full mouthfeel, slick and smooth.  The flavor just jumps out.  Brown sugar, dark fruits, and just a bite of smoke at the end.  Wow!  I picked up on the alcohol content, but it’s only warming, not overpowering.  Very tasty brew.

Rich Malty Sweetness with a Warmth provided by the alcohol without burning.  The color is spot on for its style.  The finish leaves you wanting another sip leaving behind the robust malt flavor without being overbearing.  One of my all-time favorites!
On tap at Fox and Hound. Aromas of chocolate, dark fruits, bready malts, and spices. Flavor is a lot like the aroma with good amount of chocolate with bready malt and spices. Pretty solid beer.

rich, with strong malt flavors. Not hoppy. Hints of caramel, smoke and anise.
Strong but smooth.
a nice doppelbock , not as sickly sweet as ayinger’s celebrator, with a little bit too little aroma and flavor, but very smooth and lightly carbonated.

Deep ruby/brown pour with a medium foamy head that sticks around a while. Aroma of sweet roasty caramel malt and light sweet fruitiness. Flavor is the same. Loads of roasty malt and hints of Caramel. A bit of alcohol bite on the finish, but not enough to be distracting, still smooooth. Body needs to be a bit heavier. Not the Best Doppel Bock....But this is well worth it. Thanx Doug K.

Draught, stable creamy head, beautifull clear deep brown colour, aroma of strawberry jam and sherry with some dried fruit and honey appearing as the beer warms up, flavour of bread, strawberry  jam, with oxidised notes and nuts, very sweet with a medium bitterness and a light sourness complementing. A good solid dopplebock though a bit one dimensional.

Bottle.

A - Deeper amber color, but for the style it is a little light. Smaller than average sized, foamy, creamy, off-white head. Disappears pretty fast with a thin ring of lace.

S - Slightly burnt caramel and carob. Plenty of sweet dark fruit, especially raisin along with a plumy aroma and slightly jamy. Some dark, sweet bready malt as well. Some fruity, apple along with a hint of alcohol.

T - Like the nose, there is a good amount of dark fruit with raisin and a plumy flavor as well as a touch of apple. Also a fair amount of molasses and carob. Quite malty and some dark, sweet bread along with some slightly torched caramel. A touch of nuttiness.

M - Lighter side of medium (pretty light for the style) with about average carbonation. Smooth and a touch creamy, but just a little too thin for my liking.

D - Pretty easy to drink and enjoyable, although it is pretty sweet and has a pretty big jamy feel. Alcohol shows up but doesn’t dominate. I could drink another but that’s about it.

Notes: Enjoyable beer but not my favorite doppelbock. This one is more of a fruity doppelbock rather than chocolate. Definitely worth a try, especially given its history, but I don’t think it is my favorite of the style.

Esta es mi primera cerveza alemana preferida. El color obscuro, con cuerpo decente, notas dulces y amargas encontradas, sabor fresco que deja sentir su grado de alcohol y dulzura. Al final un sabor dulce que se convierte en amargor delicado. Una buena cerveza que me ha dado momentos inolvidables. La recomiendo ampliamente!

Poured from a bottle without a freshness label or a brewing date into a standard pint glass. Beer is dark brown and completely clear. Carbonation moderate and the head is made up of small off white bubbles that form a uniform layer on the top of the beer. Lacing in moderate.

Nice sweet aroma. Some caramel, no hops or roast to speak of. Smells like a good doppelbock.

Full bodied, some tinge of bitter in there, but mostly sweet and a slight darker malt almost schwartz character. Drinkability high and mouthfeel is great. This is a wonderful beer and a great experience. I reviewed this on draft and in the bottle now, both great ways to drink.

Serving type: bottle

on tap: caramel, carob, hay, organics, some grainy notes, some spicey notes, honey, sweet malt, some dried fruits, some fresh yellow dates, as it warms up sour notes arrive, in the finish as well, quite simple doppelbock but enjoyable.

i really love this beer, i wish i could get it fresher because then i think it would hold up even better. my only complaint, if i can build a negative case against it is that it could use a fuller body/mouthfeel to acompany all the flavor

THOUGHTS: Nice. Not the best doppel I’ve ever had, but certainly not the worst. A little watered down. It would probably be better in a brown bottle. A bit metallic, probably caused by the green bottle. Gets a bit cloying.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a clear, very dark reddish amber that was nearly brown in the glass with an average to large head that mostly diminished and left excellent lacing at first and then just good. The aroma was moderate to heavy, dark bread, grain, molasses and caramel; light yeast; underlying grassy hops; and raisin, prune, apple, maple syrup and alcohol. The initial flavor was rather sweet, slightly acidic and lightly bitter; while the finish was very sweet and fairly bitter with an average to long duration. There was caramel, maple syrup, alcohol, a little fruit, grassy and metallic hops, molasses. prune, raisin, yeast and grain. The light to medium body leaned more toward medium and was syrupy, yet slick and then dry with light to moderately fizzy carbonation and chalky, alcoholic, dry and lightly metallic finish.

Boring Doppelbock...it has lots of caramel/licorice sweetness, and nothing else. Surprisingly unidimensional and light for a  7.2% (and for a db). Not "best in class" but an excellent way to round out a sixer at WM, considering the alternatives!
In bottle; pours dark brown with the aroma of plum, cocoa and brown sugar. Taste of dry cocoa notes, subtle caramel. Very easy drinking dopplebock given the alcohol %.

Tasted from a 0.5 L bottle purchased in Denver, Colorado.  Red-black appearance with a great, sweet Doppelbock aroma.  Sweet, almost licorice flavor.  Not my favorite German Doppelbock because of the sweet licorice flavor.

12 ounce bottle purchased over a year ago at Trader Joe’s ($1.25).  Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights and one finger of light beige foam that soon disappears into nothingness.  Aroma of caramel candy mostly with lighter notes of candied fruit and a hint of alcohol.  Flavor also is very full of smooth caramel along with lesser notes of dark fruit and smoke.  Nice level of sweetness and a very smooth finish.  Not a lot of excitement or complexity in this doppelbock, but it is nicely drinkable.  (1471, 418)
Bottle. Clear brown with small beige head. Toasty malty aroma.  Flavor is very malty, soy sauce, alcohol, and a little bitter grain finish. Medium bodied, creamy mouth feel.
Bottle.  Malty aroma.  Med head.  Light sweetness.  Light to med bodied.  Creamy texture.  Malty taste.  But this is really well done malty beer.  Smooth flavor.
Another great Germanic brew. This one is high alcohol content (but actually have of whats in the Schloss!). Really good!

Dark amber mahogony-brown pour into thick tan head that quickly dissipates into melting lacing and a ring of foam around the glass. Aroma of malty roasted chocolate and sweet fruit. Initial flavor of sweet malty caramel that fades into bitter dark chocolate with a smoky, buttery nut finish.

a good mass produced doppelbock (my fav. style).  It has a bit of edge to it that other’s (paulaner, craft brewed, etc.) do not.  A very good beer overall, but there are better options for a doppelbock....if you can find them.  good "chocolatey" taste with a heavy mouth.  It just has a "twinge" to the tongue (high alcohol?) that keeps it from being a better beer.

Appearance:  pours like cherry cola, with rich ruby notes and a ton of bubbles. Aroma:  brown sugar, toasted black bread with honey butter, chocolate and cinnamon. Taste:  as the aroma indicates, almost exactly.  Finish:  slick, slightly viscous, then the carbonation and a hint of bitterness cleanse the palate.  Notes:  Nice doppelbock.  A little too oily on the mouth, though not as bad as the Troegs.  Delicious flavors, decent balance.  Hides the alcohol well.

Bottle poured into tulip glass. Aroma was very malty with some banana. Appearance was black with a ruddy brown hue. small creamy head. Taste was a malty toffee sweetness. A thick silky mouthfeel. The finish was mellow and round feeling. This is a good doppel bock.

Pours a deeo dark ruby color with a full creamy head.  Smells of sweet dark fruits such as raisins and plums but also sweet candied sugars.  The taste is sweet with a nice fruity character with raisins and deep plums.  The finish is medium length with a nice cereal grain character.

On draught @ Taco Mac Prado.  Poured dark brown with a one finger white head.  Aroma was roasty malts, some sweetness and nuts.  Flavors were malty sweet with some nice roast flavors throughout.  Mouthfeel was nice and full, drank super smooth, oily texture.  Carbonation was good for the style, nice.  Alcohol was virtually non-existent, a well done brew for sure.
This beer is far to drinkable for it’s strength. It is responsible for several fun but bad evenings. Malty, roasty, but balanced quite well. Dangerous. Serving: Tap and bottle

Pours a very dark brown with a small, short-lasting head.  Aroma is full of caramel, toffee and some nuttiness.  Taste is a sweet and nutty mix with a hint of bitterness at the end.  A classic beer of the style.

Pours a beautiful dark ruby with a small white head. The aroma is full of caramel and toffee, with dark fruits, slight roast, and some faint noble hops. The flavor is similar, with a slightly warm but clean finish. The mouthfeel is full and smooth with light but prickly carbonation. All in all a great doppelbock, very enjoyable.

Dark brown color, with a frothy tan-colored head, sweet toasted and caramelized malt nose, with a toffeeish accent, brown sugar, hint of dark dried fruits fruitiness in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a very sweet toasted malt character with some brown sugar, hint of nuttiness, dried raisins and plums fruitiness, leading towards a rich malty finish.

On Tap @ Munich Haus, Munich Haus is becoming a favorite spot fast!  Deep mahogany color with a medium thin light beige head that dissipates fairly fast. Thin rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of malt, molasses and a bit of plum. Medium body with a sweet toffee and malt character. Light fruit and hops are present as well but the sweetness dominates. The finish is sweet with caramel and roasted malt and leaves a molasses and brown sugar aftertaste.

A-pours a deep reddish brown color with an abundance of fluffy light tan colored head.

S-the nose brings a malt presence up front with notes of caramel and hints of coffee, light roasted quality, fussel alcohols present, light malt sweetness, grainy in the back with a light leafy hop presence.

T-richer malt presence than the nose, lots of rich caramel, toffee, dark malts, again a lightly roasted quiality with hints of slightly burnt coffee, the fussels are mild and enjoyable, the grain profile is faint and not off putting, some dark fruit maltiness towards the back and light leafy hop finish.

M-rich and creamy feel on a reasonably full chewy body with a well carbonated finish.

D-this is a darn tasty doppelbock with a good rich flavor profile and enough of a hop balance and light alcohol presence that make for a tasty rich beer.
Pours bark brown w scant brownish head; smells malty and under attenuated; tastes too sweet, almost a little syrupy; underimpressed
Dark rich flavor nice little bite to it. A Beer to put on your list a real man’s beer.

Bottle: Pours a dark amber, with a nice tan head to it. Smells : your what seems to be prototypical elements : a caramely malt, dried fruit/raisin sweetness, and the like. Flavors are similar, with the taste dominated I believe by sweetness. This brew masks the ABV well - I certainly enjoy it, but I doubt I’m the only one that has celebrator on the brain while sampling...

Have had this many times before and finally decided to rate it. Colour... dark garnet brown with a thick tan head that quickly dissipated. Nose... sweetly caramel-like with notes of molasses and turbinado. Palate... gently frothy, sweet, butter toffee and caramel with a tanginess on the back and side palate and a lingering roasted malt and brown sugar flavour. Zehr gut!

Spaten
Optimator
Pours reddish brown with a medium tan head and good retention. Minimal lacing. Aroma of malty cloves with mild notes of brown sugar and dark fruits. Flavor is similar. Mild dark fruits with some spiciness and caramel malts. Smooth easy drinking with slight hop notes on the finish. Good, but Celebrator and Salvator dopplebocks are both better.
