Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  Pours a dark brown with light brown highlights with a small off-white head.  Aroma is caramel, low carbonation, and little lacing.  Taste is chewy malt, some dark fruit (mostly fig).  Very little bitterness, sweet but not too sweet.
Full flavored, no bitterness, and not too sweet. One of the best dark beers in the world.

Bottle from Kihei Liquors on Maui. Lovely reddish brown colour with minimal tan head. Delivers exactly what the nose promises (chewy malt) and the palate is rich and rewarding. Mouth-feel is comfortably medium. Alcohol is well masked. Balanced. Delicious.
Not sure what a heavy taset is but this beer doesn’t have it! One of the best mass produced beers I’ve enjoyed.
Roasted malet aroma, brown / black color, very thin to non existent head.  Draft at bar.  Somewhat creamy, full texture.  Nice finish that lingers.

Bottle.  Pours a dark mahogany with a medium off-white head and some nice lacing.  Aroma and flavor are lots of caramel malt and dark fruit (raisins, figs, cherries), some vanilla, a touch of smokiness.  A little hoppiness in the finish.  A deep round flavor.  Full mouthfeel.  One of my favorites from one of my favorite styles.
Faint candied dates aroma... Color is clear ruby red... Taste is more dates, candi sugar, malts with a hint of leaf tobacco... Not much on the palate... Pretty drinkable beer
It’s not Ayinger, or even close, but it’s very drinkable. Malty flavor and amber in color

bottle.  pours a light brown with a 1/4" off white head... nice ruby tones in the glass.  very light aroma with some sweet malts and a touch of dark fruit.  medium body with nice apple, raisin, plum and fig notes throughout the mouth.  caramel and sweet roasted malts carry through towards the finish.  very light bitterness with a toasted grain finish.

12oz bottle.  Pours brown (red under light) with a small tan head.  Fades very quickly to a small ring and doesn’t leave a bit of lacing.  Aroma is caramel malt, raisins, figs, and other dark fruits, dark bread, cinnamon.  Quite malty on the nose, strength fades as it warms. Flavor features toffee, caramel, dark fruits, a bit of chocolate, bread, some sweetness, although not cloying, but does become more pronounced as the beer warms.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin, medium carbonation.  Nice Doppelbock, not to the level of the excellent Ayinger Celebrator, but MUCH better than the sticky sweet ones such as Sam Adams, Primator, etc...

Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, bread and a touch of alcohol.  Pours a clear yet deep dark ruby red, minimal white head.  Med-high sweetness, low bitterness.  Malt dominates this medium bodied beer, with a seemingly thin texture, alcohol is hidden well.  High carbonation, with a sweet finish that leaves the slightest hop touch on the tongue.  Very good malty doublebock.

[3114-20100704] Sample. Date-like raisin malt aroma has a hint of cocoa. Clear, dark red brown body with a quick foamy off-white head. Light boozy figgy fruit malt flavour has a long sweet roasty malt aftertaste. Medium-full body is boozy. Pretty good, great name.

(@ SIB 2010, Seattle, WA)
Sweet honey nut aroma and after taste.  Rich deep flavor with notes of brown sugar.  Just the right amount of bitter and plenty of sweet.  Very drinkable and not too heavy.

(16.9oz bottle).  Pours dark amber with chunky tan head.  Aroma of caramel, hayand leather.  Taste is sweet with nice caramel notes.  Medium bodied with creamy texture. Finish is long.  Optimator is a nicely balanced beer and easy to drink.  Nice beer.

Pours a dark auburn with a light brown head.  Smelled so good I accidentally put my nose in it.  But the taste was where I truly fell in love.  I’m not usually a fan of German beers.  I know they are some of the most popular brews in the world, but they’re just not my thing.  But the Spaten Optimator changed my mind on the entire genre.  Sweet notes of coffee, toffee, and mocha bombard the taste buds at first only to equalize with a bitter, alcoholic finish.  I simply frackin loved this beer.

Bottle. Aroma is caramel, molasses, butterscotch and candied figs. Appearance is dark reddish brown with an inch of milky white head. Taste starts off with strong caramel malt and toffee flavors along with cocoa, raisins, dried figs and brown sugar. Mouthfeel is slightly creamy with medium carbonation and a dry finish. Overall, this is a solid Doppelbock that’s packed with strong dark sugar and roasted malt flavors. Thankfully, it’s not cloyingly sweet and it goes down relatively smooth.

Pint served at the Fort Worth Gingerman.

The beer pours a dark brown color with an off-white head. The aroma has notes of caramel with some dark fruit mixed in. The flavor is just as good if not better. I get some caramel malts, bready malts, grapes, dark fruit and molasses. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Bottled, amber pour with ruby highlights and medium tan head, dark fruits with light caramel aroma, roasted malt sweet toffee with slight floral hop finish, medium body with high carb and lingering malt finish.
Malty aroma. Dark amber color with a small tan head. Very sweet beginning developing a mild bitterness in the finish.

Pours a dark, yet clear toffee brown.  Little in the way of head; some white wispy lacing.  Funky, slightly musty aromas.  Thin mouthfeel with moderately sharp effervescence--quite pleasant.  Nice malty taste, with toffeeness abounding.  Great bock.

Bottle pour gives clear cola color with brief thin light tan head.  Aroma light malts and caramel.  Palate a bit thin.  Taste sweet malts, slight dark fruits.  Not much carbonation  Finish clean with a touch of bitterness.  Alcohol not detectable.

Just OK, not a bad choice if you don’t have something better available.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark amber-caramel brown. Smells of roasted malt, caramel, molasses, and just a hint of licorice. Tastes of roasted caramel malt, brown sugar, and notes of fig and nut. Very smooth. Well-balanced and full-bodied. "Blessing of your heart - you brew good ale." In this case, ’strong lager’. --Shakesbeere
Heavy but good, the alcohol is notable, but not so much as the rich maltiness. Quite sweet with hints of liquorice - really good.

Pours a dark ruby red with light tan head.The aroma is of brown sugar and a little alcohol.It’s got the flavor of toffee and molasses.Leaves a mostly bitter and slightly sweet aftertaste.I would buy this again.

this is a surprise import beer.  label says malt liquor and threw me away for many years.  actually an extremely smooth beer.  almost baker-powder sugary with a strong touch of chocolate.  this beer would topple houses if it had a little bit of bitter dry finnish.  never the less, i like it.  ultra smooth.  7.3 is not detectable.  no skunk taste like another german import i know of.  I would love to have this one close to the born on date.  may never happen.  2.59 for a pint is reasonable.  i’ll go again.  shit.  i used to spend 5 dollars for a forty of O.E. when i was 16 out the ice cream truck.  I’d rather not compare this one to O.E.  Malt Liquor is a loose term is what i learned today.

I had this Spaten Optimator on draft at Volksfest at Deutches Haus in New Orleans in May, 2010.  It has a thin, beige head, and a moderately carbonated and dark brown appearance.  Taste and aroma is roasted and caramel (to an extent).  Body is medium.  It finishes heavy.  This is a very good beer, and I highly recommend it.

RJT
On tap at The Taphouse, pours black with a tan head. Aroma of sweet caramel malts, molasses and dark fruits. Flavour is dominantly sweet caramel malts, with a full-bodied palate. Really good one.

1 PT 9 Fl. Oz. bottle from BevMo Long Beach.

Aroma is herbal and spicy with dark malt roastiness. Pours a dark reddish brown with a small off white foam head. Taste is signature doppelbock with a smooth slightly warm finish. Palate is perfect. Just enough body and carbonation to complement the style. Overall an incredible doppelbock and very nicely priced. Will definitely drink again.
Bottle. Dark brown with creamy head. Aromas of caramel, fig and roasted nut. Flavors of caramel, fig and roasted nuts. Medium body with light carbonation.

Malty fruity aroma. Perfectly clear rosewood color with creamy head. Medium sweet taste of raisens (or is it dates?) with a little smoke. medium body with good carb. Creamy texture but not sticky. Long tasty finish. Very nice and light for a dark beer. Could drink several (especially after the Pens loss).

on tap poured into a pint glass at the flying saucer in san antonio.

smells of cream and cherry to me.  poured with a thin head that went away fast.  the color is deep brown with a hint of red.  the taste is cherry and oak.  a little sweet for my style.  interresting none the less.

caramel, dark fruit maybe raisin, sweet roasty malt and dark...yummy yummy yummy...a great deal at $10 a  sixer at Whole Foods...a little booziness, just a hint, makes for an enjoyable tipping brew on a chilly rainy night

Optimator--1998 16.9 oz. Bottle.  6.00% ABV.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Doppelbock.  Rich clear black cherry color.  Rich thick cherry caramel malt body.  Slightly sweet and bock smooth as rich flavor coats mouth.  Tingle of balanced bitterness at end clears palette.  Nice.  Sampled 3/30/1999.

Optimator Doppelbock--2000 12 oz. Bottle.  7.20% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Clear deep cherry walnut color.  Rich smooth sweet flavorful malty body.  Medium heavy texture.  Bavarian Yeast off flavor in character. Clear bottle. Cherry caramel toasted flavors.  Smooth to end.  Sampled 3/14/2000.

Optimator Doppelbock--2001 12 oz. Bottle.  7.20% ABV.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Lightly hazy rich amber red golden color.  Malty laced head.  Floral hop bouquet leads into tasty pale malt body with malty light caramel biscuit fruit flavor.  Balanced smooth lingering malt hop finish.  Sampled 6/21/2001.

Spaten-Brau, Munich, Germany--SPATEN Optimator Doppelbock--Green Label--2010 16.9 oz. Bottle.  7.60% ABV.  20 IBU’s?  (3.5 / 5.0)  Thick pour.  No sediment.  Light tan 1/2" mild lace dissipating head.  Clear dark ruby edged black color.  Toasted black cherry fig mild hop front.  Mildly creamy rich roasted fruit toffee cherry malty smooth mellow sweet rich BOCK body.  Dry mild hop hot EtOH end.  Sampled 1/8/2011.  Purchased for $2.47 at Fred Meyer--Ballard, Seattle 12/28/2010.

This is a very interesting beer, with a bitter-raisin flavor with overtones of a sherry-like acidity. It smells wonderful, promising a flavor of great intrigue and complexity. It is deep burgundy in color, and pours with a short, quick head. It has a fine carbonation that lingers both on the tongue and in the glass. A most interesting brew.
Bottle. Ruby brown pour with some tan head. Had this beer when I started getting into craft/imported beer. Some nutty, caramel, toffee malt notes and some lager flavors as well.

Draft, West Seattle Prost. Dark red brown pour with a short, but dense, light beige head.  This is a great classic doppelbock.  Flavor and aroma are loaded with rich dough, toast, and caramel notes with light raisin and nuttiness.  Doesn’t taste hot at all, and is quite balanced and drinkable despite the intensity and complexity of it.

Had to go all the way to Tokyo to get this beer... Dark red-brown colored with vanishing yellow head. Nuts dominate this aroma with some roastiness and sweet chocolate. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is even more roasted with same dry nuts, alcohol comes up nicely. Nuts still in malty aftertaste.
The 1st time I had this was at the Schmankerl Stube.Genuine Bavarian restaurant in MD and fell in love with it.

Bottle pour, dark caramel color, pillowy head that drops down to a light tan head.  Smells of fruits and raisins with a light coffee lingering smell.  Taste and palate are very nice with a thin to medium mouth feel with a taste of  fruits, sweet brown sugar and cherry.  Good brew.  Sweet for it’s type but nice and satisfying.

Pours almost black with an almost tan head. Smells of bitter chocolate and caramel. This is a great beer, tastes of caramel and dark chocolate. Slightly dry finish. Leaves great lacing effect on glass. Very drinkable and delicious. Best beer of the night.
Roasted malts, cinnamon, and brown sugar stand out in the aroma.  Palate is a little lighter than expected.  A bit sweet in the finish making this a good doppelbock.  No celabrator, but impressive.

12oz bottle.  Pours a deep dark copper with a light tan head that dissipates to a sticky lace.  Smell has hints of caramel with sweet and toasted malt.  Taste is dominated by caramel malt with nuttiness, chocolate, and alcoholic. Leafy hoppiness comes throgh in the finish.  Was thinner in body than I expected, but it was highly drinkable.
Around $8 / sixer  - I love the malty optimator.  Sweet throughout, but not overpowering.  This is one "malt beverage" that deserves a look.

From a 16.9 oz. bottle.  Pours dark brown with reddish hue.  Nice, big, creamy head that lasts and leaves lacing. Aroma is of biscuit, roasted malt, toffee, and port.  Flavor is molasses, some cherry, and somewhat earthy, a decent enough amount of bitterness to balance the sweetness.  A nice warm, satisfying finish.  An impressive Doppelbock.
Pronbably an excellent representation of the style but the finish was much sweeter than expected
A dark beer  that’s real smooth. Aroma is like coffee. This is what Guinness would taste like if it was any good.

Bottle pour, tan, pillowy head dissipates fairly quick. Nice, clear, deep brown appearace. Smells of fruits, wine and dark sugary malts. Tastes of sweet brown sugars, caramels, plums, slight hops bitterness on the finish. A bit slick and oily on the tongue. A good brew, just a bit too sweet and winey for my tastes.

1pt 9 floz. Pours an oily black with no head. Smells like plumbs and general fruitiness, almost like a wine. The taste and palate are also almost like a wine with a slight acidity that sticks to your cheeks. Very fruity, very smooth. A fine selection

(12oz bottle) Pours medium brown clear with a light tan head. Nose of burnt caramel, toasted malt and raisins. Taste of burnt sugar, very dark fruits, molasses, and other very roasted sugars. Slightly thin mouthfeel. The bartender asked me if I wanted a lime with this beer. Politely told him no thanks!

Dark brown pout with garnet tints and a thin off white head that dissipates pretty quickly. The aroma is biscuity caramel, dark fruit, toffee,molasses, peat, and brown sugar. The flavor hold more roasted character than the aroma might suggest, and complements the dark fruit/ dark sugar arrangement. Lots of caramel, toffee, raisin, plum, and some chocolate. The palate is medium to full with a velvety caressing mouthfeel and a clean, semi-roast like finish. Yummy for sure.

Dark brown pour with red tints, small white head. Aroma holds caramel, brown sugar, plum, pear, apple, and biscuit- really dig this brew on the nose. Flavor is great; lots of bread, biscuit, roasted malt, and some more dark fruit. Some of the sweetness is shifted into the roast flavor, but the caramel and plum notes are still present and welcome. Palate is medium bodied, with a nice sweetness. Really nice doppelbock.
Waaaay better on draft than in the bottle.  Super malty flavor with a nice mouth feel.  Makes an excellent ingredient to a pot of Texas chili.
On tap at Gingerman Fort Worth.  Nice dark color with a light head. I can taste more of it on the back of the tongue. Nice and dark without too much bitterness.
Finally, a good beer tonight.  Brown with an off white head.  Malty and toasty flavors with a decent bitter finish that left me thirsty for more.

Strong malty aroma. Prune, caramel, skunky. Dark dark brown color, mild hint of red/orange. Nice thick white head, forms quickly then disapates. Strong malty flavor. Prune, burnt caramel, green bottle skunk/bitterness. Medium full body, lingers.
Unique and striking beer. Can take a bit of getting used to. Comes in brown and green bottles. The browns are cloying... the green just right.
Dark brown pour, thin tan head.  Aroma of herbs, bread, and malts.  The taste is initially a thick, roasty flavor, and subsides to a mildly hoppy finish.

Bottle. This is a beer I passed up on for so long and finally bought. Pours a hazy deep reddish amber body with a small khaki head. Aroma is cherry, raisins, nuts, caramel with vegetable background. Pretty good fruity, sweet malty flavor, on the verge of being too much. Full bodied, warming malty finish. Overall good beer that could sneak up you.

Sample poured from a bottle at Cincy Beerfest.  Pours a somewhat cloudy brown-orange color with a small, creamy beige head.  Aroma of caramel malts, nuts, sugar, cream, and roast.  Flavor is also sweet and nutty, with notes of hops, brown sugar, and toast.  Medium bodied, with gentle carbonation and none of the skunk/funk that shows up in other Spaten beers.  Sweet and malty.  Not bad but this isn’t my kind of thing.

nice aroma of honey n toffee , pours a deep amber with a decent off white head , tastes malty and rich and sweet without being cloying with a beautiful balance lightly chocolatey . this is one smooth and nutty beer with great drinkability .

Poured a dark ruby brown with an off white head that left no lacing. Aromas of roasted malt, caramel and chocolate. Very good flavors of roasted nuts, dark fruit and caramel. Creamy palate that finished slightly sweet. A solid beer from Spaten.

12 oz bottle. Aroma of a wet field of grain (I used to set sprinkler pipe in such fields when I was 12 or 13--that’s what this beer smells like). Pours brownish red with a medium head, great lacing. Diminishes too fast. Raisins come out in the flavor. Somewhat sour. Medium carbonation. Finishes grainy, sour. Despite my relatively high scores for every aspect of this beer, I can’t in good conscience give it any higher than a 13 for my overall impression. I just can’t see myself ever buying this (this bottle was given to me as a gift). It’s just not that good. Well-made, obviously, but just not my cup of tea. It seems like when I had it on tap at my local Oktoberfest celebration it was much better, though.

12 oz. bottle- Pours dark brown with little head and good lacing, aroma isn’t the best but not horrible. The flavor is smooth chocolate malt kind of like a porter only lighter, its very good and drinkable.

This beer pours a dark black with a thick white head. It has a malty, yet not very sweet, and yeasty aroma. The aroma of yeast was particularly pungent in my nose after I accidentally put my nose too close to the glass and drank some of the beer through my nose. The taste is of fairly standard roasted, slightly burnt, malt with some slight coffee overtones. Not a bad beer, but very typical and a little uninteresting.

Tan creamy head dark brown with ruby hue pour ... aroma of bready malt and sweet caramel malts ..... taste of caramel malts bready/alcohol taste and a roasted malt ..... definitely a bock with some balls to it a tasty brew fills you up but is a sessionable beer ..... not bad for a macro

500ml from Goody Goody.  Deep, dark brown body with a quickly dissipating tan head.  Caramel, toffee, plum and chocolate malt aromas.  Flavors of chocolate malt, plums, figs and caramel all combining for a rich, light to medium sweetness. Medium carbonation along with a light to medium body.  Short caramel/toffee and bittersweet (?) chocolate finish.  ABV is well hidden and results in a deceptively easy to drink doppel.

I am not a fan of Spaten; most of their beers are mediocre and I am standing by my opinion as such. The only beer of theirs I have supped so far that was respectable was their Premium Lager. Up to bat today is their Optimator, a German Doppelbock which I hope will also be respectable seeing as I enjoy doppelbocks in general.




He poured a deep dark mix of burgundies, browns, and mahogany while a thin khaki head quickly retreats into oblivion; a thin collar is all that remains.  Lifting the glass to my nose, a thick and syrupy assault of molasses and maple syrup weighs upon my senses. This isn’t the finest of the finest; this is the artificially saturated syrup which comes in gallon jugs at a sleek price to appease all the non-discerning general public. Floating in that tub of sickenly thick and artificially sweet maple and molasses are raisins, prunes, cinnamon sticks, and sliced apples. At the back of his nose is a painful hit of alcohol heat. Already I feel my rather limited respect for Spaten in general and their Optimator specifically quickly spiraling into the usual pit of disappointment. My first quaff is sweet and surprisingly a touch dry, a fact his nose certainly didn’t reveal. Dry cinnamon powder and brown sugar ground super-fine are most evident atop my tongue while his body is thick and heavy with artificially sweetened molasses and maple syrup. The further I quaff, a growing sense of staleness works its fingers into his palate much like a poison slowly spreading through the body of its victim. Stale breads such as rye and pumpernickel unfortunately linger in the background, growing ever more apparent as the maple and molasses also starts to go sour. It could also be that the sweetness is just so overwhelming, so heavy, so thick, and so dominating that I can only handle so much before my body starts to reject what I am apparently trying to torture it with. I’ve tasted enough and I would rather the Spaten Optimator not come back later to haunt me. There are no fond farewells here, just an immediate exit strategy expertly executed.




What can I say but yet another disappointment from a brewery which I have very low expectations for anyway. If you come across any Spaten other than the lager, avoid it like the plague. No more need be said.
(i would like to add an add that Spaten comes in green bottles so there is always that question of freshness...)

Poured a dark brown with a small white brown head.
Aroma is all roasted malts.
Big caramel malt flavors up front, a touch of chocolate and with a slight hop bitterness on the finish.
Medium bodied and fairly drinkable ( don’t notice much of the 7.2%). Overall a pretty decent dobbelbock.

Bought because of the rave reviews it gets on RateBeer - Not a big fan of German beers in green bottles. Regardless, reddish amber color, small beige head, aroma of malt (a little too sweet for my liking) and needs more hops. Probably won’t buy again.

§lct-mhgy, med-body, med-co2.



dark-malt fruit-cake earthy aroma.



T1 dark-malts minerality. 

T2 dark-roasted-malt §earthy-hop.

T3 §coke §sambuca §earthy-hop iron/mnrls/tannins.

fairly drinkable and simple but too minerally to me.

Pours deep amber brown with fading tan head.  Deep malty aroma with spice and alcohol.  Flavor is toasted/roasted malt, baked bread, and light spice.  Alcohol warmth.  Crisp with medium to full body and slightly bitter aftertaste.

Bottle - What a classic. Pours deep brown with a tinge of red and a small cream head. Smells of sweet caramel malt with a bit of sourness and nuttiness. There’s just a bit of hops below the surface for balance. You’ve got to let it warm up a bit, but the taste is smooth and sweet, with a caramel burst of maltiness that transitions into some nice balancing hops. That bitterness stops it from being cloying or too syrupy. It’s just easy to drink which still keepign that sweetness. Feels great in the mouth -- smooth, thick, and a bit syrupy. It’s easy to forget how good this is.

i love this beer.  its an amazing yet easy drinking and tasty beer, especially with its alcohol content.  Dark in color, thick off white head.  The flavor lasts too.  It has tons of malt, toffee, a touch of chocolate and a good alcy kick.  not too  much carbonation. finishes slow.
"Delicious" sums up this beer. Toffee apple nose. Rich palate, with flavours ranging from chocolate, toffee, raisins, stone fruit, and medicinal notes. Very moreish.

Clear, mahogany color.  Spare but persistent head.  Coffee and toffee notes from the malt dominate with a hint of dried fruit coming through.  Not overly sweet.  Subtle hop contribution.  Pleasant finish and hint of alcohol with each sip.  I am always impressed when I taste a German beer that observes the Reinheitsgebot:  that brewers can coax such a complex of flavors from four basic ingredients, sans additives.

50cl draught stein with lid in Munchen.
Decided against going out of my way to have a Celebrator, sampled this instead, and certainly wasn’t disappointed.
Deep amber body, thick dense beige foam that hangs around.
Rich aroma; lots of toffeeish malt, chocolate and nuts, undertones of prune and fig with a hint of booziness.
Moderate carbonation, thick texture with a somewhat chewy texture.
Delicious chocolate and caramel maltiness that holds complex undertones of dried fig and plum, raisin, sherry and subtle alcohol perfume. Beautiful lingering finish, low bitterness.
Fantastic dark strong lager!

Pours very dark brown with a thin light tan head. Aroma is toffee, biscuit and roasted malt. Rich thick sweet flavor with roast malt and caramel and also some raisin. Medium body with creamy carbonation. Green bottle does seem to affect the taste.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a clear, dark, amber-brown color with a creamy off-white  average head that dissipates fairly quickly and leaves excellent lacing.  Aroma is a rich malty caramel sweetness. Flavor is caramel, molasses, and some dark fruit. Medium bodied. Slightly warming finish.
This is the first beer I have tried since first finding this website, it is very good if I can say.

Dark brownish red pour with a beige head that doesn’t last as long as you’d like. Nose of sweet caramel, bakery, cookie dough, and malt. Thick syrupy mouth feel. Roasted grains with a bit of hops on the palate. More hops than most bocks. Some nuttyness, but could use some more, much more. Aftertaste is more bitter than most bocks.
I am a dopplebock fan through and through. its nice and dark, it tastes good cold or warm, and it packs a decent punch. I would suggest it to anyone!
A very good Doppelbock.  Sweet and very smooth caramel flavor dominates the flavor profile.  Full and somewhat creamy mouthfeel, nourishing and quite filling.  Finishes clean with no off flavors.
brown  pour with a small tan head, warming aroma with a big malty sweet taste. mmmmmm!
From the tap poured a dark brown color with a good amount of head.  Nice strong sweet malty flavor with a lasting finish.

This is an interesting malt liquor. Pours thick and golden red. Like drinking caramel syrup... sweet sugary and thick. Ultra smooth body, creamy with some burnt aftertastes. A good beer, though I’m not used to the style I guess.

Pour a dark red brown with a quickly fading tan head.  aroma is of roasted malts, baked bread, and carmel.  falvor is of roasted grains, baked bread, caremel. dark fruit toffee, and a little chocolate.  has a medium-full body and a creamy mouthfeel.  overal, a very good dobblebock.
Pours dark reddish brown color with light tan head. Toasted malt, caramel, and dark fruit aromas. Flavor is sweet and malty caramel. Medium body with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.

pours out clear brown and semi thick with an offwhite bubbly head that fell really fast.  the body is dark maroon ruby with very litlle bubbles rising from the bottom of the glass with no lacing at all.  the aromas are that of caramel and butter scotch with a nice roasty scent to it.  the flavours are definate roasted caramel and toffee. the mouthfeel is medium bodied with very moderate sutel carbonation with no aftertaste and soft on the palate. nice winter beer to drink on a cold day.
Pours a deep dark brown color with reddish hues.  Aroma of toasted grain and malt.  Flavor is of roasted grain/malt with a hint of sweet chocolate.  Has an almost creamy texture.  Quite good.

12oz bottle.  Deep amber-brown color, looks filtered still.  Sweet and malty, with some pungent and rich yeast tones.  There is some medium bodied lightness to this one that isn’t typical of Doppelbocks.  Sweet and roasty caramel and chocolate notes with a malty Lagery finish.  Simple and understated, this is a nice beer, but hardly a prime example of the style.
Pours a very dark amber with a thin creamy head. Light & subtle nutty aroma. Sweet carmel/coffee taste with little after-taste. Not a bad doppelbock, recommended.
Dark red-brown with a light tan head. Sweet malts and fruity esters. Taste has some alcohol, toasted malts, and some toffee notes. Some dark fruit. Medium-full body.
A good beer, would definitely get it again. Very dark pour with very little head. Nice flavor.

From the bottle, this poured dark brown with deep grape red tones and sticky light-tan suds. It smells of booze,warming into bread pudding minus the vanilla; candied sugar, toasty malts, a little bit of fruit. The flavor is intensely sweet. a touch sour with a bitterness in the finish. The syrupy quality is balanced well with adequate carbonation. Deliciously potent.
Pours dark very brown with a little red and a off white red. Excellent smoky sweet aroma and a similar flavor of roasted nuts and sweet fruit.
I keep trying new Doppelbocks but always seem to come back to this one. Sweet but not too sweet. Nutty and malty as well. Its also really cheap for a beer this good. Scores extra points from me.

Pours dark amber with ruby highlights.  Very clear with a quickly discipating head.  Aroma is distinctly munich malty sweetness.  Body is medium full.  Flavor has a lot of residual malt sweetness but is balanced well with a background bitterness.  A really good dopplebock.

I have had this many times, but it has been probably two years since my last one. Pours a deep porter-like dark brown, small lace, caramel and roast aroma. Flavor is big and mildly sweet. It was 6.99 a 6pack at my Trader Joes and at a respectable 7.2% abv, this is a mighty fine beer to start out my October!

dirty charcoal filtered pour gives to caramel colored yet translucent brew with minimal head and zero lace. aroma is well devloped caramel and caramelized nuts. flavor is of more of the same and a late and light booze mule kick. palate reflects the ABV - silky but only such as 7% can provide. i’d like to see this ferment out to 10%.
Dark brown pour with lots of aroma, especiallly caramel.  The taste is sweet with malt and caramel.  If anything it could use a bit more bittering balance.  Silky presence on the palate.  Enjoyable.
Dark maroon with light tan head.  Aroma of nuts and caramel.  Sweetish caramel taste with toffee and raisins.  Alcohol shows through.  Lots of malt, could use better balance.

Bottle. Medium to dark brown with a large, creamy, off-white head.
Full of aroma: caramel, dark malts, some hops, chocolate, dried fruits.
Sweet and malty. Caramel and chocolate flavors. A touch of alcohol taste, which works to balance a little. Very lightly hopped. Could use a little more to balance it out better. Malt is rich and thick but not very complex. Finish of roasted malt &#40slightly drying&#41, a touch of hops and alcohol, and malt. A decent bock, but too much on the sweet side for me.
Brown color, malty aroma, sweetness is very present in the flavor and maybe a little chocolate, finishes very smooth.
Pours a nice dark borwn with a tan/white head. Aroma of grains and maybe some fruit. Taste is of malted grains, and slightly strong alcohol aftertaste. Good beer, especially for the price.
Brown with medium, lasting head. Fruity aroma and taste. Somewhat bitter especially the finish. Its strong strength is not noticeable. A pretty decent beer.

Pours a very dark brwon almost black with next to no head. Has a caramel or some sort of sweet smell to it. Has a molasses, sweet taste up front with a dark fruit finish. Finish is very close to Chimay Blues finish

&#40bottle&#41. Clear, deep amber/brown color. Medium tan head, which is mostly diminishing. Molasses aroma.  Light molasses and alcohol flavors. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Slick texture. Soft carbonation. Spare lacing.
The epitome of a dopplebock!  This beer is well balanced with a good combination of sweet, malty, and bitter - a must have!  I especially love getting liters of this stuff!

Rich reddish brown. Thin, disappearing head. Aroma of toasted nuts, toffee. A little thin bodied for the style, but with complex roasty flavours with some dark fruits. Easier to drink than the 7.2% abv would lead you to suspect.
A very dark pour, pitch black. Has great roasted aromas and a big malt flavor. Nothing too overpowering and very enjoyable.
Huge malt flavor, caramel, raisins, sweet, dark fruit. Palate is a little thick, probably the alcohol, very light carbonation. Fantastically rich and a good example of the style.  Yum.

Looks amazing in the glass, thick creamy head.  Aroma of cooking malt.  Dry and crisp yet oddly thick for that.  Labeled as malt liquor (presumably for legal abv. reasons) but this is some awesome malt liquor.

Pours clear dark chestnut, with a medium tan head, and fine lasting lacing.  Sweet aromas of toffee and banana bread, with some earthy hops.  Medium body, velvety, rich, and crisp.  Flavors of toast, dark fruit, a hint of chocolate, with an earthy and citrus finish.
Bitter, but toasty taste, definitely not what I expected when looking at the beer in the bottle.  Medium body, minimal head when poured.  Aromatic.
Pours dark brown with an average sized light brown head.  Nose is malt and caramel.  Taste is malt, bread, caramel, and toffee.  A nice beer, very satisfying.
The steady go to beer. Bad day at work, have the optimator!.Great taste and great price and available everywhere.
Sampled at the 8th Annual Music City Brewer’s Festival.  Red-brown with a light tan head.  Aroma is grassy, caramel, metallic and thinned by the alcohol.  The taste is caramel, malts, grassy hops.

On tap, Bavarian Grill, Plano.  Impressive sized mug arrived at the table dark amber-black, average off-white head.  The food had arrived by this point so I couldn’t make out too much of the aroma, some light caramel/toasted malt/biscuit.  On the tongue, very alcohol-forward, but the strong, balanced roasty-toasty flavors came through as well.  You don’t have to be a huge dopplebock fan to like this beer, as it is rich & thick yet has a moderate sweetness & soft carbonation that make it very approachable.  And it goes without saying, supremely excellent with German food!
Bottle.  Pours an amber body with a tan head.  Sweet and nutty with hints of caramel, dried fruit, lager notes, toffee and a full body.  Nice session lager.
2009 Bottle - Pours dk ruddy amber with a small white head...aroma is light fruity malt, a bit nutty and bready...flavour is similar, toffee malt, roast and some booziness, lightly spicy...tasty
Pours dark brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is of sweet malt.  Flavor is very malty with some spice.  Not bad at all.  Good lace and great beer for the style.

Pours a deep amber-brown with tan head that laces surprisingly. Aromas of sweet roasty malt - nothing too special. First sip was a bit of a shocker. Very sweet candy caramel with roasted malt with a cleansing hop finish. light body medium at best. The third and fourth sips were kinda a let down. probably the best main stream affordable doppel out there. Might let it warm next time I dunno still well overrated in my opinion.

Presentation: It was poured from green 12oz bottle into a smooth mug. There appears to be no freshness date and the label reads "malt liquor".

Appearance: The body has a deep brownish mahogany color with a dark reddish amber hue and good clarity. On top there is an average size (about 1 finger thick) light tan head. It is slow fading and leaves behind good lacing on the glass.

Smell: The aroma has a sweet almost fruity nose with some dark grin notes and a slight hint of a mild sweet alcohol.

Taste/Mouth Feel: The flavor has a big sweet malty character and full body with notes of caramel roasted grain and toffee. Hop bitterness is very light and really only comes out a little bit in the finish. There is also the slight presence of a mellow alcohol that adds a little more complexity to the overall character. The palate has a slick full mouth feel with soft carbonation.

Notes: This was a very enjoyable doppelbock. Also this is the only Euro imported beer I have seen that is 12oz and not 11.2oz.

bottle.  Pours a clear brown with a thin tan head.  Nose is of caramel, toasted malt and bread.  Taste is caramel malt and biscuit with some spice.  Mouthfeel is sweet and some alcohol.  This was one of my crossover beers into craft brews.  Have a personal fondness to it even though it doesn’t taste as good for me as it used to.

I really like Spaten’s "double shovel" logo, as it takes me back to the summer of ’71 in Munich.  Ah yes, getting loaded at the Hofbrau Haus and then pissing in the streets on the way back to the youth hostel.  What’s better than a drunken teenager?  Oh, sorry.  Back to this beer.  It poured VERY dark, to become probably the darkest German beer I’ve yet had.  So dark that it was nearly impervious to the light along with a foamy tan head of perhaps two fingers thickness.  The aroma was of malts with I think some floral notes and spices as well.  The taste was quite malty with a nice combination of sweet and spice; mouthfeel was maybe a but thinner than I’d like but this is almost carping to say that.  Aftertaste was as sweet as I’d want, anything more would’ve detracted from this beer.  Really really nice.

bottle, pours dark brown, medium light tan head.  Sweet carmel and a doughy malt aroma.  Sweet lightly toasted malt, some carmel notes and a light spiced finish that lingers.  Moderate carbonation and a medium to heavy mouth feel.  A solid doppelbock.

Bottle; can’t believe I haven’t rated this one.  Poured a dark, dirty brown with some amber notes.  Aroma of sweet malt, wheat, caramel, and brown sugar.  Not bursting with aroma.  Flavor was pretty minerally, perhaps too much so initially.  But that goes away.  Caramel and brown sugar notes are very strong.  Some vanilla and brea.
Very dark pour with white head. Can really smell and taste the malt. Has sort of a chocolate after taste.

Very nice deep clear dark amber brown colour with a suitably off white creamy head. Smell of molasses, cola, and wheat. Taste is smooth and creamy with some slight caramel, rye, burnt sugar, cherry, vanilla, even some coconut notes. The alcohol is practically invisible amongst the flavour. Overall, a good, drinkable Doppelbock; but one that suffers partially from being kind of unexciting.

nice dark brown pour, slight head.  really potent aromas of sticky malt and raisin.  creamy mouthfeel and nice traditional malt roast.  A little bit of chocolate and dark fruit in the aftertaste.  Really quite good
Sort of a dark scotch ale aroma? Not much head to speak of. Malty and roasty. Some alcohol burn. Strong, sweet. Reminds me a lot of Old Chub.

Pours rather dark brown with a bit of a matching head.  Nose is sweet with hints of dark fruits (plums, raisins, etc.).  Flavor is very creamy and smooth with the same dark fruits from the nose.  I believe I also detected some floral notes at the end, or at least something similar to what I usually identify as floral.  An excellent beer, to be sure.

12 oz bottle.  One of the darkest doppelbocks I’ve seen, pouring a deep red and brown; if it were a shade darker, it would have been a stout.  Aroma and flavor are of dark fruits and malts with a slight spice at the end.  Overall, I was very impressed with this.  Definitely one of the better doppelbocks out there.

~Pours a dark brownish amber with big fluffy light brown head. Clear clarity.
~Big ready toasty caramel on the nose as well as some dark fruits such as raisin.
~Sweet bready biscuit malt flavor with prune, dark chocolate and raisin.
~Creamy medium feel with carbonation. Sweet bready finish. 
~A very enjoyable doppelbock. Doesn’t seem as cloyingly sweet as others. Very drinkable

bottle from midway mart in denton, tx.  poured a brown/rubywith a biege head.  aroma of caramel, raisins, grains, italian sausage,  maybe some brown sugar, and some spice which i want to say ginger root, but can be way off.  flavor was caramel, roasted malt, dark fruit, some spice, and a hint of liqourice.  pretty full bodied with high carbonation.
Pours a dark amber with off white head. Aroma of roasted malt, bread  Taste is very malty and smooth. Solid Doppelbock
Not sure how this one got in the fridge. Nice clear brown color. Loved the malt and roasted grain that come through on an earthy platter.

Pour from 12oz bottle. Deep amber/brown color, thin off white head. Aroma of roasted malt and caramel.  Delicious malty flavor with caramel and roasted grain overtones. Not an undifferentiated sugary blast of malt syrup, but rather a refined,  well balanced, yet heavy malt flavor. A classic indeed.

Get rid of the green bottles! This is a solid offering from Spaten that probably loses a step or two on it’s way to me in OKC. Not as sweet as most Doppels, and a tad acidic. But complex and good overall.
Dark brown pour with a small off white head. Aroma mostly of caramel with a similar flavor. Lots of caramel and malts however not overly sweet.

12oz bottle. Clear and dark with minimal head. Heavy on the malts from nose to flavor. Nice roasted flavors. Smooth texture on the palate due in large part to 7.2% EtOH content. Great balance overall.

Bottle.  Pours a clear dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of pizza dough and roasted lager malts.  Flavor is nice and doughy with some sweetness in the finish.  A touch vegetal.  Nice and pleasant to drink.
7/4/7/3/13 (3.4/5)
Great beer rich malt flavor dark and full bodied really nice texture rich and thick chocolate tones and nutty biscuity roastyness.

Cool name and bottle.  33cl pours a sizzly carbonation that lays fairly flat, tan over rich gemlike brown coat. Aroma typical rich subtle doppel plus some wet wood and delicate earthy mushroom. Superficially the taste and not so much the aroma resembles Weltenburger, hitting similar notes of hay, honeyed malts, but rather than WBK’s country barnyard it has a hint of pan-steamed wild mushroom. Fantastic stylish beer. It sizzles my tongue and palate just a little bit, and the malt almost threatens to be a bit treacly but then it  kicks the right amount and ’shape’ of hops at me to keep the dynamic interplay of this beer so fascinating.

Bottle.  Poured a brown, with a beige head.  Aroma of sweet, bready malts.  Taste is also very malt forward, with some toffee and other light roast notes.  Mouth is smooth, and the body is medium.  A nice drinkable brew.
12 oz bottle.  Caramel colored in the glass with light head.  Nose is super sweet malty.  Taste is same.  Rich and full.  Nice all around brew.

Bottle pours a dark reddish brown color with a tan head.  Very sweet, roasted malt aroma.  The flavor is quite sweet and malty as well.  Rich mixture of malts and dried fruits, mostly raisin.  Nice lingering aftertaste.
This is a cheap one! Two dollars for a pint. Lots of malts. sweet and bready if thats a word. the doppelbock for all others to be judged!

Deep brown color, sudsy head, lacing, smells like honey covered oats, honey wheat bread, smells very good. The flavor is full on malts, possibly fruity raisins, bready. Overall this is a decent dopple but it smells a lot better than it tastes but who can complain for $2.49?

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-27-2009 00:42:31

Sweet caramel, malty aroma with a whiff of coffee. Clear rust appearance. Medium sweetness and bitterness with a hint of salt. Medium body, thin oily texture, soft carbonation. Long, bitter nutty finish. Simple and tasty.
Bottle at hideaway bar. Incredibly sweet, bold caramel malty taste.  Also tastes pretty strong, even though it’s not.  Pretty good for something that’s really easy to find.

Bottle pours a clear reddish-brown with a large, quickly-thinning, fizzy head.  Very little aroma, sweet taste with a long aftertaste of bittersweet caramel.

Not particularly interesting, but not bad for a simple pure beer.

Dark brown pour with a foamy, cocoa colored head.Light aroma of sweet malts. Flavor is sweet, yet with some coffee and light bitterness. Kind of meh, typically german. I dunno, there are lots of other doppels I’d want before this one.

Pours a very deep brown with a reddish tint to it. A large foamy beige head lasted for quite some time.Smells of malts and coffee but not a lot else. Coffee and roasted malts really stand out on the tongue. Taste is much better than the nose would lead you to believe. Gets better as it warms.
Bottle. Poured an amber color with a decent two finger white head. Aroma was caramel, sweet malts, and other fruits. Flavor was malts, sweetness, yeast, and fruits. Medium body. Good beer.

16.9oz bottle from BevMo!  One of my favorite Doppelbocks of all time.  I think the first time I tried it was at the Yard House.  Nice dried and candied fruit aromas, nice fruity flavor with a slightly sweet finish.

Had off the tap during Beer Week 2009 in south Philadelphia. Nice color and head, though nothing special. Sweet, even taste, without any overpowering flavors. Flavour of alcohol is deceptively missing; much stronger than I taste would indicate, I ended up sleeping on a porch after but three of them.

Glass of the month at Winking Lizard, served in a .5 liter mug.  Clear amber color with a medium beige head.  Sweet caramel malt aroma with a definite lager yeast impression.  Candi sugar flavor with caramel, yeast and hops and nuts in the finish.  Still a solid d-bock.

En fût. Pinte dégustée chez Mr. Dunderbaks (Tampa, FL). Arôme: Odeur de mélasse avec une pointe de céréales. Apparence: La couleur est brune foncée. Présence d’un mince col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel avec une pointe de raisins et de prunes. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Mince effervescence en bouche. Présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #2294)

Bottle.  Pours a great dark amber to brown color, with a thin offwhite head.  there are a lot of good sweet flavors, dried fruits like plum and raisin.  Those are nicely blanaced with some roasted nut flavors and of course the malts.  Alcohol is completely hidden, and the mouthfeel is great, just a little bit of carbonation to keep it alive.  This is a very solid beer.

Bottle. Pours a small brownish-white head, with a dark red/brown body. Notes of raisins, malts, prunes, dark fruits, caramel and yeast. Creamy and pleasantly fizzy mouth. Nice roasted nutty flavor with some raisins and light alcohol bite. Overall, a good beer.

Location: 
Original rating from 2004, on tap at the Capital Ale House



Overall Impression: 
Excellent beer, had it on tap first, but have also drank many times out of the bottle, nice, dark color with an excellent combination of flavors that make it one of my favorite beers. I know I’m overrating this one a bit, but damn its treated me well over the years.
Bottle: Pours a dark amber almost chocolate in color. LIttle not no head or lacing. Tastes like a hops filled pilsner, but with more malts. Pretty good for a german beer.
TAP: medium brown pour, grain and roast on the nose and taste. Medium body, very slightly bitter. Solid german brew.

Pours a medium-dark ruby brown with a creamy four finger beige head that has decent retention. Aroma is sweet grainy malts, caramel, plum, fig, a little raisin, fresh cut hay, floral hops, mild roast and a nice bready backbone. Flavor is caramel, sweet grain, toasted grain, sweet bread crust, a hint of light roast, sweet toffee, lots of brown sugar, dried plum, licorice and weak herbal notes. Finish is dark fruit, toast, roast, brown sugar and floral hops, very low bitterness. Palate is medium thickness, slightly syrupy and has a nice carbonation level. Overall a good Doppelbock, not great.

On tap. Mild aroma of hops and bread. Dark brown with no head. There are flavors of roasted malt, bread, caramel, and alcohol. Full bodied with low carbonation, glides down smooth. This is a great beer, strong and dark but surprisingly an easy drinker.

Multiple bottles consumed from my gigantic Spaten beer mug. Just a consistently good German beer here, nice red brown pour with a fluffy tan head. Very sweet on the palate with a nice mild caramel malt profile and some nice roastiness to it as well. Nice dry finish, very tasty brew.

Bottle.  This beer never disapoints.  Pours a dark reddish brown.  The aroma is of sweet malt and caramel.  Full bodied with roasted malt, toffee, and alcohol notes.  Finish is slightly dry with mild bitterness.
Chocolatey, creamy, smooth and not too hoppy.  A great looking deep red/brown pour.  A very nice, drinkable bock.
Ruby pour with medium head.  Great aroma of chocolate and hint of caramel, slightly bitter taste with the carbonation of alcohol.  Good example of this style.

Dark ruby pour, with little head. Tastes of sweet flavors with hints of chocolate. Slightly tingles over the palate, mainly due to the APV. Not bad. A drinkable doppel.4.0

RE-RATE 2/9/10 Pours dark brown with huge rouge tints. The smell is lovely. Lots of dark fruit, alcohol and rich malts. Flavor is all red grape upfront. Rich malts fill in next with a touch of bitterness. Finish is just the right mix of bitter malts, dark fruits and sweetness. Better than remembered.

Bottle at Concordia Ale House, Portland, OR.  Dark brown (although bad lighting), thin beige head. Notes of nuts, bread, dark fruit, thick malts, rust.  Flavorful and roasty, fairly sweet.  Were it not carbonated it could be mistaken for chilled wort.  But it is nicely balanced, and my opinion is strongly positive.

12oz. bottle from Trinity Liquors in Spring Hill, FL. Pours a clear dark red-brown with a small tan head. Aroma is malty, mollasses, maybe some raisins..The smell is interesting and really hard to put my finger on. Flavor is more mollasses, maybe some raw honey, raisins...again, weird, cant really figure it all out. Lighter mouthfeel, no aftertaste. This one is really odd...but pretty good and very drinkable.
Bottle. Poured a dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of malt and carmel. tastes of roasted malt and carmel. Smooth on the palate with a sweet finish.

The quest continues for cheap strong beer from Europe.  Smell is sweet malt, a bit nutty, with a suggestion of slight tartness, like decaying fruit, and a bit of cola.  Taste is clean, toasty, nutty, slightly sweet, with some fresh bread and caramel.  Light medium body, a bit of bitterness in the aftertaste.  Dopplebocks are usually quite handsome with their deep red brown color, and this one fits the type.  Not much head though, and what there was faded quickly.  Lacks richness and depth of flavor, particularly in the finish.  Not bad flavors, but they seem a bit thin.
Nice dark brown with reasonable head. Malty flavor with a touch of sweetness.

Very good dopplebock, and at a decent price. This is not the best dopplebock out there, IMHO, but there is nothing about this beer I do not like. It’s a big mouthfull of malty goodness with just enough hop to balance it out. The color and aroma is fantastic.
I love this beer.  Its full of flavor and body.  It does come a bit heavy after a couple glasses, but the taste really doesn’t fade.
Bottle. Great malty, spicy, well balanced by sweet and robust carbonation. nice doppel example, terrific standard.

Transparent chestnut brown with a medium beige crown.  From a green bottle, so I was expecting a skunky aroma, but luckily was spared this time.  Aroma of caramel, molasses, mild alcohol and dark fruits.  Taste of caramel, light sugar, toasted malts and light alcohol.  Kind of a bland aftertaste and compared to other dopplebocks this one is a few rungs below.
Pours brown with ruby tinges. Aroma is malty. Sweet roasy malt with a slight bitterness in the finish.
On tap.  Poured dark, chestnut brown with a good tan head.  Malty nose with fruity hints.  Full bodied with good mouthfeel.  Malty, alcohol flavors, slightly bitter.  Overall, a good doppelbock.

On tap at Hessen Haus in Des Moines. The beer is particularly a staple at this joint and I used to drank it more than I do now. It does drank pretty good. Pours a deep brownish black. Plenty of molasses and sweet roasted malt in the aroma. Flavor is very sweet in a decidedly good way notes of licorice, sweet malt and coffee. Terribly enjoyable.

Slight tan head over chestnut brown body. Nose was slight orange peel and grapefruit, some malt sweetness. Taste was of raisins with a very soft malt beginning, followed by a building roast quality, and then a bitter hop finish. Very soft and well balanced. Medium fill, soft fizzy palate.
500ml bottle.  Pretty nice doppelbock.  Dark brown color with an off-white head.  Aroma is lots of sweet caramel malt.  Flavor is sweet malt, brown sugar, and alcohol.  Nice fairly full palate.

Poured from a 500ml bottle.  Wonderful sweet, caramel aroma.   Tan head dissipated pretty rapidly.  Amazingly smooth and complex mouth feel and taste.  Vanilla finish is accented with food.  I can’t find anything wrong about this beer.

Pours dark brown with a small head. Aromas of toasted malts and big time caramel. Taste was, again, hard on the caramel with some nice malts and a little alcohol coming through.  Nothing spectacular coming through, but extremely solid nonetheless.

Bottle.  Pours a deep dark mahoagony with a small light tan head that leaves decent lacing.  The nose is dark fruits and caramel malts.  Taste is prunes,  molasses, caramel and burnt brown sugar with light hops in the finish.   Medium, semi-creamy mouth feel.  A touch sweet for me but this is a well put together beer.

Draft in Epcot at Disney  Pours dark bown with tan head.  Has good aromas of malts and carmel.  Has a sweet taste but is balanced nicely with ligThis was a good find.ht hops.  Good carbination and an alright aftertaste.
Big bubbles, a head that disappears quickly.  Taste is slightly complex malts, caramel, toast...but I thought it would be better.

(11/15/08) Bottle at friends’ house in Philadelphia. Dark brown color with a big stable beige head. Big malty aroma with caramel and toasted dark bread. Sweet malty flavor with caramelly sugariness, some dark bread notes and light fruity hints. Medium-bodied. Pretty good.
500ml Bottle; Yum.  Pours very dark.  roasted malt flavor is prominent.  Great beer with full flavor.  reminds me of a spiced Belgian dubbel.
Kinda light for a doppelbock. Which is a good thing. Tan foam,  caramel malts. Nice carbonation as well. Would like to try this again.
Great caramel flavor combined with heavy malt, perfect bitterness, well-balanced and heavy, finishes sweet and dry.

Dark Brown, with 3 finger head. at first i thought this to be too syrupy sweet. but after i let it sit and warm up just a bit, it seems to have really mellowed out a bit, and seems more balanced. although still a tad sweet, its not overpowering, nice bitter hops comes through in the end and helps balance out. I would get this again, and would like to sample it on tap.
Light caramel aroma with a light brown head. A heavy roasted and caramel flavor. Little bitterness, and a heavy mouth feel.

They ain’t lying about the roasted malt flavor. Pours a dark amber cherry cola color with white head. Bubbles rise continually, helping this beer to taste fresh. The smell of roasted cigar like scents fills your nose, and a roasty malty, lite flavor follows. goes well with pot roast. Not too complex, just good old fashioned roasted barley taste. A focused brew.

Pours a clear dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is very malty, strong on the raisins, malt syrup, and nuts.  Yeast and chocolate become apparent while sipping through the head.  When it gets down to actually drinking the beer, the malt syrup and raisin elements are up front, becoming more roasted in the finish.  Decidedly hot, boozy mouthfeel, dry on the tail, somewhat thin-bodied.

330 mL. Pours a clear deep orangish brown with almost no head and little carbonation. Aromas of cider vinegar, caramel, dates, milk chocolate. Taste is watery up front with sweet raisins, dates, brown sugar, and heavy malt. Coats the mouth and leaves a cardboard-like dry taste. Overall probably one of the worst dobbelbocks I have tried. Not much here.

Pours very dark slightly orange amber with little head on an aggressive pour.  The aroma is of malts and yeast.  The flavor is decent, mostly malty and grainy.  The mouthfeel is moderate and slightly creamy.  This is decent beer.

Bottle at Flavor of India.  Good color, like raisin and date juice.  Smells of the same with chocolate.  Flavors add roast and smoke to the mix.  I wish it were a fuller effect - a noticeably thin beer.
On  tap. Black big head. Nose of chocolates and yeast. Taste of chocolates, malts, sweetness. Palate is full and lingering. Served a bit too cold. Overall very easy to drink and refreshing.

Pours a nice dark mahogany into the glass, with an initial creamy tan head that diminishes to nothing.  Nice chocolate, maple syrup and light molasses to the nose.  The flavors are much the same, entering some dark esters and rich malt, with light roasts to close the finish.  The mouthfeel is round and somewhat deep, hampered by carbonation levels that are a bit livelier than expected... not necessarily bad, just not expected.  A very good offering from Spaten, and a very nice Doppelbock.  Not quite on the Ayinger Celebrator level, but one of my favorite "go to" brews.

The aroma starts when opening, which is a great chocolate, molasses, and hops smell. The color is a nice and deep red with a small off white head. The flavor is just like all doppelbocks with a strong start and finish. It is a  creamy chocolate, syrup, hop flavor with a little hint of liquorish and nutmeg. This is one of my favorites.
I buy a pint every time I get a mix and match six pack.  Still at its best on draught, supremely drinkable.
nice taste for a Doppelbock which is not a favorite style for me.  Heavy malty full and rich in flavor.

12 oz bottle. Poured a good looking clear red brown with a huge frothy light beige head. Aroma of vinegar, dark fruit, nuts and malts. Thinner body with strong carbonation. Flavor was nothing spectacular and was rather bland with some skunky notes over stale malts. Im still shocked that I found a ber at the parents house that I could actually rate.

1 pt. 9 oz. bottle.  This has become a favorite of mine--buy a bottle whenever I buy a 6- or 12-pack of something else.  High in alcohol content and it sometimes seeps through the big bold chewy flavors of the rich malt.  My favorite German Doppelbock-sorry, but Celebrator is too sweet for me.

Pours a very dark brown-amber, with a quickly diminishing head.  No lacing.  Aroma is of pit fruits and chocolate.  Heavy malt profile, slightly sweet raisin, a bit of yeast, and some slight alcohol.  Palate is a bit thin, but probably consistent with the style.  Overall a very drinkable Doppelbock.

Dark cherry color, compact vanilla white head. 

Aromas of rich milk chocolate, honey, cream, and carmel.  Doughy malt character, floral freshness.  Some molasses, nuts, and raisin.

Flavor is mild toasted malt, some fruit and nuts, and has enough hops to put it not to far on the sweet side.  Molasses, coffee, raisin. 

Palate is very smooth textured, and has little carb, which I appreciate.

Pours a deep mahogany red with a creamy tan head mostly dissapating. Nose is chocolate, molasses and malt. Very creamy on the palate. Malt dominates flavor with subtones of molasses and black cherries. Finish is slightly sweet with a hint of hops. This doppelbock has a full bodied flavor that will stand up to most any meal, including brats, burgers or gyros. A true German original, often imitated, but never duplicated.

Pours a dark red-brown with minimal head.  Sweet caramel aroma, can really smell the malt.  Flavors are mostly roasted malt, but I tasted nut, coffee, and chocolate.  Almost like a laid-back porter.  I found the alcohol to be pretty assertive, but necessarily in a bad way.  Clean on the palate if a bit watery, with a little sourness at the end.  Good balance, an enjoyable beer.

9/24 on draft at DC’s Bar & Grill, Renton, Wa. Aroma bready, super malty, with a slightly sour alcoholic background. Appearance is clear brown with almost no head. Flavor is sweet/sour malt forward with light roast and faint alcohol. Mouthfeel is medium-full bodied with moderate warmth and low roasty bittering. Overall, full flavored and easy drinking for such an alcoholic brew.
bottle. has an aroma of lemon and wheat. pours a golden brown with a thin tan head. has a sweet flavor of dark chocolate and roasted carmel. very good.

Poured into a seidel. Dark clear umber with a nice thick tan head. Good lacing and retention. Aroma is freshly baked bread with a hint of darker fruits. Tastes like carbonated wheat bread. Accents of nuts and caramel, but really none of the chocolate and roasty notes that I expect from a doppelbock. Not quite deep enough. Mouthfeel is rich and creamy, no complaints there. Decent drinkability but this one seems like a beer to pair with something rather than to drink on its own.

Bought by mistake as D-bock’s are not my favorite style. Pours a dark red color with a minimal off-white head. Very malty and caramel aroma. Drier than I thought it would be and detected a little hops in the finish. It is growing on me.

Poured dark reddish brown with a nice two-finger head that dissipated slowly but left very little lace. Sweet fruit aromas - mostly cherries - dominate the nose, but caramel and malts are also clear. Roasted malt flavors come first on the palate, followed by dark fruit sweetness, offset by the slightest of hops bitterness at the end. Lightly carbonated, medium body, and an aftertaste of lingering fruits. Definitely not a session beer for me, but I enjoyed the complexity.

12 oz.bottle. Pours a whitish head, of minimal duration, with heavy lacing, over a clear dark brown body...nose of molasses and heavy malt, some bready tones....tastes of molasses, sweet malts, minimal hop....heavy, thick, chewy mouthfeel, with medium carbonation. finish is sweet.

Bottle.  Poured a dark brown color with a three finger tan head, into a stem glass.  Aroma of dark fruit and sweet malt.  Flavor was decidedly sweet, with caramel and some fruity notes.  Slight hop bitterness in the finish.  Medium/full body with mild carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.  Good beer.  Definately would drink this again.

Bottle. Pours a darkish brown body with a fair sized cream head. Nice aroma, quite malty with ample dried fruits, dates, etc. Taste is in the same vein with a sweet malt body with caramel and dried fruits. Slight bitterness at the end. Well carbbed with a nice crisp finish.
Had a very nut brown ale sort of taste to it that I was not expecting at all. There were a ton of different flavors and it almost went down like the normal porter usually does.
Pours a redish brown with a small off white foamy head.  Aroma of sweet malts.  Heavy sweet malty flavors initially with  the alcohol a little present in the end.  I prefer the Ayinger Celebrator.
Bottle.  Pours dark brown with little white head. Flavor is malty, caramel, with slight hop bitterness in the finish

Bready malty aroma. Clear dark brown with small white head. Rich malty flavor with some spicy hop notes and graininess. Medium body and medium/full mouthfeel. Finish is somewhat dry and malty with moderate residual bitterness.
Dark brown pour with frothy white head. Sweet malty aroma; sweet taste with roasted caramel malt, nice balanced bitter finish.

Poured a dark amber/brown color with a small off white head. Aroma was very malty, some dark fruits in there and a bit grassy. Flavor was very malty, much like most german dopplebocks, nice caramel roastedness .

Getting my old notebook online. Bottle. Dark redish tint, creamy looking head. Smell: Hint of sweetness, fruitiness. Taste: Fruity bitters, bitters go away a little leading to a bit of chocolaty tones about halfway through. Strong good beer!
For a high alcohol beer it sure has a great taste. This beer is packed with tons of flavour with a sweet taste and smell of raisins.

Not as good as Celebrator but not bad by any means.  Dark brown color with quickly diminishing head.  Extremely well balanced.  This is an extremely dangerous beer at 7.2%.  Very enjoyable with it’s malty and balanced flavor.
Very well-hidden alcohol content; a surprisingly easy drinker for such a strong brew. Lots of malt and a little fruit flavor.

Not my normal beer fair however outstanding flavor that hides the high alcohol well. Be careful with this stuff it will sneak up on you if you have more than one. I did not even realize the high content until I had three of them. Then I went wow. 

I got it on tap at the Berlin Cafe in DC

From bottle. Aroma is malty and bready with a touch of berries. Flavor is more malt and bread, with more of those sugary berries on the initial attack.  Good carbonation and body. Hides its alcohol well. A decent beer.
Dark brownish amber, slightly roasted malts, bready, little brown sugar, little nutty, slight chocolate.

Poured from bottle a brown color with medium sized tan head.  Aroma is of sweet malt and bread.  Flavor is very malty with a brown sugar sweetness, toffee, a little nuttiness, and bread.  Palate start s bit sticky sweet and then mellows out slightly with a very big malty feel and nice carbonation.  Normally I might think this beer is too sweet, but this day it seem to flow just right with the spicy, cheese barbeque food I was having.  It was quite nice.
Wow! This is amazing. The flavor realy blew me away. Just a great full bodied beer if I’m not in the mood for hops....which is very rare.

I’m not a big fan of the style, finding it much too sweet and lacking bitterness, but it is the style.  This beer handles it’s 7% alcohol very well.  It is well balanced with a lingering maltiness that becomes sweet.

On tap at the Germany pavillion in Epcot.  Pours brown with a moderate tan head that lasted through mid-glass.  Pleasant, rich, malty aroma.  The flavor is very rich malt with a bit of brown sugar and caramel.  Light bitterness at the finish.  Nearly full bodied with a well-rounded mouthfeel.  Maybe it was the midday heat in Epcot, but I thoroughly enjoyed this beer and thought it was quite good!
Light brown color, aroma of toffee, grain, and slightly roasty, smooth, a real good doppelbock.
Rich and malty with an overpowering sweetness after the first sip. The roasted malt stands out with a nice hop balance.  Ends with a smooth filling finish.

Bottle. Pours dark and heavy like German tank oil. Generous lingering tan head and lacing. Right from the pour this looks serious and inviting. Aroma has caramel, chocolate, and malt. Feels properly full and heavy on the palate like a doppelbock should. Carbonation is light and pleasant. Flavor starts with some caramel and toffee sweetness which usher in rich roasted malt and chocolate. Light hops lead to some good bitterness on the finish and only a hint of alcohol that belies its higher A.B.V. Well -balanced and complex. This is a very satisfying beer, and the best quality for the money (and availability) that I’ve encountered. A mainstay for sure.
12oz bottle. nice head. lots of sweet roasted malt. slight molasses. Nice Doppelbock especially for the price.

well I had small glass of this today and then just realized I had never rated this.  I have had it many times and I have always liked this one.  Brown pour wtih a fair sized beige head.  Aroma is malty and sugary.  Flavor is caramel, toffee, malts, dried fruit and some yeast.  well done.

Poured medium light brown with a slowly dissipating tan head. Aroma of toffee, grain, and slightly roasty. Most of the aromas come though over to the flavor with an added oats and a slightly noticable alcoholic finish. Bitter finish. Not bad for a new beer at Tops. Overall a pretty decent Doppelbocker.
ON tap at german place.  Dark brow with a creamy tan head.  Wheat grain aroma and taste with a crisp oat taste to the finish.

On tap at the flying saucer in KC.
Pours a thinner looking brown with a off-white head. Hint of alcohol smell with notes of berry candy and light hops. Tastes of sweet caramel malts, toffee, a little bit of roast, and berries. Pretty dry and breadlike with a lighter body. Ends with a tiny hint of bitterness. Overall, a solid doppelbock, but just not up to Ayinger Celebrator quality. I would get it again though.

On tap at Resi’s Bierstube.  I was happy to see this on and so I had to get a couple of these.  Pours a dark black/brown with a beige head that lasts through most of the glass.  Straight forward roasted malts and a touch of sweetness in the aroma. The molasses and roasted flavors are strong in the flavor with an edge of charred burnt malts.  As this gets too warm the malts start tasting somewhat cola like and a little sweet.  But this is otherwise a solid doppelbock that’s so drinkable and I’ll grab whenever I see it.

You can certainly smell the maltiness of this beer from the start. The appearance is similar to Coca Cola, as noted by another user. Pretty smooth for the ABV, with a slightly fruity flavor, hints of apple especially. The palate is slightly lively, pretty pleasant. A nice beer overall, not too dark for the summer, either.

Pours exactly like a Coca-Cola.  Strong malt/molasses taste.  No subtlety whatsoever, it’s pure malt.  I am absolutely unable to detect the strong alcohol presence in the taste but this one hits you like a sledgehammer if you attempt 6 in one sitting.  NOT sessionable at all is what I mean, at least not for me.  A poor substitute for Celebrator or Samuel Adams Double Bock in my book.
I don’t think it’s safe to say that this isn’t an excellent beer.  It’s complex and contains rich flavors with a beautiful amber appearance.  Nice job Spaten.

This is a most excellent beer.  Deep dark brew with a light cream-colored head.  Smells of dark malt, light alcohol nose.  Very complex beer with dark molasses and nutty flavors intertwined with the flavor of alcohol.  Very good beer.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark brown color with an off-white light head.  Aroma of sweet roasted malts.  Very nice balance b/w the bitterness of the roasting and sweetness of malts.  I was very pleasantly surprised.  Medium-bodied with an easy finish.  Good brew.
Dark Brown color.  Molasses Aroma.  Sweet roasted malt flavor.  Molasses Taste and Hop finish.  The best beer I’ve ever had out of a green bottle.
(Bottle).  Clean malt toffee aroma.  Pours cola brown with off white head.   Flavor a pleasing caramel malt, and not too sweet.  Not much of a finish.   Not outstanding, but a nice beer.

12 ounce bottle as part of a 12-pack set called Best Beers of the World, a name that most of the beers have not lived up to. Pours a viscous-looking dark amber color with no head and a swirl of white on the top. Nose is dark fruits like blackberry. Flavors include more dark fruits, subtle caramel hues from the apparent malts, oak, and molasses. Finishes clean and smooth with no trace of the ABV, although the bottle claims it to be 12%. Medium/full body and low carbonation. If this had more hop character, I could almost think it to be a barleywine. Pretty good; paired well with the bacon-wrapped top sirloin I made for dinner.

Deep ruby/brown pour with a medium foamy head that sticks around a while.  Aroma of sweet roasty caramel malt and some sweet fruitiness.  Flavor is the same.  Loads of roasty malt and hints of medium-dark ripe fruit.  A bit of alcohol bite on the finish, but not enough to be distracting.  Pretty damn good!

Bottle.  Pours a deep hazlenut brown in color with a huge offwhite head.  The aroma is a caramely, fruity malt.  THe flavor is much of the same with a small alcohol kick.  This beer has a full body, huge complexity, very sugary feeling, almost cloying.

Pours smooth tantalizingly sexy brown sugar stream into a glass. Smell is dominated by the malt. Taste follows suit. This is a damn tasty doppelbock. The first sip may seem a little on the sticky and sweet side, but follow up your first one with at least 5 or 6 more...just to let the complexities develop. If you’re a fan of the doppelbock, give this one a go. For the price, you can’t go wrong (unless you get ripped off)

500ml into weizen.  Medium malty brown, not much head.  Strong malt aroma.  Sweet like malt balls.  Malty finish.  There’s a lot of malt flavor in this one.  Noticeable alcohol kick to the maltiness.  Like, add it to your milkshake malty.  Did I mention the malt?  It’s ok if you like a lot of malt forwardness, really great if you love it.

7/28/2008:  Optimator pours out in a smooth stream of chesnut brown and has a thin khaki head on the surface that doesn’t last long.  Sweet, heavily caramelized maltiness dominates the aroma and flavor.  The rich maltiness of the flavor has some complexities that include roasted malt, hints of coffee/chocolate, dates, and even a little fig.  The sweetness and strength is balanced by just enough Noble bitterness in the finish.  This beer has a medium to medium-full body that is smooth and just a touch syrupy on the palate.  Overall this is a solid doppelbock.  Like many others I agree that Celebrator is a better one, but Optimator is still a worthy contender and always enjoyable.



12 fl.oz. green pop-top bottle (L07981G) from tish.  Thank you!  Rating #1190 for this beer...
pours a super dark mahogany color with some head. Malty with lots caramel sweetness. and roasty character, it’s no celebrator but its a good doppel

Pours nice mahogany color with small tan head. Nice malty aroma, caramel and toffee notes are predominant, some date and alcohol aromas are also present. Wonderful full bodied malty flavor, great balance of the sweet caramel/toffee and the hint of dark fruit. Certainly a very straightforward malt heavy doppelbock, and not quite in the same league as the Celebrator, but an excellent beer none the less.

Pours a black color with small white head.  A nice beer that is lager-esque in feel but has a strong malt backbone that has coffee notes.  To me this seems like it could almost get away with being called a stout.

pours a very very dark amber/brown color, no lasting head at all. great aroma, caramel, almost a bit fruity. goes down smooth. a bit soft when drinking, overall i definitely enjoy this one. a good fall beer.

I thought I would give a different doppelbock a shot, and I think I like the Celebrator better.  This one has a good malty flavor, but the Celebrator just seems to be a more complete beer.  This is a decent German bier that has the ability to stand on its own, but they seemed to have missed the mark a hair.  If you try this one and like it, you’re bound to love Celebrator.
A fine example of the doppelbock.  Not as good as Celebrator, but very tasty nonetheless.
brown pour with medium head with a good malt aroma accompanied by dark sugars/caramel. Taste more mellow, mostly just malts.
I think this, ayinger’s, and paulaner’s are all similar, and all great.  But I can get this a lot cheaper than the other two.
Pours brown with little head.  Smell of malt.  Taste is kind of nasty with sad aftertaste.  HAd high hopes for this one and was sadly disapointed.

Dark cola brown pour with relatively disappointing off white head.  Should have poured more aggressively, I suppose.  Aroma is like Spaten Munich but amped up... pretty distinctive malt character.  Also brown sugar, caramel, some raisin notes.  Palate and taste not as complex as hoped for, but very nice overall... toffee, malt, brown sugar, caramel... and many more synonyms for sweet.  Seems like a good food beer, but not my fave.

Pours a deep ruby-red with an off-white lasting head and some lacing. Aroma is funky/sweaty sweet munich malt. Tastes lightly toasted, diacetyl, dates, nice finish. Thick body, viscous and moderately carbonated. Well executed, but not terribly exciting.

One of the better Dopplebock’s I have tried, but I am not a huge fan of the style. I had a six pack when I was in Florida and had one every day for dinner for a week. It does assault your palate after a while, but has a rich color and strong taste of bitter malt.

On tap at MJ Barleyhoppers on 6/21/08. Pours a dark mahogany color with a thin white-tan head. Aroma is malt, raisins, brown sugar, and spice. Flavor is sweet, malty, ripe grapes, raisins, and sugar plums with a nutty finish. Medium-bodied mouthfeel with a slightly bitter finish.
I was expecting something great.   Not saying it sucked but didn’t meet expectations that I had hear.  Got a nice on the sweeter side amber flavor.  But doesn’t last on the palate.

2/19/08 notes:  bottle from six pack. Aroma is of faint malts and brown sugar.  Pours a solid brown color, not too thick. Initial flavor is mellow with faint hops and grass, but quickly develops into firm alcohol and sweet brown sugar base.  Goes down dry and easy, one of the best dark session beers I’ve tried. This is my first doppelbock, and it was interesting. I recommend this beer.

16.9 oz. bottle. Pours a deep dark amber with nice fluffy light tan head that left moderate lacing. Aroms of malt, sweet brown sugar and earth.  Flavor is of wheat and malt with notes of anise, caramel, and a little alcohol; and the finish was well balanced with the sweetness passing quickly fallowed by a nice flavorful linger. Medium to light on the palate with dry texture and soft carbonation with warm light alcohol finishing feel. An excellent doppelbock and I’m not that big on them, but I will have this one again. Hopefully on tap, say in Munich.

12oz bottle. Pours a deep mahogany color with a large decent lasting foamy light tan head. Nose is bananna, caramel, brown sugar, some clove. Great smelling and great looking beer. Taste is ok but lacking some of the characteristics of the better doppels like Aventinus or Celebrator. Strong wheat and clove taste with alot of light caramel and toffee notes. A bit of bananna but its barely noticable. This has a very dry finish, not bitter but it seems to have more of a bitterness than most doppels. Very full palate. Very solid doppel.

Pour is dark brown with an aroma of dark fruit, molasses, and alcohol.  Flavor is filled with more dark fruit, roasted malt, and toffee characters.  A slight bit of alcohol in the finish.  Good brew.  May buy again.
Awesome Doppelbock enjoyed on draft at Yard House in Las Vegas, Nevada.  Malt underlying the sweet and yeasty body, finishes slightly alcohol and actually becomes more like a brandy as it warms.
Had this on tap at the yardhouse.  I think this may be one of the only things really worth drinking there.  Hugely raisiny and sweet.  Very worth it.  I wish I had tried this sooner.
Very tasty beer. Reminds me of a Celebrator. Solid colored brew with strong malty aromas. Nice; try it...

Bottle, not sure how long this has sat around, pours a dark ruby with brown at the edges, has an off-white head that quickly disperses to a ring and thin covering, large aroma of dark malts and some bread, hints of chocolate, some dirt earthiness on the nose?
