Some malt sweetness but not overly so, same flavors as found in the aroma, dark malt, bread and some chocolate in there, and there is flavor of plum, some malt sweetness but not in over abundance as I find in some Doppelbocks which I find to be too sweet, this is a dryer doppelbock &#40not as sweet&#41, and I like it, lots of malt flavors seep through, easy to drink, mouth feel is pretty full on the palate, very good Doppelbock and easy to drink,  I did not detect the alcohol at all.

Spaten Optimator pours well, has a lovely head and good aroma. It’s taste is at first very full and satisfying but seems to be missing something as it finishes. It’s better from the keg than the bottle. But I wouldn’t refuse a glass no matter the source.
This beer is rich with roasted malt and licorice flavor. Also, it has good head. A caramel aftertaste lingers. Overall, it is worthwhile.

Aroma is full of molasses and licorice, with some dark malts and caramel.  It’s appearance is very dark, akin to cola.  It’s head was rather absent.  Seems to be somewhat flat.  It’s flavor is full of dark malts, roasty malts, molasses or syrup, some licorice or anise, and some caramel.  It’s a bit of a heavy drink, and seems to be for single use, not long nights of session drinking.
On tap at henk’s, dallas.  Perfect with sausage. Nice dark dopplebock, Flavor of caramel and orange, roasted malts.  Smooth palate.
Solid colored dark brew with strong malty aromas. There is a very flavorful, sweet even orangy malt flavor that is very smooth and enjoyable. The beer is a little thin, but overall very tasty.
Dark ale with a thick foamy head.  Rich roasted flaor with matching aroma.  Goes down smooth, overall very good.
Smooth dark beer, I was pleasantly surprised since I’m used to Spaten’s other beers.   This beer is the best I have tasted from this company.  The coffee flavor taste good.
nice beer shared with saaz buddies at coasters in melbourn a nice fluffy tan head caramel and molasses aromas roast coffee and full bodied very good
Nice looking dark beer with a coffee like aroma.  Great sweet taste and a wonderfully clean finish.  Excellent beer!!

Ruby colored with a quickly diminishing tan head...  Aroma is of brown sugar and caramel.  Taste is overly sweet to me, but it is complex.  Definite earthy notes, with some smoke to it.  Maybe not the starting point to get into German beer, but if you are a couple of brews into the country, you should give this one a try.
"Wicked Good!!" what my girlfriend thinks of this beer.  One of her favorites  that she believes is not perfect but pretty damn close.  Check out this German amber beer.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a thick off white head.  Aroma is slightly roasted, very mild hop presence.  Flavor is a little malty sweet, roasted and the hop presence is more pronounced.  Not bad.
The aroma is great coming at you with sweet ripe fruits. Flavor is sweet malt with a touch of hop. Not as sweet as some others. Very nice.

Poured a dark amber color, almost a chocolate brown; a thin tan head resting on top.

Smelled of dark roaster caramel malts.

Tasted much like the scnet, dark roasted malts and caramels. Hints of chocolate and coffee were also present.

Goes down smooth with a nice mellow level of carbonation. Leaves the palate a little dry, though.

Definately a solid session beer, I could drink this all night.

Serving type: bottle

pours from bottle dark red to brown. slight off white lacy head. smells of molasses and yeast. taste of bing cherries, tobacco. ends hoppier than i would have though. alcohol is stronger than i expected. not bad.

[Tap] Poured a clearish deep ruby with a moderate off white head. Aroma is surprisingly hoppy for a doppelbock, but there is plenty of malt to back it up. Lots of caramel, molasses, and dark fruits from the flavor. Flavor follows the aroma, with a nice hop bitterness on the finish.

Dark pour, little head.  Aroma is minimal, but its flavor is quite complex--figs, dates, bread, rye, fruit, and raisin.

Finish is clean and tart.

Draught: Sour, grainy nose. Not much head or lace. Tastes like a fruity Shiner Bock. Other flavors include figs, caramel, maple syrup and dark bread. Long, tangy finish with a little bitterness. Hoppier than the Celebrator or Salvator. What I found very interesting is the spicy cinnamon flavor that came out after taking a bite of a delicious sandwich that had horseradish on it. Decent.

12 oz bottle into imp pint glass. Very clear brown bottle with little to no head. Smells of malt and fruit- maybe some banana and raisin. Sweet taste initially with malt follow. Very light feel in the mouth and very easy to drink. This is a go to beer for me because of its easy drinkability while masking pretty high alcohol.

From a 500mL Bottle.  Transparent, cherrywood brown colored pour with a thick layer of fizzy beige head.  Fruity, raisin-laden munich malt aromas with some sweet caramel melanoidins.  Clean, soft, and malty, with no yeast or hop characters noticeable.  Medium bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel with a smooth, soft texture.  Hints of chocolate bitterness accompanies a smooth, raisin and plum laden malt flavor on the palate.  Fairly sweet in flavor, but doesn’t weigh heavily on the palate.  Moderate, warming alcohol presence.  Finishes clean and acceptably dry, leaving behind hints of chocolate roast lingering on the palate.  It’s a classic for a reason.

pours brownish red color, with tan head that didn’t last long, smells of raisins and maybe some fruit, also caramel malt. the flavor is on the sweet side with a slight bitter finish, alcohol is evident, in my opinion it also tastes like a sugar cookie but maybe thats just me. overall very enjoyable dopplebock.
esta la probe en munich cuando fui a pasear y todos los dias despues de reuniones nos echabamos las birrias y pasamos un buen rato que vale la pena super
12 oz bottle. Pours a brownish red cody with some off-white head. The aroma is sweet, the taste is roasty with some notes of sweetness and alcohol.

Calibration beer at the liquid poets first-and-a-half slam homebrew competition.   scores in () are bjcp, scores in [] are ratebeer

Aroma:  Malty-toasty.  some light metallic/oxidized notes.  some skunk (6/12) [5/10]

Appearance:  Med. brown w/ a think tan head.  small ring of tan bubbles @ edge of glass.  crystal clear (3/3) [5/5]

Flavor: Malty, bready, sweet start with toasty notes.  Light hop bitterness.  No Diacetyl. Clean finish, but with some sweetness (17/20)[8/10]

Mouthfeel:  Med. body, low carb , warming, all good for style (4/5) [4/5]

OA:  nice D’bock.  No major flaws except the skunk/oxidation. (8/10) [16/20]

Pours a fairly dark brown colour with a large tan head. Aroma is fruity, of black cherry and apples. Nutty of course, mouthfeel is creamy and taste is pleasent- roasted malts, butterscotch and almonds.
On tap, dark brown with slight head. Aroma is sweet and fruity, nice malt taste with little hops finish.
Nice aroma, great color and head, tase a little too bitter finish for me but overall a pretty good beer

The color was an orange/amber. The head was creamy, light beige, and medium-bodied. The aroma was alcohol, strong, and light licorice. The flavor was alcohol, spice, and a little bitterness. The palate was thin/medium bodied, nicely carbonated, and smooth. The finish was clean

Graduation weekend on tap at Scotty’s in Bloomington. Spaten Optimator Dark is a clear mahogany beer with a small and quickly disapearing head. The aroma is sweet with notes of hops and berries and small hints of alcohol. The taste is full of the same flavors with a roasted, dry finish.
Poured to a dark brown beer with a lacy head. The aromas of raisins and roasted hops were prominent. Initial taste of malted barley followed by a slighty bitter sweet finish. Not a bad beer.

Pours a dark neutral brown with very little tan head.  Nose is malty with the slightest sweet hint of fruit.  Taste is malty and caramelly with a hint of plum and raisin.  Finish is sweet with just a slightly bitter snap of hops.
12oz bottle. Pours deep brown with a very small white head. Nose is barely noticable sweet and noble hop. Flavor is sweet doppel to style with raisin and plum accents. Rather smooth on the palate.

Nice fruity nose with citrus hops balanced by darker, plum/raisin fruit. Kind of standard in brown-red bock color, off-white head, and no lacing. The palate was a little thin for my taste, though hops in swallow gave it a little boost. The flavor followed the nose with more dark fruits, a little bit of roast, and minor bread. Satisfying and drinkable.
pours a dark cloudy brwon with full frothy head, yeast smooth malt aroma.  light palate with a dry front.  milk chocolate hints in finish with malty background.

12oz bottle, dark amber color with a tan head that dissapates quickly. It’s tastes a bit of carmel, malts, grains, molasses and a hint of oatmeal. This is a first for me in the ’Spaten’ line. For some reason I expected a bit more out of this, but it gives a good try.
Dark amber in color with a tan head.  This brew was the best Spaten beer I have had but it was still middle of the road for me.  I wouldn’t go out of my way to drink this again.

12 oz bottle...poured a nice brown w/a small tan head that disappeared as fast as it appeared. Nose of caramel, malts, grains, malts. Flavors of dough, oatmeal, malts, molasses, and some sweetness. Medium bodied w/ slight carbonation...a slight bitter finish. Not bad!
Dark brown color. Big bubbles, a head that disappears quickly.  Brussels lace is non existent.  Taste is slightly complex but I thought it would be better. Mostly malty and grainy. Nothing special.
16.9 0z. bottle, nice head and dark amber color, big grape nuts malt flavor that overpowers anything else
Nice malt bomb. Lacey head with amber glow. Very little bitterness and lingers sweetly on the back of the tongue. Not too overwhelmingly complex as to distract form it’s purpose.
Pours with a small, light brown, fizzy head. Dark brown body. Aroma is strong of malgts with some prunes and soy saucee. Thick mouthfeel. Malty salty taste. Pretty refreshing.

Pours a deep amber/brown body with a thick tan head.  Lots of lacing left on the glass.  Aroma seems quite sweet with some maltiness and winelike notes.  The flavor is pretty strong, hits you a little hard but isn’t a bad taste.  A sharp winey characteristic mixed in with some malts and sweet sugary notes.  A little sour in the finish.

Dark, brazen brown body with a white settling head; occupies the Celebrator glass well... excellent tracings of lace... heightened malts.... the sweet aroma is warming and inviting... smooth, medium-bodied with little effervescence around the tongue and below...creamy... the pitch of bready yeasts and malts are empowering, rich and rewarding... the end is warming... in the first of six doppelbocks sampled, the Optimator sets a brisk pace... the malts arrive as expected, balanced as the lion and lamb month they ’re intended for...

Nice crystal clear amber color with a off white head. Smell is dark fruits, prunes, raisins, and a little effervescence to it, a good doughy yeast smell also. Smell is extemely smooth on the mouth. The dough flavor just coats your mouth and leaves a strong aftertaste to it. A bit of a raisiny taste but that bread taste is hard to beat. A damn good bet for a fairly common beer.

Pours deep mohagany into the dimpled mug with an inch of frothy white head.  Aroma of caramel, chocolate, hops and roasted malt.  A strong caramel flavor up front with a strange fruity flavor in the finish.  Not as good as I would have expected.
Poured brown with a hint of red. This is a malt lovers dream. Carmel and molassas are the primary flavors. Medium bodied beer with quite a bit of lacing left on the glass.

Probably the most common beer I still haven’t rated. Reddish brown, moderate head with pretty good lacing and retention. Aroma is immediately skunked, thanks green bottle! Some caramel, bread more sweet malts. Medium bodied, quite sweet. Pretty standard stuff, would be better in a non green bottle.
Pours a dark brown with a roasted caramel quality to both the aroma and taste.  Its a hearty bear and would seem to be a good brew for a cold night up here in Upstate NY.

I’m not a huge doppelbock fan to begin with so take that into account when I say this is a disgusting beer. This stuff should have a weight listed on it because it’s like drinking Quaker State Oil. I love the aroma, malty, as I would expect but the flavor is sweet, malty, and malty. The first drink wasn’t too bad but the more I drank the more foul it tasted. I couldn’t finish it
Pours out a deep red/brown color with a thick head. Very malty aroma/toasted malt taste, a little sweet in the end. Very easy to drink.

Bottle... Poured ruby with a thick off-white head.  Roasted malt and chocolate aroma.  Highly carbonated with flavors or roasted candy-like malt, chocolate, sweet caramel and toffee.  Very smooth and easy to drink but also complex and satisfying.

Pours a brown, slightly red, clear, body with a quickly descending head that never the less leaves some lacing. Brown sugar aroma along with something that might be dried fruit. Taste has a slight bite of alcohol and is pretty sweet at that. Sweetness might come from the fruity elements in the beer. Thick palate.

Pours a deep, clear brown with a thin, light tan head.  Slightly sweet malty aroma.  Lots of roasted malt flavor and biscuit.  A smooth mouthfeel and just a bit of sweetness.  Nice complex flavor and finish.  A very solid beer.

Poured into pint glass.  Rich, dark brown color.  Nice head with full foam.  Died down shortly after pour, but not immediately.  Smooth drinking, rich tasting beer.  Very easy drinking for abv.  Aftertaste isn’t great, but other than that this beer is a winner.

Dark mahogany color with minimal head, visible only around the edges really.

Huge sweet grainy malt smells.  Caramel, toffee, sweet barley, some fruity yeastiness. Slightly salty and a bit alcoholic.

Sweet roasted barley, caramalts, bit of fruitiness (apples).  Slightly salty drying finish, slightly alcoholic as it warms.

Somewhat aggressive carbonation, light-moderate body.  Pretty drinkable, but a little more rough than the best examples of the style.
A pretty good dark beer. Germs do well here. It is sweet. ottle, clear deep brown. Malt and caramel, toasty and roasty some sweetness. Also fairly priced.

bottle. pours a dark cola color with a bit of a red highlight. I had to force it to have some head by pouring the 2nd half of the bottle very roughly into the glass. the head is a light tan color that has a couple very large bubbles gathered in the middle, much like drinking milk as a child and blowing bubbles with your straw. has a very fruity nose: banana, raisin, plum, and peach are all noticeable. sweet raisin malt flavor with a bit of roastedness. finishes with a roasted bitterness.

Bottle.  This poured dark brown, very turbid.  the malt odor was noticeable.  There was little head or carbonation.  Sweet malt with grapes, and fruit, and licorice undertones.  The wine character was obvious.  still a reletivekly clean finish.
 Now on tap at Pipers pub
04/11 Stopped at the Stube on Hagerstown and it is on tap.

Pours a deep brown. Sweet,  thick roasted malt with a bit of a sour finish.  Alcohol really comes through as it warms. This one didn’t come together quite right for me. Didn’t really care for this dopplebock example.
bottle, clear deep brown.  Malt and caramel, toasty and roasty some sweetness.  Decent doppel bock, not the greatest ever but quite drinkable.
Bottle: Pours a deep brown with a tan head. Aroma, roasted notes, caramel, slight chocolate. Flavor, roasted malts, caramel, brown sugar, some earthiness, sweet and smooth on the finish. Very nice.

12 oz bottle, pours a dark clear amber color with little head. Aroma is of semi sweet chocolate with alcohol very evident. Taste is sweet and very powerful- it fills your mouth. Palate isnt that smooth but i found it quite appropriate for this kind of beer. Also not too watered down like some brews of this variety. Widely available and a good option at a bar.

bottle from my garage overstock, always one of the finest doppels ever made, beautiful deep and thick malts rock this powerhouse, the abv is a nice counter and is laid over by the complex smooth finish,  a true classic is the db block, oi

Obnoxious 3 inch head, but good taste to make up for it. Pour pure brown, without that red tint crap that most dark ales have. Head settles down to almost nothing of a tan foam quick enough. Aroma is of wood, malt, sugar, and clove, and hay. Taste is a little thick and of strong sweet malt primarily. This beer is almost cloudy depsite being a lager (bock) even though it is a doppel. The beer goes down rather easy, and smooth (no bite), unlike some beers (keystone) which claim to be smooth, this one actually is.

Back in the day, the doppelbock used to be one of my top faves.  Pours a sweet reddish brown, regular head, solid lacing.  (oops - just stuck my nose in the beer - head deflated- while smelling) Sweet, malty aroma.  Yep.  Head is gone.  Serving at "been out of the fridge for 12 minutes" temperature.  Palate is warm and tingly, more pronounced than a cold bottle.  I can’t tell what it tasted like, really.  Something smoked, maybe.  Taste is alot like the smell, but... different.  Leaves a neat after sensation in the cheeks. Definitely fulfills my tongue’s daily desire for good n’ yummy beer.  Anyway, I’m analyzing this great beer too much.  I just need to drink it and enjoy all that is Optimator.

This one is hurt by the fact that it was imported and probably has sat for a while.  Pour was fine - nice darker caramel color and thinner head.  Aroma was skunked pretty hard.  You could make out some caramel or dried fruit notes, but it was tough.  Flavor was a bit acidic on the palate and that funk came through pretty strongly.  I’ve had it fresh in Germany and this one is not nearly as good.  Blame the retail outlet or the wholesaler.

aroma of malt and raisin. Not much to look at. Dark brown color with little to no head. taste of plums and raisins. very dry palate with a bitter aftertaste. I think this is a good Doppelbock. Not outstanding but good.

pours amber with a one finger fluffy tan head. aroma is strictly caramel malt. has a medium body with descent lacing and carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma but a bit stronger. this could use a bit of bitterness but not bad of a dopplebock. a real easy drinking beer.
malty but not sweet,   Goes down very well for the alcohol content.  Its very easy to knock back a few and not even feel it until you get up.
Bottle. One of my favorite dark beers. The malt flavor and creamly mouthfeel are delectible. This brew goes down easy and with any bitterness. One of my fav for everyday beers.

Poured from a 0.5L bottle purchased locally. Deep amber with red hues. Small, tight, light tan head. Lace around glass and has legs. Brillantly clear. Aroma - Malty, slighty fruity. Strong malt flavor, dark, almost burnt caramel. No real hop bitterness. Just enough to balance malt. Sweet but not heavy or cloying. Thick, rich and smooth. Dries in the finish. Overall, a fantastic example of the style. Extremely drinkable for the gravity. I love the smoothness of the malt and the complex malt and caramel flavors.
Pours a dark brown color with minimal head. Tastes of alcohol and roasted malts. Pretty good, but not as dark as I was thinking, it has a clean balance in its body.
Bottle, pours a red color.  Aroma is super sweet with a diminishing offwhite head.   End is dry and a small note of alcohol.  Pretty good, this is a decent Dopple Bock I would try this again.

this beer meets its style well enough--low hops, dark, some alcohol in the flavor; however, i note a lot of buttery vegetables (along with a  typical note of caramel) that turns me off to prevent me from digging really any deeper...
500 ml bottle. Pours dark brown with amber highlights. Short tan head. Not much aroma some lightly roasted malt and dark fruit. Taste is nutty malt and molasses quite sweet. Pretty good.

Pours nice and dark with a nice roasted aroma and thick head. Very much enjoyed the first couple, be wary of having more than that. The malt really starts to come through and can become very overbearing. Would probably pass on this given a second chance.
500mL bottle. Pours dark chocolate with thin tan head. Nice roast roast malt aroma. Malty, slightly fruit taste with decent body. Good beer.
12oz bottle.  Dark pour with nice head.  slight chocolate with a hint of malty nut.  I taste no fruit at all.... not sure why others say that...

Bottle. Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet caramel malt with maybe a touch of hops. Medium/full, very pleasant body. Flavor is again malty, but kind of light. Notes of caramel and bread. Pretty good.
12 oz bottle.  Dark brown pour with white head.  Sweet raisiny aroma.  Very fruity.  Sweet chocolately flavor.  Like tootsie rolls, Nice balanced bitter hop finish.
Bottle. Amber color, nice brownish head. Roasted nutty malt aroma. Some milk. Malty nutty flavor, roasted and with chocolate.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with almost no head -- I want a big head on a dopplebock so this was disappointing.  Flavor is good though, true to style with pleasant mouthfeel.  Very smooth, nutty, slightly chocolaty, sweet.  Not bad, but there are definitely better dopplebocks.  Will re-rate.

Drank it at my parent’s house. They claim it is their favorite. Drank it at Epcot Center, at the German village Hofbrau. My consideration for the best representation  of good German bier ( against Becks and some other hiefenvizen)., It was paid for and was at Disney, thus the high score.
Bottle. Actually a case, from Costco. For the price, you can’t beat it. Dark color, sweet taste. A great value.
Has a nice fruity aroma. The head is a little thin, but the beer has a very full nutty/chocolatey flavor, particularly when served at the right temperature.  Very enjoyable.

Great beer.  Aroma of nuts and toasted bread.  Nice initial head, but didn’t last very long.  Sweet, malty flavor, with very present taste of alcohol, hints of oats.  Smooth with a slowly developing aftertaste.  Not incredibly complex flavor but very robust and well-balanced.

Pours a clear dark scarlet red to black. Carbonated with a thin elegant head. Caramel or coffee sweetened with brown sugar. Some hop presence. Bold coffee flavor fallowed by liquorish and a dark chocolate finish. Palate is thick, smooth, and wonderful.
Dark rich color with a hint of chocolaty flavor.  Creamy head and gives a bit of a warm feeling going down the throat.  Goes great with dessert.
Pleasantly dark with a rich malty taste. At the same time, easy to drink. Goes well with a heavy German meal.
I really liked Optimator, wasn’t sure what the style was when sampled @ World Cafe Live beer fest.  Hoppy, medium bodied dark  beer with sweet malt and great drinkability.

One of my favorite drinking beers. Color is dark reddish-brown, pours (out of bottle) with thin head. Aroma is dark and fruity, but not overly sweet. Flavor is wonderfully malty, and perfectly sweetened (meaning not too sweet). Not the most complex beer ever crafted, but a quality beer nonetheless, and really easy to drink.
Drank this with VMILaxer back in Jan, but forgot to log it.  Classic German taste, it was fruity with a thick, dry flavor of the roasted malt.

Pours a decent sized head that dissipates quickly but never fully disappears and a nearly opaque color.  The aroma is dark fruits, notably raisins.  Taste is huge malts with grapes and raisins.  Mouthfeel is pleasantly thick.  Quite good beer.
(German) Dark Brown color, with sm-Tan Head. Sweet fruit smell, and a bit Malty. Go for this one!!!

Bottle.  Pour is a thinnish brown with a two finger tan head and aromas of dusty grains, wood/sawdust, a touch of dark fruit and roasted malt.  Flavor is full bodied and interesting... molasses, sawdust, prunes, and sticky, brown sugar sweetness are all there in a thick mouthfeel.  This is thick and full flavored but could be a little more complex in terms of what it offers.

Bottle. Pours dark reddish brown with a small thick head. Aroma is dark malt, molasses, and crushed grains. Taste is thick bodied with heavy malt sweetness, molasses, yeast, and a hint of caramel malt. Finishes a little thick. A great dopplebock, but if you can find it on tap, I think it is a little smoother with more dark fruits (and much more dangerous because of the alcohol!).

bottle from local san diego.. pours a darker brown with a smell of oak and hickory.. the initial hit to the palate is very concentrated pulls of malts that wrap around my taste buds, well bodied and deliberate this drink has a hint of sweetness at the end.  good brew

Bottle at Winking Lizard. This brew is a deep mahogany color with a medium thin light beige head that dissipates fairly fast. Thin rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of malt, molasses and a bit of plum. Medium body with a sweet toffee and malt character. Light fruit and hops are present as well but the sweetness dominates. The finish is sweet with caramel and roasted malt and leaves a molasses and brown sugar aftertaste. Decent overall, although it swings a little too far to the sweet side.

Very nice, sweet bock. Full flavored, but not overpowering. The malts take center stage on this one, making for an excellent accompaniment to bratwurst or any other German food. ON SECOND ANALYSIS: This goes famously well with chocolate, or anything sweet. Gives you the hop nose, but doesn’t run against whatever sweet food you are eating.

I haven’t had this beer for a very long time and had completely forgotten what it tasted like...so when i had it on tap the other day I was very pleasantly surprised.  Pours a dark brown with a little red in there.  Thin head.  The flavor is overpowering of malt, malt, and more malt.  Very different though and well done.  It seemed to be a little fruity and sweet as well.  I think I might have to start having these a little more often.
Pours a dark brown and smells of roasted malt with oak and chicory. Tastes very much roasted but has a high alcohol finish. Enjoyable and nice to have a good German doppelbock.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Nate.  Pours brown with red hues, capped with a small beige head that disappeared quickly.  Nose is sweet fruit, prunes, berry, plum and cherry with honey and a touch of anise.  Taste is big on malt, some caramel and toffee with tons of fruit, cherry and prune, grape and raisin, with a slight bitterness at the end to create crisp finish that leads into an after of honey and cherry.  Tasty beverage.

Pours a nice deep brown, but there is nearly zero head.  Smells of fruit, almost prune-like.  Taste is very malty, with a nice touch of sweetness.  The body of the beer was as flat as it’s appearance, and left my tounge wanting some carbonation to liven things up a bit.
This beer changed my outlook on beer altogether. The greatest beer in the world. I wish they produced this stuff in a pony keg.
12 oz bottle. Pours a clear brown with very little head. Nose is of brown sugar and maple syrup. Taste is sweet. Flavors of brown sugar, maple syrup & honey. A sweet tasty treat.

12oz bottle.   Clear dark orange/brown, no head.   Sweet malty brown sugar and caramel aroma.   Sweet and clean flavor withsome dried fruit, no hops and some alcohol.   Very smooth and chewy palate.   Its crisp and drinkable, but pretty simple and somewhat boring; it just didn’t do anything for me.

I enjoyed the smoldering dark malts of this Spaten with tortellini alfredo last night. It was very easy to drink in the moment as I took her into view and I could have easily had another while the alcohol made a slight nuance in the overall flavor. It must be super on tap.

.5 liter brown bottle. Poured a clear reddish brown with about a finger of off white head. Huge malt aroma with some dark sugar and a little bit of noble hops. Fully bodied thick with malt. A pretty good amount of noble hop bitterness to balance the malt. Alcohol is evident in the finish. Good example of the style. Goes down a little too easy at 7.2% abv!

BOTTLE: Aroma is very interesting, not what I would call appetizing.  Nice body, effervescent, lively, flavor grows on me after first few drinks.  Maltiness obviously permeates the flavor which is good or bad depending on your liking, but for the style it’s excellent.

The best doppelbock  Fantastic flavor...best when served out of keg but still fantastic in a bottle.  Pours a dark red color, distinctive taste &#40compared to other dopplebocks&#41.  World Class 

First had at the Rathskeller in Indianapolis...changed beer drinking forever in my eyes.  Use to drink Budlight and Miller light...never again

New update - built a kegerator with Optimator on tap &#40all the time&#41 - What a life
Dark and malty.  Has a good fruit aroma with little harsh aftertaste.  Looked good in the glass.

Bottle 11771Y.  Not much more to say that the 1,000+ previous posts.  Pours a beautiful dark ruby red with a tan head.   Malts and sugars are strongly evident in the aroma.  Heavy mouth feel.  Very sweet and malty in the flavor.  A solid brew.

An excellent doppelbock, and has been for a long time.  Very dar amber to brown, nice head and lacing sticks throughout the glass.  Classic doppelbock aroma: malty sweet.  Full bodied, malty, and deceptively strong.

Very dark brown with some reddish hues.  There was a very small tan head that disappeared quickly.  Some bready, malty sweet smell.  Apples and some other dark sugars.  Almost not bitter in the taste, but a little bit hits you at the finish.  Has a good sweet and tangy flavor.  A nice thick mouthfeel too.
tap at blend.  Pours near black with a thin white head.  Dark fruit aroma.  Flavor is similar.  Raisin,  plum,  cherry, roasted malts and honey.  Light carbonation and slick pretty darn good.
lager journey. Feed the hungry kids. Etc.  A nice dub light headed sweet smokey taste. Good with meatloaf.

Bottle. Typical dark lager appearance, soft, creamy head, disappeared quickly. Raisins, prunes, some coffee bean, wheat make up both the aroma and flavor. Nice lager body, full but oh so easy going down. Very nice. 7-4-7-4-15/3.7

Rerate 5/14/09 Bottle. Aroma of very sweet malt, raisin bread-like. Flavor the same. Just overbearingly sweet for me, hint of sweet coffee, hint of sweet roast, everything has the word sweet in front of it, and though I guess that’s what they’re going for, it comes across to me as very unbalanced and not particularly fun.
A very good Doppelbock with tremendous flavor but still not quite on the same level as Celebrator and Salvator.
A really good dark beer with a sweet, refreshing aftertaste.  I really enjoyed this beer with my meal and would highly recommened that you try it.
Quit drinking for six years. This is the beer that got me start again. Best at germany in Epcot Disney after a long day. Germans call it Terminator.
Dark appearance, prune nose and creamy feel. Roasted malt and prune taste. Low carbonation and 7.2% alcohol content. Very enjoyable and smooth.
Sampled a buddies last night and was veryimpressed. Plan to buy on the next trip to the store. Any beer that has been brewed since 1397 is doing something right.

Draught.  Arrived at table with small head, but it came about ten minutes after I had ordered it, so I cannot know how long it sat before the waitress brought it...deep brown color, semi-transparent. Aroma of currants, medium roast malts.  Flavor is incredibly long & very well balanced. Sweet & malty, gradually becoming bittersweet & ending with a wonderful & thick hoppy bitterness. Yes!

12oz bottle, fridge cellared for about 6 months.


Caramel brown body with a towering light tan head. 3+ fingers thick and some nice retention. Also nice cobweb lacing. Nose of sour cherries, caramel malts, bread/biscuit dough, dark fruity esters and candied sugar. Fore is more of the same, concentrating on the fruit and sugar sweetness. Mid palate brings some nice toasty malts into play along with more of those dark fruits. Creamy mouthfeel, body is medium-full. Low carbonation.  Finish is medium length, dates, plums, malts and fresh dough. Very low bitterness in the finish which accentuates a nice toasted almond note even further. ABV is only noticeable in a slight warming effect as the beer is consumed, otherwise it’s well kept in check. Very nice.
wooooweeee! take a wild ride on the Spaten Optimator roller coaster!! Dark, tangy with subtle sweetnesses. But beware of Spaten in the bottle... tap is where it’s at!!

The aroma was deeply malty with a nice Munich malt toasty and biscuity aspect and a dark fruit characteristic of prunes and raisins. A crisp lager character and a light bit of spicy hops were notable along with chocolate and a bit of caramel. The beer poured into the mug clear amber brown with a beige long lasting tight bubbled head which laced the glass. The flavor was malty with a strong presence of caramel and light bit of chocolate coupled to a Munich malt presence which was nutty and toasty and had just a bit of a biscuity nature. The flavor also had traced of dark fruits, once again raisins and prunes. The bittering was just enough to allow the finish to go dry. The aftertaste had lasting dark fruits with some chocolate. The body was medium with a moderate level of carbonation and a creaminess on the palate. A really great doppelbock! 12 ounce bottle. Served in a huge Optimator dimpled mug.

Had this beer on tap at the German area of Epcot and really enjoyed it.  Purchased by the bottle at home, and loved it even more.
Mouth-watering aroma, and no bitter aftertaste like some it’s German cousins.  Pour this beer, smell it for awhile, and savor.

BottleDark pour with small microbubble head. Pretty light aroma with a sweet flavor. I’m really not too much a fan or the flavor though, kinda tastes like fake sugar. Decent, but I’ve had better dopples.
Good beer. Had on tap - great with the burger I had (drank extra cold). Heavy finish and great malty finish. Brown sugar and coffee.

Bottle sampled. Pours a deep dark brown with a nice fluffy tan head. Sweet caramel malt aroma with molasses, toffee, and notes of brown sugar. Flavor is smooth and full bodied with dark caramel, roast, toffee, brown sugar, and a hint of dark fruit. Very well balanced with a roasty dry finish. An excellent dopplebock

Who doesn’t love a good optimator.  This beer is an Oxford OH staple at the Steinkeller.  A very strong and bold doppelbock not for the faint of heart.  Let that malty flavor pour over you and take your time to enjoy.

Ohhh yeah, this was good stuff!,,,had one 1 hour ago. Pours a great deeeep red color, could be brown, terrific aroma. ahhhh, the smell...then it hits the tounge and a party starts.....wasn’t aware it had 7.2% alcohol, and I was on empty stomach...hit quicky! very nice....Very malty taste, the head was thick and did not want to go away. VERY malty flavor, still on my tounge, other beer taste like crap after drinking this within 30 min. Still not as great as a Celebrator, but pretty close! Very rich taste. Now I have to go to Germany!!!!

Bottle. Pretty deep brown color, little light comes through. Thin off-white head clings a little. Sweetish smell. Perhaps one of the best balanced beers I have tasted - easy swallower, non-bloaty despite packing some serious alcohol. Carbonation very even and non-distracting. Great roasted almost-caramel flavor. Strong but not overambitious malt presence. Sensed a slight metallic aftertaste in this batch that I will chalk up to improper storage by the retailer. DEFINITELY will get this brew again. Very enjoyable.
Medium head, malty aroma, balanced taste of sweet and roasty, hops bitterness in finish, thick, full mouthfeel.

Seeing as how the doppelbocks are my favorite style, I guess it’s time I actually rated this one.

Pours just like a doppelbock should, nice and dark.  The head on this one is never what I think it should be (compared to the Celebrator) but no matter.  This looks great, very dark and rich looking.

Smells very malty and full of molasses.  Very nice aroma.

Nice reliable doppelbock taste here.  Not quite what the Celebrator is but this is still a very good doppelbock.  Rich and malty, a bit sticky on the palate.  Smoother and smoother as this thing warms too.  

Overall, this is a good, solid beer and a good representative of the style.  Malty and rich.
I drank it from a tap in a dimpled mug.  The first thing i noticed was its dark color and tan foamy head.   It had lots of flavor and is definitely a great beer.

Pours a nice mahogany/brown with a tan head that stood up surprisingly long. Wonderful aroma of sweet malt, a hint of molassas. The mouthfeel is where this beer really comes through - almost like drinking silk. A great beer for a cold winter night - like tonight, in fact!

Pours dark caramel color, almost amber with a tan head that thins quickly.  Sweet aroma - fruity hints, some molasses notes.  Nice light bitter finish on the back of the tongue.  Much more molasses - a sweet, yet rich savory taste in one.  Not bad.  Sticks to the tongue a bit for my taste.  After a while a has a finish that reminds me of the taste of grass.
Caramel and roasted aroma.  Toasted, caramel flavor with very little hops detected.  Sweet finish, with just a bit of the alcohol.
yeasty/musty aroma with a soapy head....malty flavor with a sweet finish..not what I expected

Tons of flavor here... roast, malt, a little fruity (but it’s subdued), not hoppy.  The increased alcohol content is apparent in the flavor, too, but it compliments the other flavors.  Pours a deep mahogany.

On tap.
Very malty, with a caramel like taste. Great for those who aren’t fans of hops, but love strong flavors.

Poured a thin head which dissapated quickly.  Nice brown/ruby color body.  Aroma is a slight caramel with a hint of banana to it.  Decent toasty malt flavor.  No real hoppy bitterness detected... A nice beer overall.

Bottle. Sweet nose, some caramel and fruit with a touch of smokey chocolate. Flavor is a lot of the same, really nice but with a slightly cloying palate. A bit overly sweet, nonetheless a good bock. Deep brown, touch of ruby/amber in the thinner areas.
Pours dark brownish-black.  Small head that dissapates.  Nice aroma of caramel malts.  Medium body, sweet to the finish.  Very nice beer.

Pours a dark caramel red, rich and clear with a big light tan cream colo  red head, diminishing relatively rapidly to a thin layer.  the nose is sweet with big malt, caramel, with even a slight aspect of roasty fruitiness.  Clean with a small amount of honey.  Light floral hint of hops in the backdrop.  Sweet, but not cloying, rich in the nose mostly.  A full rich creamy mouthfeel.  Small subdued bubbles.  Big and sweet.  Rich round caramel malt with a bit of alcohol and some roast countervailing.  A of dark malt acidity makes the sweetness modestly powerful.  The caramel malt richness gives way to a fruity and actually dry finish, powered by a good bit of roast.  A lingering dry fruit stays on the tongue.  Not a bad go-to beer!
Tasted on draft at Yard House San Diego. Nice dubbelbock with a good ballance
pours very dark copper brown,nice thin whit head,very malty nose,strong,roasted malt flavor,very nice.
Very strong malt smell and taste.  FInishes drier than most dopple bocks.  .

purchased at red apple in bremerton, washington.
pours a dark brown with a red tint, medium head that dissipates quickly.
smell is sweet malts, caramel, touch of wheat, roasted nuts.
taste is similar to smell, roasted nuts and malts hit first, then a clean wheat taste, followed by a sweetness, leaves the mouth semi-dry.

Pours to a deep reddish hued cola colored body with a lively bread dough looking head.  The aroma is extremely bready and smells sort of like the asagio based sourdough bread I have in my fridge.  Perhaps a dark nutty cola too.  The flavor is dark bread dough, cola, and cloves.  Something that I can’t quite put my finger on pervades through this beer’s flavors.  Almost like some grape juice or other dark sweet fruit like dates?  The palate is sweet, medium bodied, has little texture.

Pours Dark Red-Brown.  Tan head that dissipated almost instantly.  Aromas of malts, yeast, and molasses.  Smooth on the mouth, flavors of molasses with malts and yeast underneath, along with a slight nutty flavor.  Finishes dry and lingers.

Draft at the Issaquah Brewhouse. Deep burnished mahogany with rubied and golden-brown highlights. Light rim (grayish), light lace. Caramelly and roasty nose. Clean, light body with density and complexity to it, but certainly not overwhelmingly so--in perfect balance. Rich caramel, nut, and toast on the mid-palate. Clean finish.

Dark ruby red color. Tan thick head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is surprisingly clean for such a dark beer. Hints of malty sweetness with touch of yeast and molasses. Smooth taste. Light sweetness and molasses. Decent mouth-feel. Very drinkable. Not too aggressive. For a beer that is readily available in grocery stores, a good option. I buy it regularly.
Reddish-cherry color, small white head.  Strong caramel smell and taste.  Sweet, but enjoyable.
tap.  small tan head into dark brown body.  aromas of strong malts (caramel) and light hops.  very enjoyable beer.
Bottle. Pours with no head, clear, dark, dark brown. Aroma of coffee and banana. Taste is light for a doppelbock, with all the requisite flavors as well as a little coffee and bubblegum. Pleasant.

Funny, I’m not really getting the same experiences as the rest of you are. This is my beer of choice when I go to my favorite bar, Red Lion, in LA. Don’t get me wrong, it’s different than a sipping beer, but I love the full-bodied taste, the sweet/bitter after taste, and the crisp finish. It does leave that caramel, heavy sweetness feeling in your mouth like you get after drinking Coca Cola, but a glass of cold water along with it really finishes it up nicely. I love Optimator.
I like the color.  Had an interesting allure.  Smell could have been better, but I’m not complaining.  Rather light taste, but a good beer overall
Pale, nothing special. You can taste the alcohol from time to time. Skunky. Could have been a dated bottle fom a store that primarily seels 30 packs. I’d get it again though.
Some times I really like and sometimes I just can’t palate it.  Can be a little too sweet at times. Nice roasted flavors and bready maltiness.

very average and forgettable,  clear mahagony color and white head which diminishes quickly w/o at trace. would make a good base for a beef barley or fall vegetable soup.  Not complex at all.  Can’t understand the high rating.

Good but not great.  Im pretty sure I got an old bottle.  I popped the top, and all I smelled was skunk.  Tasted pretty good though, albeit a bit strong on the nose with the alcohol.  Very sweet, medium hoppiness, and bitterness. Not bad.

Appearance: Pours a clear, dark reddish-brown body with a small, off-white head.

Smell: Somewhat sweet-smelling aroma of carob, dark fruits, and apples.

Taste: Mild dark caramel flavor mixed with some carob sweetness. Accompanying notes of dark fruits and chewing tobacco. Very minor hint of apple. Only a faint amount of hop spiciness, but no real bitterness. Touch of alcohol on the finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: It’s a pleasant middle-of-the-road doppelbock.

Bottle. Drank from the bottle so no comment or deductions for appearance. Will re-rate. Caramel malt aroma. Very rich malt character with notes of molasses. Some roast qualities as well. Very good for a green bottle brew.

12 oz bottle:  Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, caramel and a little bit of nutty goodness.  Poured a almost coca-cola like black with a medium sized tan head that diminishes into a soapy tan foam at the top of the glass.  Taste is caramel malts, roasty, somewhat chalky, chocolate cake, and a bit of espresso too.  Palate has a lingering malt texture and is quite carbonated and bubbly.  Overall,  Not a bad Doppelbock IMO.  Not bad at all
Pours mahogany/brown with a thin tan head.  Smells of caramel, pepper, some hints of offee and roses.  Tastes of licorice, dark fruit, brown sugar, caramel, sweet malt.  Decent.

12 oz. bottle 
Pours a garnet hue with a big brown head. Has a black licorice sweet smell. Taste is a strong, dark caramel, black licorice and chocolates. Full bodied, almost syrupy mouthfeel. Finishes with a slight bitter alcohol taste. 
This brew tastes best at warmer temps. 60-65 degrees.Oct 2003
Dark, delicious doppelbock. Rich and malty, suitable for the style. A little on the metallic side. Not my favorite doppelbock but a highly drinkable one nonetheless.

Pours a dark reddish brown with about 2 fingers of lingering head.  A scent of cherries and leather.  The taste is sweet malt and cherries- very sweet taste with a nice citrus aftertaste.  A pretty good beer, especially for $13 for a 12 pack.

I was not so impressed with this one. Slightly grassy flavor with a strange and lingering aftertaste. I was at a bar and I could have been given something else because it didn’t taste much like the others’ descriptions.
Bottled. Nice dark appreance. Taste is ok, maybe a bit to much bitter aftertaste for me. I will say the 7.2% alchohol content gives it a nice kick.
Quite possibly the best beer I’ve had!  Pours a dark hue; taste is very strong and flavorful.  After taste sticks with you for a good amount of time.  Would definately drink this again (and again).
Dark, almost ruby black.  Aroma and taste are very bready... especially manifesting as a worty or unfermented flavor. $6/16oz

Lately, this has beer a favourite. It tastes so German to me. I love it. Sadly, we cannot get it in Alabama. But it is in Florida and it is delicious. It is somewhat flawed. It is a bit overpoweringly alcoholic, yet the complexity of the palate and the flavour of caramel is to me a beautiful thing. I love it. I would buy it more regularly if we could get it in AL.

Bottle- Sampled @ Siebel during the German style tasting- Clear dark brown cola color, off white foam, small bubbles. Nose is raisin, some brown sugar. Very sweet, unbalanced. Would be hard to enjoy a whole pint.

Poured into a dimpled mug in Munchen.  Clear amber, brown colour with a medium head and good lacing.  Nice roasted malt flavour but maybe a touch too sweet.  Big flavour of molasses and sorghum.  Still enjoyable though.
Had this on tap in the microbrewery at the Mt Angel Oktoberfest and i must say that it lifted my spirits whilst watching a polka band with an alphornist.
tap.  falling rock.  maple pour with almost no head.  big roated malt, maple sugar aroma.  sweet like candy.  sugar and maple.  thick rich toffee malts.
This is a very tasty well balanced beer.  smooth but with a tingle on the lounge.   I enjoyed this over and hour.  it was great.  Ill buy this again and soon!
12 ounce bottle purchased at ABC Liquor Pembroke Pines, FL $1.61This a great  beer.

Aroma: Strong roasted malt, sweet with slight chocolate on the nose. Appearance: Dark brown with ruby highlights. Off white foam head with good retention. Flavor: Caramelized rich maltiness with a hint of chocolate. Alcohol of 7.2% is warming and not overwhelming. Hops are supporting roll and not prominent, but strong enough to balance it to the malty side. Overall: This is a great beer. Strong malt, sweet and smooth. Excellent overall taste with well caramelized flavors. Highly recommended. Cheers.

12oz bottle,  Aroma is malty with fruit juice, and sweet malts.  Nice Dark brown hue with a medium sized off-white head that mostly diminished and left no lace.  Flavor is sweet and malty with an average finish.  Palate is full bodied and oily flat.  Less offensive than a belgium but still not my style.
Nice dark pour with small head.  Flavor is malty with astringent backing.  A little too much alcohol burn to this one, but I can’t complain.  Great beer.
7.2%?? Where is it?  Hidden so nicely under rich malts.  caramel, coffee, toffee flavors are present. smooth going down, very nice.

Bottle. Nutmeg aroma along with some roasted notes. Dark body but held to light you get a mahagany red body with decent head. Flavor is not overly sweet as most doppelbock tend to be for me. Caramel, tooffe, nutty and coffee flavors present. Thick body texture. Little chewy tobbaco left on palate. Decent beer.

Poured brown in color with a nice, stubborn, off-white head. The nose was strong with molasses and chewy caramel. The taste was dark, heavy molasses were unrefined and very bitter. The malt flavor was just dripping with it. The rich, caramel compimented it well. The end had a nice round toffee finish with strong warming alcohols. This is a very rich, heavy-duty beer. Not for the timid.

this is the kind of beer that i know is good but i dont like it. ive tasted other dopplebocks and this one was much better, but i still dont like it so ill try to score it as a dopplebock instead of the beer i drink

Pours a beautiful rich chocolate brown. Aroma is strong, mainly malty, and tempting. Flavor is rich and malty with hints of toffee and a smoky undertone. There is not the least bit of bitterness. Smooth, very pleasing, this beer is great all by itself, especially after a meal.

Vanilla and licorice aroma, a little yeasty. Color is very clear, ochre-brown. Medium tan head,  Good mouthfeel, but flavor is bad. Horehound and dry dog food. The unpleasant qualities fade during warming. Alcohol is noticeable, but only in the background. Finish is weak but well balanced hop and bark.
A favorite Bavarian doppel, excellent malty sweetness from the heavy malt but not too much or too much like syrup.  Just a hint of hops. Great for a night with a bit of a chill in the air.

Date: November 28, 1996

Mode: Draft

Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs

Appearance: dark ruby red, thin head

Aroma: sweet carmel malt aroma

Flavor: lots of rich sweet malt flavor with sweet crystal carmelness, no appearant hops

Overall: similar to a scotch ale



Date: December 08, 2004

lots of rich malt flavor but somewhat dry, 



Date: August 31, 2005

Mode: bottle

Aroma: mart aroma

Flavor: bit sweet malt flavor, just a touch of hops for balance



Date: October 15, 2008

Mode: draft

Source: summits woodstock

Appearance: clear dark brown, fine beige head, spidery lace

Aroma: sweet dark caramel aroma, light smokyness

Flavor: rich malt flavor, caramel sweetness is well balanced with a smokey earthyness giving it a dry character



Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20

Rating: 3.6/5.0
Drinkability: 7/10

Score: **4
A total surprise. Rich dark in color with a full head that dissipated very fast.  For its dark rich look it was very smooth and slightly sweet. I felt this would be a great dessert beer.

An excellent doppelbock.  It looks like a stout when you pour it.  The flavor and aroma are of rich malt, chocolate, and some coffee.  The head diminishes really fast for some reason.  I found this beer quite refreshing for how heavy it was.

Poured from a bottle. Aroma is decent. Very dark amber in color. Head is somewhat thick, diminishes sooner rather than later. I have to admit, I was expecting something a little more carbonated on the palate. It seemed somewhat flat, but the flavor was decent. Has a nice kick.
Among my favorite doppels.  If it is huge mouthfeel and malty sweetness that you are searching for, then you have found your brew.

Spaten Optimator is simply my favorite beer in the world. I was first referred to it by a friend in South Bend, Indiana since I had described what type of beer that I like and he thought that I might like this one. Optimator, to me, is a "heavy" beer (especially the bottled version) meaning that it is alcoholic and I personally can only drink two of them in an evening. 

The appearance is excellent. An amber "body" with a lighter orange, yellowish head. The smell is chocolatey and even is a bit like a mocha. Taste is even more like a mocha with a very dry middle taste but then a very pleasing smooth after taste. "Mouthfeel" which is something that I had not even thought of before is very good as Optimator is very smooth. To me, it is more like a meal in and of itself so if you are eating while drinking this then you will get very full very fast. 

Again, it is my favorite beer of all time. I drank the draft version at Chef Paul’s Bavarian House in Lisle, Illinois while visiting with family there and I actually prefer the draft to the bottle since it is a bit lighter. I cannot say enough good things about Optimator.

Poured from bottle.  Poured a deep amber color with a nice head that diminished somewhat.  The taste was dominated by malt flavors with a hint of fruit (apple?) making an appearance.  Nice mouthfeel and little alcohol presence.

Deep coffe and buttery toffee aroma. Thick head that lingers and leaves some lace. Dark brown with a little burnt ochre color...not quite red but reddish hue.  Heavy malt flavor with a strong warmth. Spicy on the tip of the tongue. Well balanced. Not over sweet like some dopplebocks. Medium bodied. A delightful beer.

Aug 2005 - I thought this was a good, but not great dopplebock. The green bottle made me nervous, but no skunk was there. Poured deep reddish color with nice head and lacing that clung to the glass throughout my drinking endeavor. Mouthfeel was slightly carbonated, but smooth. Taste was really good, but not as full, rich or complex as Celebrator or Maximator...but not sickly sweet as some of the "low end" dopples are. Well done.
One of my first dark beers. Very impressed! Great taste and a beautiful color. I’ll def be having this again. Soon.

Bottle - Amber appearance with a slight red tint. Very sweet caramel flavor with a hint of  cherry and spice. Very full bodied and smooth. Good from start to finish. did not detect and type of bitterness in this beer. This is one that stays in my stock when I can find it around here. VERY enjoyable beer.

Clear russet appearance with a medium size, off white head and little lacing. Sweet aroma, with dark fruit, caramel and a hint of soy sauce.  Earthy, roasted malt flavor accompanied by dark fruits like plums, figs and raisins.  Low keyed hop presence.  Alcohol rocks the taste buds for awhile.  Full bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel with a long lasting, semi-sweet finish.

Aroma: Malt/yeast with chocolate, freshness hits me as well. Surly darkness with minimal  light filtering through. Looks: Cherry darkness in direct light. Taste: The hops still has a presence with all the malt and roasted goodness going on.
Bottle. Pours deep reddish brown. Aroma is is thick, syrupy caramel malt. Flavor is buttery, dark spirits, caramel and toffee, somewhat sweet. Sticky finish.
this was the first doppel I ever had and amazingly it still holds up as my fav doppel

Pours a dark amber color with a light tan head.  Aroma is of roasted malts, caramel, dark fruits, and molasses.  Flavor starts off sweet with the dark fruits, caramel, and molasses then finishes with the toasted malts.  Nice lingereing flavor as well on this one.  Very delicious, I don’t know why I didn’t rate this sooner.
Nice... Deep amber.   Aroma of Sweet malts.  Sweet taste of caramel and molasses.  Smooth finish despite the ABV.
i love this beer!  dark ruby/red color.. malty scent. a little fruity and the high ABV is very surprising.
A really good beer. Nice balance with sweetness and smoothness. 7.2% but really well hidden. Great!
The standard for Doppelbocks, in my opinion.  Dark brown color, malty aroma, and a hint of fruit (apple?) in the flavor.
Darrk red pour very little hear tan in color and it was gone quickly. Nice arroma, yep apple and you can,t taste the alcohol but its there well hidden well ballanced a delightful brew.

damn good dopplebock. Nice and malty, touch of sweetness balanced, caramel and toasty with good hop flavor. Decent carbonation. Ayinger is still my fave, but for 33% less cost, Spaten makes a great substitute, plus it seems to be more available

Pours dark brown, clear, with a moderate head. Aroma is somewhat roasty and sweet. Flavor is chocolate, caramel, and other "dark brown" flavors with a hop tingle that really sets it off. I’m generally not big on dopplebocks, but this was good.

Pleasantly surprised with this, a pretty mass-marketed doppel. Poured deep reddish brown with a nice light brown head that quickly fizzled down to almost nothing. Smells of biscuits, caramel, and apples. Very rich malts in the taste, and the apples come through in force here as well. Smooth palate, pleasant carbonation.

A WEIRD SORT OF A BREW - SMELLS  ALMOST OF BROOMSTRAW - IT IS NOT PARTICULARLY ENTICING - EVEN TO THIS LAGERMONKEY. THE TASTE IS QUITE INTERESTING, ASTRINGENT EARTHY, MILDLY SPICEY WITH A MORE THAN TOUCH OF SPICY GERMAN STYLE HOPS! HOT AS IT IS THIS BEER WENT DOWN WELL. COMPLETELY HIDDEN ALCOHOL. TINGLE IS GOOD ON THE TONGUE AS WELL. I FOUND IT PERFECTLY (MILDLY) SWEET. THIS COULD BE ADDICTING. MY BEST GERMAN SO FAR. COMPLEX IT IS MUCH LIKE A WINTER BREW.

Rated 8/5/07.  Semi-cloudy, dark chestnut body.  Large, uniform tan head that recedes to a thin film.  Spotty, sudsy lacing.   Caramel, toffee, yeast, bread dough, and a hint of spice comprise the nose.  The flavor is sweet from the caramel, with a myriad of floral flavors and an ever present yeasty pungency.  Little to no hop bitterness.  Carbonation is quite apparent on the palate, and it leaves a bit of a tingling sensation in the back of the throat for a few seconds after the swallow.  The body is on the light side of medium, with ample sweetness lending to a light syrupy consistency.  Quality brew that is just a little to sweet for my taste.

Bottle and served in my Unibroue tulip: Finally got off my arse and rating a beer I have had numerous times. A deep rich caramel brown hue with a fading beige fluffy head and good lace. The aroma has notes of nougat, marzipan, caramel, toffee, earthy yeast and a hint of alcohol. The taste is pure sweet dark malts, pumpernickel and rye found as an undertone. As expected the bitterness is almost non-existent as it should be. The nice well attenuated dry finish with just a touch of allspice. The mouth feel is lively yet hardly aggressive with the alcohol mostly an afterthought. A classic bier in the old world tradition.

12 oz bottle.  Country House with Dad.  Poured very dark.  No head.  VERY sweet tasting- like drinking a Coke.  The sweetness and prevalent alcohol masked the other flavors this beer had.  I am sure this is a high-quality product- but just not my preference.
This smells like what a doppelbock should smell like.  Nice licorice overtones, smooth mouthfeel.  Reddish brown in color.  Nice mix of malts and hops.

Pour is dark brown with red highlights, short off-white head.  Roasted malt, maple syrup (nice call kmw), toffee, molasses in the aroma.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Rich flavors of malt, more molasses, cookie dough, toast, and alcohol.

12oz bottle, courtesy of LordMaynard (who likes to give me free beer).  Thanks, Russ!  Pours a deep, ruby-crimson color; off-white head with patchy lacing.  Generous, nougat and chewy wet malts in the aroma; some maple syrup and sugar.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: relaxed carbonation, showing a dense malt core (caramel, nougat, and maple syrup), with a slight viscosity to it; some toasted malts appearing mid-palate; dense and chewy without being absurd.  Very drinkable.  Medium, candy sugar and toasted malt finish.

A dark brown pour with a light white head and lace. A sweet malt flavor with a hint of chocolate. Just a hint of good warmth. A solid smooth palate with decent carbonation that is just a tad fizzy. Overall solid beer but sweet if you like that

Sweet, malty, some fruit aroma.  Russet color with an off white frothy head.  Taste was sweeter than I thought and there was this slight alcohol presence.  Almost bitter at the end.  Ist Gut.  Nicht wunderbar.  But I do thank Mr and Mrs Kobler for the gift.

(16.9oz bottle): Pours a medium to dark reddish brown, big tan head, lasting. Very sweet malty aroma, wood and toffee, grape juice, but not very strong an aroma. Taste of some coffee, chocolate and grape juice, effervescent. Not heavy like I thought. Good.

I’ve had this beer plenty of times and just now noticed I’d never rated it...gave me an excuse to pick up another bottle (not that I really needed one).  Pours a nice molasses with red highlites and a small tan head.  Toasted malts, wood, molasses, raisins, and some other dark fruits.  Body is creamy and full.  Tasty with a finishing bite, too.  Toasted, woody, sweet malts, molasses, and a little cocoa.  The alcohol isn’t very noticeable.  Finish is long and bitter/burnt malt.  One of the first "real beers" that got me hooked on this obsession.  Will always be one of my favorites.  Excellent.

12 oz (green) bottle.  Deep chestnut brown with a nice light beige head.  Aroma is not too strong: roast malt, sweet/tart fruit (cherries?), and chocolate.  Taste is sweet, with suggestions of roasted nuts, chocolate, alcohol, and lightly burnt caramel.  Not too strong.  Smooth and very drinkable.  I kinda like it.

500 ml bottle.  Pours a deep rich mahogany with a copious tan head.  Plums and raisins in the nose.  Medium-heavy body with a bold malt presence.  Semi-sweet malty start with complex fruity lingering finish.

bottle. color is a heavy ruby brown  shade that nearly looks black. a light tan head briefly forms on top. strong sweet raisin and plum aromas with a deep roasted smell and light hops showing up also. nice roasted flavor that is fairly light, a little sweeter than other dopples. spicy hops come into play on the finish. this has more molasses and plum than the bitter chocolate and coffee flavors that i go for in this style. but it is quite good and very quafable.

The pour is dark oily brown with a tan head. the aroma sparks molasses, chocolate, nuts, and roasted malt. It seems to me that there a slight hint of dough and yeast. Deep rich malty flavors with molasses and hint of nuts. A very heavy body beer with a slight bitter mouth feel The finish last a few minutes.  A very good beer to enjoy

I am astonished, if not appalled, at the other reviewers high ratings.  Admittedly, I don’t like doppelbocks, but this seemed particularly bad for a doppelbock.  The aroma is weak, malty, as I would expect.  Flavour: sweet, malty, rich, a tiny bit of sourness.  I think it is too sweet, and too weak tasting.  But this is not my main concern: as one drinks this more, an unpleasant character emerges, a sort of strong biting taste, a foul taste.  The alcohol content is not well masked; one can taste the alcohol and it burns slightly.  A poorly executed beer which I will avoid in the future.

The aroma is inviting, some chocolate, caramel, and very fruity.  There is also a vegetable aroma I can’t quite place my finger on, but I rmember it from other dopplebocks and porters I have tried.  Nice dark brown/ruby color, medium tan colored head.  Flavor is sweet, malty, lots of molasses/brown sugar notes.  The mouthfeel is medium/thick, true to the double bock style.  Nice finish, malty sweetness left on the palate.  Reminiscent of a porter as much as a dopplebock.  Very enjoyable beer overall.  This is one of the beers which started my craft beer odyssey.
It IS a great German beer. Very rich and deep. Malty flavored and strong. ++

Bottle. Poured dark reddish black with a medium brown head. Decent lacing. Aroma was of roasted malt. Flavor was fairly sweet at first, but then changes to a very burnt-roasted malt flavor. Palate was medium bodied and clean.

Bottle shared with Blankboy, his bottle.  One of those ones I always see on my trips to Buffalo and say "Sure, I’ve had that".  Well look at that, I never rated it until now!  Nice fresh aroma - tons of burnt sugar, wood, lots of sweetness.  Dark orange, small white head.  Taste is sweet, tinny hops, burnt sugar/caramel.  Full bodied and complex.  Great stuff, certainly lives up to its hype!
Bottle.Clear dark brown.Sweet dark brown sugar and molasses aroma.Sweet roasted malt flavor.Medium body.Clean finish.Very nice.
Excellent dark bock available at our local german joint, student prince. A very strong malty flavorful brew

Draft. Heavy malty aromas of dark bread, molasses and toastiness with light notes of herbs and earth, and dates and cola in the background. No head to speak of (but I’ll bet the bottled version has a decent head) and the color is root beer. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, and finishes lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, watery to oily with a lively carbonation. A nice deep Doppelbock.

Perhaps I was spoiled by the highly-rated Ayinger Celebrator but this beer tasted quite watery to me. The core taste was pretty good, with a suggestion of roast, but the finish seemed weak, particularly with Spaten, whose beers I generally like.
unfortunately i didn’t really enjoy this beer.  after drinking half of the first one i called my brother and offered the rest to him.

The color was an orange/amber.  The head was creamy, light beige, and medium-bodied.  The aroma was alcohol, strong, and light licorice.  The flavor was alcohol, spice, and a little bitterness.  The palate was thin/medium bodied, nicely carbonated, and smooth.  The finish was clean.
Great dopplebock! Pours a nice dark reddish black mohog color. Smells sweet and caramel like. Small fizzy head that dissapates quickly. Tastes of malty and caramel. Roasted notes too. Really nice.

Dark mahogany with small white head. Caramel and faint molasses nose, lightly toasty. The malts just go so well with food, sweet roastiness meshes so well with any kind of meat. Smooth on the palate with a long malty finish.
Bottle. Poured a very dark brown color and head didnt last too long.  Nice roasted malt flavor.  This was one of the better doppelbocks I’ve had.
xxx a good beer here, not sometthing i would drink often, but definitely a nice beer to taste here and there/.

Draught:  Faint aroma of malts, nuts, and wood.  Poured brown with a hint of ruby and a small brown head.  No lacing.  Sparkling.  Almost opaque.  Flavor of tons of malts with nuts and wood.  Medium body.  Sticky texture.  Average carbonation.  Malty finish.  Overall, way too malty but good for the style.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into my Bell’s dimpled mug.  This beer poured a dark brown color with visible carbonation and a one finger thick beige head that slowly faded away.  No lace.  The aroma consisted of rich roasted malts and a sweet caramel note.  The flavor was mostly malty, with notes of caramel and dark fruit.  The mouthfeel is full-bodied and lively.  Just the right amount of carbonation and alcohol.  Very well done.  Excellent!
Bottle. Very dark brown, almost black color. Not much head. Dark, malty flavor of dark fruit. Slight kiss of hop bitterness. This is an excellent doppelbock IMHO.
12oz bottle into a stem glass, pours a cocacola brown with little quickly disappearing head, smells of carmel, tastes of carmel, chocolate, honey, sweet finish, very smooth going down.
bottled. dark amber with a beige foam. flavor was of roasted malt and caramel with some grain in the end. traces of the alcohol. simple but cleam finish and easy to drink.

My bottle (12oz), shared with tupalev. Pours a clear deep orange-ruby with a small diminishing creamy tan head. Nice aroma of roasted malt and burnt caramel . Flavour’s the same, roasted malt and burnt caramel along with some grain and mild hops -- simple yet very enjoyable. Medium bodied. One of the best Doppels I’ve had, this is very refreshing and easy to drink -- great stuff!

1 pt .9 fl oz bottle.  Pour is a reddish brown with a 1 inch tan head that faded quickly.  Aroma has a bit caramel malt and a dried fruit.  Taste is very smooth, starts with some sweetness, continues sweet in the middle with more malt and finishes with sweet/sour.   Easy drinking, but nothing special.  A little bit of metal funkiness in the aftertaste.  I had this ages ago, and remember liking it better.

Pours a clear ruby-brown with a small, beige head that quickly diminishes to the surface. The aroma is fairly muted with a sweet caramel and cookie nose backed by a light raisin. The mouthfeel is medium-bodied and slick with a clean, lightly dry finish. The flavor is sweet malts, caramel and an effervescent, lingering, dark fruit finish. Quite tasty with a hint of alcohol on the exhale, this is a nice doppelbock, but it’s not even in the same league with Ayinger’s Celebrator.
Wonderfull beer with heavy maly taste, and subtle caramel flavors, nice malt aroma and cola like appearance, not overly carbonated.

Bottle. Nice dark brown color with a beige head, aroma with some chocolate, caramel and coffee, notes of acohol and coffee in flavor, the finish is like some between swetty and bitterness..

Cerveja escura com espuma bege e aroma doce com notas de chocolate, caramelo e café, sabor forte notas de álcool e café, fica um sabor entre o amargo e doce. muito boa..

Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a medium light tan head. the aroma is malty with hints of fruit and chocolate. The taste is almost like black licorice with a smooth finish. better than oktoberfest.
Bottle... beautiful dark color, light brown head, wonderful aroma, and a full flavor with much character. One of my favorites!
bottle and draft.  Rathskeller 5/1/07  Some choclate notes with a cedar aroma and taste.  Thin mouthfeel with a heavy stomach feel.  One is much better than three.

Amber brown with a small white head. Aroma of caramel/toffee malts, and some light hops. Flavor is mostly lightly sweet caramel malts upfront, with a lightly hopped undertone. Palate is medium, a bit effervescent, lightly sweet, and a bit sticky. Decent, but a bit one-dimensional.

Pours dark brown with ruby highlights and a thin head. Big sweet malty aroma, caramel, a light fruitiness, some german hops. The taste starts with a big malt base, more of the grassy hops and caramel, smoothly carbonated. Not as good as I remembered.
Good fallback beer most regular grocery stores in my area stock it.  Pours dark tan with light head.  Leave your lips a little sticky as it has an orange sweet flavor.  On tap at j-Betskis
brown light tan head med to light body and carbonation strong orange water aroma bitter floral and salty with malt orange
Bottle, dark clear color, with a malty aroma. taste is malty semi bitter/burnt. A more watery mouthfeel than I expected. Not a bad brew, but definately no Celebrator.

12 oz. bottle courtesy Thaichile. Dark ruby amber colour with a fully diminishing fizzy off-white head. Molasses, burnt sugar, caramel, vinous, and light fuselly alcohol aroma. More caramelized sugar and molasses in the flavour along with toffee, orange, walnut, and merlot, with a light alcohol and nutty bitter finish. Full bodied, rich mouthfeel but a bit sticky. I presume this is one of those classic before Interbrew/InBev got a hold of it stories? As it is now, just okay.

Rated 11/22/06:  Powerfully sweet doppel. Aroma is killer very strong and hearty with lots of sweet malts and a dark fruitiness. Generous brown pour sizeable head that calms down. Mouthfeel is rich and sweet easy going down with a nice finish. Flavor is highly malty really hanging on the sweet side. Nice breadiness with some strong caramel and maple syrup influences. Enjoyable but really sweet.

Aroma of medium dark malt with underlying grassy hop. Beautiful ruby color in front of halogen. Light beige head that lasts for quite a while. Nearly full bodied. Almost chocolate with clean roasted malt. No nasty burnt tones. Really seems like light chocolate. Smoooooth. Mouth smacking good. The finish is kind of toffee caramel, and I don’t think there is much, if any bitter, but the roasted flavors are so clean that it does not matter.

Decent brew. I thought the flavor was a bit weird when I first tried it. I didn’t know it was a doppelbock until I tasted the sweet characteristics. It tasted like a type of sweet syrup at first. The palate was fine. The beer was kind of thin and had the consistency of oil, in a way. It was smooth and the aroma had a nice sweet smell to it. I enjoyed this beer, but I think the Celebrator did do a better job, by adding flavors like honey and coffee, still a decent beer.
Bottle.  Dark brown.  Very sweet flavor, almost syrupy.  If taste was less sweet, other flavors would have been much more balanced.  Carmel notes, some hop.  Good dopplebock.

Dark brown with some red in the light. Medium thick creamy light tan head. The aroma is sweet and malty, caramel. The flavor, some hop. The palate was a little thin for this. Not as good as I expected.
The best dopplebock i’ve had to date. Rich, robust flavor. All around nice beer.
Wow!  Simply amazing.  The caramel and malt aroma is awesome.  Great tast.  Great bock.
Pours a deep brown color with no head.  Aroma is sweet malts, some caramel, and a bit of roasted malts.  Flavor is malty, doughy, and a touch of roasted malts.
Draught.  Brown pour with light tan head.  Aroma of caramel and malt.  Flavor of caramel, brown sugar and butterscotch.  Nice sweet finish.  Great desert beer.
Pours dark brown with medium head.  Dark fruit aroma, medium complexity.  Rich and malty flavor.  Alcohol well hidden.  Some sweetness, but malt dominates.  A very good beer.

I was a little disappointed with the Optimator. My pour had a nice robust head and the dark carmelized color looked appealing. The taste was a little too contrived, for me it had a butterscotch flavor which was surprising.
Excellent beer! Pours great, dark color and tan head. Not much more I can say about it except, you must taste this beer!

Caramel color.  Dry fruity notes from the yeast, malt and alcohol.  Slight hop bitterness.  Not as rich and complex as Celebrator, but easier to drink.  This is a great standbye and easy to find.  Probably a top 5 doppelbock.

Bottle. Pours dark ruby-brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is sweet caramel, a little roast, and a few hops. Flavor is roasted malt, a bit sweet, and a little creamy, with some hops in there somewhere. Mouthfeel is thinner than expected, both given the look at the fact that it’s a doppelbock. A strange doppelbock really; almost like a more robust dunkel. Pretty good, though, and oddly almost a session beer despite its 7.2%.

Draught @ Flying Saucer Little Rock 5-2-07.  Deep reddish-brown, and opaque.  Faint hop aroma, mostly sweet nose.  Flavor has lots of caramel and sweet creaminess.  Hops are barely detectable.  Good, but when I compare this head to head with the Ayinger, it falls short big time.  Rerate after reading notes, numbers change only.

Draft at 6 feet under.  Deep brownish color with a minimal tan head.  Smotth and easy to drink.  Looks dark but not as thick as it looks, much more viscous.  The flavors are full bodied, slight fruit and roasted malt tastes.

50 cl bottle poured a dark translucent red, like a wine but with more brown. The head was a fine grained white leaving minimal lacing. Smells of alcohol and sugar, malt and prunes. Taste is prune-raisin with some caramel, malt and alcohol/liquer flavors. Flavor grew on me as it warmed, but still not as much depth here as I had hoped. Decent carbonation. Body is medium and a little slick. Finish feels a little salty and cottony with some alcohol fumes. Overall a good beer, but I prefer the Weihenstephaner Korbinian or Ayinger Celebrator over this.

Draft. Okay. Saw the Spaten tap in an old hotel bar. Ordered one, thinking it’d be their main pils. Instead I got something dark brown and delicious looking. Could this be Opitmator, I asked the waitress? "No, it’s Spaten Dark," she replied. "Oh," I said, thinking I’d hit a brand new beer. But no, there’s no such thing Spaten Dark, Spaten’s bock beers are all helles type, and I’m sure this is too dark and the wrong season for an Oktoberfest, it must be Optimator.Body is indeed doppelbock dark, under a brown creamy head. Dark rich malt flavor, accented by a slight yeast bite. Comes across as creamy, perhaps a touch oversweet, but then with a slight milky sourness. Nice heady hit of alcohol. Score one more for beer-ignorant bar servers.

Green bottle.....hmmmmm........says it’s a malt liquor on the label....hmmmm. This one actually tasted more like the Dunkle I just had, but not as good. I don’t think it holds a candle to the Ayinger Celebrator I had last week. That sh*t rocked my world!

500 ml pours almost opaque black-brown with red highlights. Small head quickly disappears. Aroma is malt and molasses with maybe some slight herb hop. Taste is malt syrup, some chocolate, slight bubblegum esters and some occasional cereal-corn. Alcohol and hops present in the dryer finish. Palate seems more medium than full, and is prickly with carbonation and alcohol. Pretty good, but not nearly as smooth (or tasty) as Celebrator.

super malt bomb. very mellow and rich. 
almost needs some hops to round it out.

Nice deep brown with ruby hues, think tan heaad. Very mild alcohol aroma. Taste is malty with a medim light mouth feel, no hops at all. a bit light for a dopple bock, much better are available but this is pretty good for a mass produced lager.

Very tasty, flavorful beer.  Wonderful combination of caramel/choco/roasted grains.  The molassas blends well.  Giving it a smooth ride on the tongue.  While it has a much lighter body than a stout/porter, no flavor is sacrificed.

Bottle from Isaac Newtons takeout. Ok I might have found a green bottled beer I actually like. Deep mahogany pour with thin off white head. Sweet aroma with a caramel malt finish. Surprisingly the taste was not too sweet but rather blended well with caramel and molasses. A well crafted brew.
Pours a deep dark color. Aroma of chocolate and caramel with nice roastiness. Taste is same.
If you like malty and dark, this is a great choice. Very enjoyable and easy to drink. For me Celebrator is a touch better, but happy to drink either at any time.

Bottle, Western New york at 21 hundred hours and 45 minutes. Eastern standard time zone. Weather Fair, Warm with a light north-west breeze. Sky clear with crescent moon next to an amazingly bright planet named Venus.. 

This lady is a sweet one. With legs that go all the way. Out of all the Spaten’s this one is pimpin it like Jacques-Yves Cousteau use to pimp the red sea. 

PEACE IN THE MIDDLE EAST ! ! !
Great deep amber poured out the bottle, this lays out some fat flavors on you - dark malts and sweet stuff balanced out by a bitter finish with a hit of alcohol.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Clear, orangey brown with a creamy, beige head. Sweetish aroma of burned caramel. Quite full-bodied with sweet, roasted malt, toffee and caramel with a very discreet bitterness. A lovely Bock. 050407
Bottled at Asterix Bar, São Paulo. Pours dakr brown with a tall brown head. Aroma is sweet with notes of hops and alcohol. Taste is also sweet, fruity. Roasted malt. Full body with lots of alcohol.
My favorite....  superior beer. Opaque and malty. Beautiful on tap, lovely from a bottle, best in a glass- in my hand!

Pours near black, smells of nailpolish and vinegar.  Deep roasted malt flavors with chocolate finish.  
[Need to rerate I know this is way better.]
Pours dark, dark brown.  Aroma is malt, taste is malt and some chocolate.  Very drinkable for a d-bock.
