Bottle - Dark red brew with decent head.  Average aroma of roasted malt and overripened fruit.  Flavors of malty fruit, bread, raisins, alcohol... hops finish.  I expected more from this, but it’s good.  I may re-rate later.
bottle: pours a clean deep red brown with a tan head . aroma of sweet malts. flavour is malty with just a touch of chocolate.  pretty new to this style not to bad though.
12 oz bottle  deep ruby pour ,decent head, no lace . sweet malt aroma with a touch of coffee . very smooth ,sweet malt flavor and chocolate notes with a mild  bitter finish . very good beer .

Bottle. Pours a dark chocolate color with an amber hue when held up to the light and a good amount of tan head. Aroma is malty. Body is thick and malty. Taste is malty with hints of chocolate and mild bitterness. I haven’t yet acquired a taste for dark, malty beers but this is pretty good and relatively mild.
This is my all time favorite beer. It is dark and mellow with aq hint of chocolate and a hint of that German "tang".  I love this stuff.  Perfect score.

Having this on draft at Bodega Brew Pub downtown La Crosse, Wisconsin USA. Old standard of classic Bavarian dopplebock. Noticed an odd somewhat salty flavor here. Dark rich sweetness of course also. Very drinkable, but not quite as I recall from before. Clean finish.

Dark with tan head.  Although its translucent there’s good body to the taste.  Malt flavor is apparent and a subtle bitter - the combination makes for a smooth taste that doesn’t hang in your mouth. Just a great well rounded flavor. Chocolate on the tail end.  Great with a hearty meal.

I have since tried the celebrator, and it does have a superior palate (the carbonation is fantastic) but this is a good cheaper alternative.

A good dopplebock, but not quite as malty and flavorful as Ayinger Celebrator or Weltenburger Kloster Asum Bock.  Just had on tap at Lachet’s in Chicago, properly served in the dimpled mug.  Seems to be pretty readily available for a dopplebock-- some can be hard to find on tap.
Malty aroma.  Dark colour with a tan head.  Full bodied and smooth.  Bittery finish with a sweetish smack.
Very sweet beer. Has a nice smoothness to it. It just shoots right down your throat easily.  Cannot taste the Alcohol content, very well hidden.

When it comes time to take a step back a couple years and relive my humble beer nerd beginnings, I can always count on the Optimator to remind me that those weren’t always bad times.  Dark, inviting, smooth and packs a gentle wallop.  Super easy to quaff down which also helps me remember that night I nearly cracked my skull open on the fireplace after a few too many of these.

Best out of all the Spatens i have had. The beer is excellent. Pours very dark with aromas of coffee and caramel. Especially delicious for the ABV%. Makes you wonder why an American Macrobrewery cant put something like this out. Everyone should try at least once!

Great beer for the price, full of flavor and nice alcohol content. First tried this at the Rendevouz in St. Augustine after some really strong belgium ales so I wanted to try Optimator by itself.  I am a relative (relative to high quality beer) beer novice but for now Optimator is in my top 10.
One of my favorite German macros.  Dark brown pour with no head.  Sweet and strong, this one is my favorite pairing at my local German restaurant.

Ótima cerveja escura. As Spaten me surpreenderam. Espuma de boa formação, densa e coloração caramelada; Cor vinho escuro avermelhado, muito bonita. Cheiro gostoso de malte torrado. O gosto é de malte torrado, encorpada, densa, cremosa e suave. Graduação forte. Muito boa.

Draft.  Pours very dark brown with red highlights and a small, quickly disappearing head.  Sweet, malty aroma with caramel and chocolate.  Flavor is sweet malts with burnt, sweet chocolate finish.  A nice beer.

pours clear dark brown with a big loose quickly disappearing tan head. aroma.......hmmmm.....smells more like heineken than a doppelbock......really crappy weak heineken hop aroma and not much else......well a hint of dark malt but it doesnt make up for anything. flavor fairly balanced but the flavors are just no good. sweet caramel malt with some dry grassy bitter hops. medium dry bitter spicy mustard green finish with some caramel malt. medium body.....kinda fizzy.....i mean if you swirl it it fizzes as you smell it......thats almost never good. i dont have much experience with the style but this is not what i am looking for when i pick up a doppelbock.....or a beer in general. not a drain pour but man.....i expected a lot more.......basically drinkable......but only once.

Bottle code L08961Y.  An aggressive pour into a brandy snifter yielded a healthy 3-finger, creamy tan, persistent head.  Color is a crystal-clear dark brown.  The lasting aroma is of delicious toasted malts with a touch of dark fruitiness.  I could sit here and just enjoy the aroma of this beer.  The mouth-feel is rich and creamy, with just the right amount of body.  The flavor and finish are dominated by sweet malts.  I can pick up none of the alcohol notes that others describe.  

The good but not stellar comments about this doppelbock are piquing my interest in exploring other top examples of this style further.

On tap, pours a clear dark brown with a minimal white whispy head, minimal lacing.  Aroma of sweet malts, with some nuts, light coffee, bread and caramel.  A sweeter medium taste with low carbonation.  A decent malty diversion from a world of hops, though a touch sweeter than preferred.
Pours a cola brown with a thin tan head that disapears quick. Aroma of roasted malt. Tastes of roasted malt, coffee, light carbination. Rich. This is a very nice Doppel!

Coloração preta avermelhada. Creme bege, bom, mas não tão persitente. Notas de malte torrado, chocolate amargo, café e nozes. Fica um leve amargor no paladar, mas falta-lhe corpo. Carbonatação baixa, muito boa. Álcool não perceptível. Antes eu achava essa cerveja excelente. Mas, após me acostumar com as belgas, ela passou a ser apenas uma boa cerveja.
You can’t go wrong with Spaten’s Optimator. It pours with a wonderful dark brown color. Relatively sweet with hints of caramel. Definitely a tasty beer.
Beer poured with a small thick light brown head. Very dark brown with a reddish hue. Lots of aroma and flavor especially the malts.

Dark brown color, with a frothy tan-colored head, sweet toasted and caramelized malt nose, with a toffeeish accent, a faint malt smokiness, brown sugar, hint of dark dried fruits fruitiness in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a very sweet toasted malt character, with some caramel, biscuity and toffeeish notes, with some brown sugar, hint of nuttiness, dried raisins and plums fruitiness, leading towards a rich malty finish.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a mug, deep reddish amber with a medium tan head. Aroma is very light and of sweet malt. Taste is of sweet malt and maybe some dark fruits. The alcohol comes through a bit after a few sips. This one is on par with Moretti La Rossa, but I think both trail Paulaner Salvator. Now if I were younger, like back in my college days in Madison, Wisconsin, I would buy a six pack of each, lock myself in a room and settle the matter. But unfortunately I have to work these days and can’t afford those three-day hangovers anymore. (Ohhh, to be young and crazy again.)

Pours clear dark brown with a frothy light brown head.  Aroma is of cookies and straw, with leather, horseblanket and broth esters.  Flavor is sweet throughout, carmel with an average finish.  Light to medium bodied, watery and softly carbonated.... Bock Lite!

The Optimator is the beast of Spaten.  A strong alcohol volume for Spaten and a darker finish.  It almost tastes like a barley wine as it doesn’t produce a large head.  Still, it’s a strong dark German beer with a good flavor.

2nd chance at this well-made dopplebock and what a difference  a few hundred beers and a warmer beer make.
One of the hardest things for an American beer drinker to do when he starts sampling good beer, is to drink it at the recommended temperature.  It’s just too many years of nearly frozen crappy pale lagers in frozen mugs that have caused me to try this ’warmer’ bock at the wrong temp and too early.
My recomendation?  Make this your 2nd beer of the day and drink it between 55-58 degrees Fahrenheit.
If you do, the beverage will mellow and the alcohol will be hidden by the malt and sweet flavors.  Very nice!
Amber-brown with tan head. Fruit alcohol aroma. Subtle roasted-cream  taste, just a little rough on the pallet.

Sampled mainly in bottle and found on draft in Tucson once. A great beer. Pours dark brown and with a thick head. Taste is tremendous with heavy hops and roasted spices for proper flavor. Highly recommended.

Deep, dark, and delectable is this beloved German beer that I keep gravitating back toward whenever I fret about American lagers.  Subtle burnt sweetness that explores the taste buds on each tasting. I firmly believe this to be one of the most consistently quaffable brews of all time.

Black, but not cloudy coloration as stouts. Dense and persistent cream. Aroma with strong presence of malt and nuts. In the palate, dry carbonation in the measure for sensations of red fruits, nuts and fruits. It goes down MADE VELVETY, leaving a good aftertaste of caramel and toasted coffee. ........................................................PORTUGUÊS: Coloração preta, mas não opaca como as stouts. Creme denso e persistente.
Aroma com forte presença de malte e nozes.
No paladar, carbonatação na medida para sensações de frutas vermelhas, nozes e frutas secas.
Desce AVELUDADA, deixando um retrogosto delicioso de caramelo e café torrado.

11.2 oz bottle. Dark, reddish tinged brown with a slight tan head. Lots of sweet, roasted malt in the nose, toffee and light berry. Quite a bit of carbonation. Sweet roasted malt flavor, a touch of nutty bitterness. The alcohol makes an appearance toward the end, but is not at all detracting. Very good!

This beer pours a very deep brown with a thin tan head.  Notes of chocolate, raisins and coffee in the smell as well as the taste.  This is a VERY good beer (especially for the price).  Go get one and enjoy it!  Cheers!
Optimator pours a dark brown with almost no head. It hides it’s 7.2% a lot better than Arrogant Bastards 7.2%. This was pretty tasty but not as good as Salvator.

Poured from a bottle it looks almost black.  Aroma has scents of coffee and does not hide its 7.2% abv well.  The taste, however, does.  It’s flavor is sweet with hints of chocolate coming through.  Fairly smooth and creamy on the palate.  This is a fantastic beer.

On tap at Old Chicago.  Pours a deep ruby red with two finger head.  One of my all time favorites.  Rich malt and caramel notes hit the nose and call for a taste.  Malt, caramel, raisins, plums, a hint of chocolate.  This beer has it all in my book.  BREW!!!
Reddish brown.  Strong malt character that I could not place exactly.  Prehaps a fig-like fruittyness.  One time experience for me.

Bottle.  Dark garnet, almost brown.  Light tan head that fades very quickly leaving no lace.  sweet, roasted malt and fruit aroma.  Sweet, roasted flavor.  Licorice, raisins, chocolate plums.  A bit on the sweet side.  Not the best Dopplebock out there but pretty solid and easy to find.

Pours out very dark amber with a full bodied malted aroma.  Medium beige foam head which dissipated quickly.  Caramel malted flavor with a somewhat harsh sour finish.  Burn from alcohol is present but tolerable.  Sorry, not very impressed with this doppelbock from our friends in Germany.  An OK beer, but its not for me, thanks.

Bottle at the Happy Gnome.  Pours out to a clear, rubyish shade of mahogany.  Strong aroma of raisin, cinnamon, and fig.  Slight afterburn of alcohol.  Heavy sweet malts define this: caramelized sugar, cinnamon toast, with a lingering sour fruit finish.  I dig the malts but not the huge sweetness.
delicious, the smell is faint, you can taste fruits, and chocolate, there is a sweet aftertaste, does not taste like there is 7.2%

Pours a translucent brown with a substantial head and nice lacing.  The nose is toasted and slightly sweet.  The flavor fills your mouth with nuttiness and a touch of caramel, brown sugar and fruit.  Finishes with a touch of sweetness and begs you to drink more. Not what it once was, but still a decent beer.

Another one of those beers I had just never gotten around to rating.  Thanks to the in-laws for this!  Deep garnet, decent head fades slowly.  Rich aroma of bread and molasses.  Flavor is deep and rich, with bread, molasses, toffee, and walnuts.  The faintest tang of roasted malt on the finish.  This isn’t my favorite style, but this really is a well done beer.

(Tap) Pours a nice brown color with a beige colored head. Sweet malty aroma, with the taste being much of the same. Medium body, with a pretty good mouthfeel. Slightly nutty, with sweet toffee in the aftertaste. An enjoyable brew!

Tonite, as we speak, I am having the wonderful moment of my first taste of Optimator from a bottle! I had enjoyed this beer immensely from a draught tapper in our local German bar. It goes for $4.50 a pint, but was worth every penny when the alternatives were Bud Light and Miller Lite! Then my wife found 12 pack for $11.75 at our local supermarket liqour department. What an excellent surprise. I love the heavy malt aroma and strong but smoothly lingering finish. It is truly a beer to sip and savor.
It is like cuban espresso compared to Maxwell house drip blend. I’d like to hear more about the Celebrator. This is a fine way to enjoy an evening!

Brown color with a reddish tint.  Malty aroma with notes of roasty-nutty grains.  Taste is sweet and smooth with a nice malty flavor.  Bits of fruit mixed in as well as some caramel.  Very smooth beer with a clean finish.  Overall, a very good D-bock.

Clear reddish brown pour with a thick, frothy, offwhite head. Interesting aroma of pilsner malts and dark fruits. Good flavor of rich malt, dark fruits and a sweetness akin to brown sugar. The body is light to medium with a creamy texture and moderate carbonation. A good, solid, doppelbock.
This beer is just about the best bang for the buck!! i pay $10.99 a 12 pack!! in Georgia of all places.... i Love it and buy it all year round!!

Pours a ruddy brown with a thick head of tan foam. Great head retention and lacing. Sweet plummy malt aroma.

Tasty and malty, with lots of sweet flavors including caramel, toffee, and plum. But given all that, the beer is not overly sweet. In fact it is just right. A mildly spicy hop character in the finish. Clean tasting, full bodied, and lightly caronated.
Bottle. Roasted malt aroma, a hint of cherry maybe. Flavor is malty, brown sugar, dark fruit, nutty. Excellent. Celebrator is better though.

The first scent that reaches your nose from the bottle is of something roasted.  This permeates to the flavor--malty, brown sugar, toffee.  Also has a fruitiness (apples?) to it.  Very thick, off-white head; darker than expected mahogany appearance.  Full-bodied, great on the tongue (during and after), and, overall, delicious.  The only negative thing that I COULD say about it:  not the most complex beer; however, it far exceeded my expectations and is now one of my favorite brews.  Highly recommended.
bottle.  clear deep brown color, little to now head.  Malty flavor, very nice on the palate, high alcohol content, also very good out of the keg.

Bottle.  Clear mahogany color with a mostly lasting frothy tan head.  Malty aromas of sweet cereal or bran muffins, granola, brown sugar, with a few grass and straw notes as well.  Sweet and malty cereal flavors with a barky, almost smoky finish presumably from dark roasted malt.  Medium to full bodied.  Sugary, kind of sticky palate.  Cloying for my taste.  Reminds me again of why I’m not a huge bock fan.

I may have to make doppelbock my new favourite style. I love these beers! The malt in this beer is awesome-- chewy, sweet, bready, delicious. Not nearly as complex as Celebrator, but still an excellent beer.

1 pint & 9 floz bottle.Pours a dark brown with a medium-sized light tan head, which quickly settles into a skinny film on top which lingers. Pleasant malty/fruity aroma with hints of toffee, apple, and roast. Great smooth, almost thick, mouth-feel. Fruity taste. I can’t quite make it out but the closest thing I can think of is apple, just slightly. Lots of malty goodness. Finishes with a small "roastiness". Complex, well balanced, and satisfying.
Cloudy dark brown color with limited head.  Tastes very smooth, with a wheat-y malt flavor.  Slightly sweet.  An excellent Doppel Bock.

Bought a bottle at Martignetti’s in Brighton. Caramel-like smell. Dark color but not opaque. Cloudy with stuff floating in it. Smooth, caramel taste. Very sweet. Now the all-time favorite of one of the reviewers.
This was my first double bock. It poured dark, with no head to speak of. Had a spicy taste and an oily mouthfeel.
On tap at the BierStube in Moline.  Dark pour, no head.  Somewhat thin on the palate.  Some smokey, sweet characteristics.  Decent doppelbock, I’d like to try this at home, away from a smoky bar.
Bottle.  Dark bronw color, no lacing, sweet aroma of toffee, malt.  Oily mouthfeel, a little toffee and spice in the taste.

Had this many o times but never rated it. Picked up a 6’er the other day. Pours out a light brown color with a small lacing head. Nice sweet aroma. Taste is complex with some notes of caramel, fruit and some toasty notes and a slight lingering bitterness. A solid beer.
Caramel, dopplebocky goodness.  Dark fruits, caramel, and rasin. Fantastic beer.

Dark brown (like a very dark version of walnut) with an ever so slightly tan head. The head disappears slowly on it’s own. Smells woody, not unlike Sierra Nevada’s Bigfoot barley wine. It’s got a light taste and full body with little carbonation I can detect. It’s hard to describe the taste though. It’s balanced and it hides the extra alcohol well. It’s got some sweetness and breadyness to it. Like a sweet biscuit. I loved it.

Draught at Richmond Arms, Houston
Dark brown color. Strong caramel aroma and taste; the mouthfeel is thick enough and oily. Ends with a nutty strong bitterness.

Pours a clear deep reddish mahogany with a thin tan head.  Sweet malty aroma with hints of honey, apples, vanilla and a little bit of smoke.  Decidedly malty flavor with molasses, caramel and some dried fruit.  Very little hop presence but the imbalance is appropriate for the style.  Long sweet finish.
Oh yeah!  A cure for rhumatoid arthritis. Please see Lindanova comments, pretty much says it all I have nothing new to offer. The three went well with the traditional Crhistmas meal.

Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a clear brilliant garnet color with permanent light tan colored bubbles around the edges and a micro layer of bubbles that swirl about and change like clouds.   Aroma is of rich roasted malts and mild earthy hops with subtle sweet notes and some alcohol.  Taste is of rich roasted malts and mild earthy hops, well blended with the distinct taste of honey.  Smooth, medium to full bodied with ample carbonation.   A warm, mildly sweet ending with some earth notes.

Bottle into stem glass - An interesting, big flavor, dark lager with a surprising punch...no head...a little skunky...some spiciness. Definitely an acquired taste. The best thing about this beer is its potency...
Dark honey coloring with a tan head. A roasted, spicy flavor with a medium mouthfeel.
Dark amber color.  Very thick head, big bubbles, lasts a long time.  Light aroma.  Heavy on the alcohol, but drinkable.  Strong whiskey-like flavor...more like a hoppy shot of JD than a beer.

Sweeeet, Maaaalty, well-balanced with tastes of caramel, roasted fruit (apples I think), hops, and coffee.  There are many comments that this beer is overpowering, but I did not experience it.  I found the smell, flavors, and finish moderate to strong.  For a widely available doppelbock, this is a good one.
12oz - Mostly lifeless caramel colored liquid supporting light tan head.  Grassy notes, slightly smoky and overwhelmingly greasy.  NFG.  This one I do not understand the passion people have for it.

Any true beer lover can’t help but love this beer ! It has a refreshingly unique flavor that is not for the uniniated ! If you are the kind of beer drinker that is happy with typical commercial beers than SPATEN is not for you, and it goes without saying that the OPTIMATOR will knock you on your a** !( at 7.2% alcohol). I quickly tired of all of those empty bottles accummulating around the house waiting to be returned for the deposit refund so, I went ahead and purchased a dual tap kegerator and stocked it with SPATEN OPTIMATOR and FRANZISKANER (less of an alcohol punch) ! Ah the good life !
Enjoyable but with an overpowering taste that finds you struggling to finish it
Although this is my favorite German beer, I prefer beers from other countries.  The beer is strong and the taste borders on overpowering.  You can taste the alcohol, unfortunately.

ReRate:  I recently tried one of these guys again after some time and I looked back at my notes and was surprised.  Maybe I had something odd to eat that night.  For aroma this beer is full of dark fruits and syrup.  It pours into the glass a deep ruby/plum colour with a small head.  There is a nice fruity, malty backbone to this brew with some warm alcohol finishing.  Overall it’s a real nice beer and deserves a better rating than my previous one.

Pours a very deep dark amber color with a nice thick head.  Smell is sweet and malty.  The taste is the same, very malty, very sweet, and you can taste a litlle bit of alchohol from the 7.2 but it adds just a touch of something to the beer.  Not quite a Celabrator, but definitiely a great well priced alternative.

Bottle from Hy-Vee Liquors poured into dimpled mug - Pours dark brown with a huge 3.5 finger brown head that lasts; Wheat, caramel, malt, dried fruit, a slight roast note to the nose; Coffee, caramel, apple, banana, roasted malt just a nice hop character on the initial taste; Roasted malt, dried fruit backtaste; Watery to medium palate; Little carbonation; First doppelbock and it’s not bad at all! I could’ve done with a little more body, but overall, very well done.
Had this beauty on tap at the Yard House.  Deep red in color with a cream thin head.  Rich full malty flavor with little bite considering the alcohol involved.  Nice cool weather beer!

.5L bottle  Reddish-brown in color with a big beige fluffy foam head.  Aroma of mixed berries, malt, roasted malt, and toffee.  Flavors of rich malt.  Very balanced.  Not sure why the scores of this beer are not higher.

Very dark but clear red-mahogany.  Head is a bit small and short lived.

Sweet nose of gingerbread, with faint roasted tones as well.

Flavors are less concentrated, simpler, and drier  than the aromas.  Body is on the lighter side of medium, with a low level of carbonation.  Finishes fruity, then slightly bitter on the aftertaste.  Alcohol is hardly detectable.

Promises more on the nose than it delivers in the mouth, but still enjoyable for its easy appeal and drinkability, not to mention its low cost.

figgy.  molasses, pistachio.  other strange things that you don’t expect in a beer.  interesting, novel, and satisfying.  i’d probably never buy it, but that doesn’t mean it’s a bad beer.  just a little too malty for me.  3.6 . Rerate: i had this the first time in a 4oz sample at a beer tasting without notes.  so now i’ll do it for real.  pretty deep burgundy color, elegant tiny bubbles coursing sides. head dissipates to a thin film.  aroma is clear lagered dopplebock.  like some weird eastern european pistachio/rosepetal mashup. a bit lightbodied, but flavor is strong and unwavering.  not terribly complex, which probably is why other dopples are higher, but pretty solid. great at maybe 55 degrees.  ended up raising appearance by 2 and flavor by 1 and overall by 1, and lowering palate by 2

Pours clear, dark amber with a cream-colored, mostly full, pillowy head which is somewhat lasting and leaving sporatic lacing.  Nose is dark fruit, toffee, and a little smoke.  Flavor is toasted malt, buttery toffee, fruitiness, and a moderate noble hop balance. Palate is medium , creamy/oily, and moderate carbonation.  Finish is a little abrupt and kind of metallic and fruity.  Overall, not a bad dopple but just not spectacular like Ayinger.  The flavors are all nice but just don’t meld well.  Decent.

Awesome doppelbock! I’m not too familiar with the style, but each time I try one ask myself why. Very dark brown pour that, to my suprise, was not too thick. Sweet with a lot of different fruits and spices coming to mind. Leaves you wanting more.

I was suprised as to how good this beer is. Its strong, but the alcohol is well hidden. Its very drinkable. Sweet but not too sweet. Has body but isn’t thick or syrupy. Very good, well balanced beer.
Thumbs way up. Go buy it. Its cheap too.
Bottle. Great Dopplebock. Sweet, but not cloying. Very dark. Strong and you can tell.
Malty sugary sweet ambery greatness.  Exactly what I want when craving a sweet brown ale or anything like it.  Maltiness that will make any level of beer drinker happy.  One of my favorites.

Pours a beautiful dark amber color with a nice tan head.  Sweet aroma.  Sweet & buttery initially that rolls into a solid bit of hoppiness.  Finishes with a fruit and nut flavor.  I started this out too cold, but it really livened up as it came up in temp.

Surprisingly fruity armoa with some dried fruit but also some fresh lemony apple which contrasts a persistant, melanoidiny grain smell.  Pours a crystal clear ruddy brown with covering of tawny foam that dissipates to some wisps.  Ascertive spicy melanoidins comingling with sweet malt and a good punch of German hops that provide an appropriate level of bitterness.  An almost peppery note comes off the toasty malt and fades to hints of dried fruit that is less prominent than the aroma would have predicted.  Medium body, moderate carbonation, a bit sticky sweet but not off balanced.

Bottled.  Mmmm....really nice. Quite a complex aroma. Some banana type esters and wheaty smell, but then you get a lovely treacle note coming through with some dark fruit and a little smoke. The flavour is is buttery smooth with some chocolate, treacle and loads of fruit too. only a touch of hoppy bitterness but the treacle sweetness lingers for a while. Beautifully balanced beer, fantastic taste and palate.

I discovered this beer at Epcot on New Years Eve day.  The maiden handed me my drink and the effervescence tempted my palate to relish the chocolate rasberry taste with a smokin’ finish.  It made my brautwurst taste even better!  It was magical.

Its that time of year to warm up to a good old bottle of dis.  Small head, with a sweet malty backbone.  This is a roasty and very pleasant doppel.  The smell is strong and the flavor is big and tasty.  Another great beer form a great beer making city.

Pour is a very dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma is nutty, malty and bready.  Flavor is nice.  A mix of chocolate and dark fruits.  Alcohol comes in on the finish and leaves a smoky aftertaste.  A very decent example of the style.  Now why did it take me so long to rate this?

The first thing I noticed about this beer, other than the wonderful Dark Chocolate look, was the strong, almost wooden aftertaste, like chewing on a Walnut log.  It has good initial flavor, like a fermented bottle of nuts, but it’s that aftertaste that grabbed me.  I had it too cold, but as time wore on, the beer livened up as it warmed up.  Not particularly thick to the tongue, and perhaps too much carbonation for me, but at least the carbonation was lass of a factor as the beer waned.  To sum up, if you see a six pack of this, and want a good general dark beer, pick it up.  Good nut flavor with excellent wood aftertaste, but let it warm up a little.
This is one of my favorite dark beers from all of Europe.  It has a sweet smell and taste to it, and boasts an alcohol content of just over 7%.  Good stuff.

This is an ok german dark beer. Its flavor has got a good bitterness with a unique kick, a good beer thats smell is sweet and saucy, The 7.2 is not noticable at all, good ole germany! average at its pinnacle...on tap i am sure it is alot better!

Deep amber/brown color, and a light tan head. Some lacing. Sweet, toffee aroma, and a sweet, roasted nut flavor. As others have written, raisin can be detected, too, and molasses in the aftertaste. Lighter, and more carbonated than other Doppels I’ve had.

Bottle. Pours a dark golden brown with a moderate foamy head. Aromas of caramel, dark roasted malt, raisins, nuts. Taste: has a biting hoppiness to it at first but moves into a smooth, thick, malty finish. Molasses aftertaste.
Bottle, pours with tan, medium and lasting head, dark brown.  Full on flavor, yet not too thick.  Chocolate, caramel flavoring.

Bottle.  Pours a clean mahagony with a small fizzy and bubbly tan head, edgy, with some spotty lacing.  Aroma is roasted nuts and caramel malt (cookie, biscuit) and yeast (warm bread) with notes of sweet chocolate and raisins.  Medium acidity and bitterness provided by the hops dancing on your tongue, medium sweetness, caramel roasted nutty malt and bready yeast, chewey with some hints of alcohol.  Medium to full bodied, fizzy and spicy palate.

very similar to a Salvator by Paulaner, rich munich malt aroma with no hop aroma. Some toasty bread melanoidins. Not at all burnt or acidic from dark malts, darkness must come from extended boil. Flavor is like the aroma rich maltiness from munich malts, slight fruitiness of plum raisin and grape, slightly sweet due to lack of hops, which is good for this type of brew. Poured a dark ruby to dark brown with garnet highlights.
Nutty, complex flavor. Full-bodied, but not sickeningly thick. Nice balance between the malt and the hops although definitely on the sweeter side.

Bottle. Dark brown color with reddish highlights, light tan head. Very tasty dopple / dunkel.  Rich nutty flavor - very malty and sweet.  Blanced and smooth.  Very easy to drink.  An excellent and accessible brew.

Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is rich, malty, nutty and slightly chocolatey. Viscous and syrupy mouthfeel. Caramel like maltyness with a roasty nuttyness and a later almondy dryness. Not a great doppelbock, however I tend to rate them harshly.
Nice heavy and dark. Full bodied doppel pours dark brown with a tannish head. Smells malty, toffee and of alcohol. Very strong malty and roasted flvor followed by alcohol. My favorite Spaten beer.

Poured a deep, dark brown with a nice tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, brown sugar and coffee. Rich malt flavor accented by chocolate and maybe a hint of dried fruit. A hop presence leaves a dry and lightly bitter finish. Full bodied brew with a good mouthy feel.

500 ML Bottle.  Poured a nice dark brown with a long lastime medium tan head.  Nose of roasted malts, with some coffee and carmel.  Good mouthfeel, and flavor of chocolate showing through.  Very good finish.  Excellent import.

Poors nice and dark, but not opaque dark brown or black.  I was hoping optimator would optimate my tasting session. What I mean by that is; no bitter finish.  After tasting Salvator, Pious munk and Sweet wheat love, I was hoping for a smooth aftertaste that was not offensive.  This has a bitter aftertaste typical of ruff dopplebocks, but not like a stout.  Finish is OK but not optimizing.

Poured rich amber color.  Aroma of alcohol and carmel(brown sugar?).  Not as much head as a German Pils.  Flavor of mellow carmel, slight raisiny character, and alcohol.  Hops are there, but not intrusive.  You know that aclohol is there, but it isn’t overpowering considering that it is 7.2% abv.  One of my favorite amber colored beers.  If you are a fan of Oktoberfest/Maerzen give this a try.  It’ll change your perspective.  At US$ 10.99/12-12oz bottles (same price as most German/Czech/Aussie/Mexican lagers) it’s a bargain.  Have a few and become one with the recliner.

Cloudy dark brown with light brown head. Aroma is cherries and some dark fruit, raisins. Flavor is roasted coffee, with a hint of chocolate. Very bitter, big warmth hits immediately, nice alcohol burning sensation all the way down. Mild bitter aftertaste.

Bottle.  This beer was a dark ruby red pour, not opaque, and had a huge tan head, but which shrank to a thin film.  Sweet aroma of dark fruit.  Flavor of fruit again, specifically cherries, bread, some toffee in there I think, but flavor is not as sweet as the aroma would have you believe.  Medium body.  Warming alcohol in the finish.  Overall, too much flavor for me.  Needed some roast to balance it out.

Tipical doppel-bock appearence, off-white head with no longevity at all, very dark caramel color, almost no visible gas.
Also tipical is the strong body and a complex sweet aroma. Most-obvious touchs are of caramel and toffee. The taste is even stronger and although sweet, not as much as the aroma is. When drinking the rich mouthfull feeling reveals nuts and raisins. The body is very dense, a coffee biterness stay on the tongue, but with all its complexity, totally diferent from a dunkel or irish dark beer for example. Maybe too sweet for some ocasions, but still a very enjoyable strong beer. I had difficulties for feeling the alcohol on the taste (despite of its 7,2% ABV), what can be good for many people and for many ocasions even for me. Maybe not the number one, but still fantastic!!!
Damn tasty beer.  Dark and rich with a gentle bitterness.  Not so rich that you can’t pound it down though.  So good and so drinkable.

Draft.  Aroma:  Light nutiness and vinousness, raisins, and sweet maltiness.  Appearance:  Deep brown with a small medium beige head.  Nice lacing.  Flavor:  Big, sweet maltiness with caramle and a touch of molasses.  Toasted nuts, raisins.  A little hop bite helps edge out most of the sweetness.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Overall:  Really enjoyed this one.  Good, rich flavors but still drinkable in mass quantities.

Pour mahogany brown with a dark tan head.  The aroma is dark toffee, doughy, raisins and dark malt earthiness.  Medium thick body with soft carbonation.  It is smooth and slick with a slightly warm finish.  Flavor starts with earthy toffee, brown sugar, smooth roasted malt and dark caramel.  The finish adds an alcohol kick along with a dry caramel taste.  Nice beer.

This is my favorite Daily beer.          
My local store sells it for $12.99 a 12pack.
Cant beat that value.

Right up in your face flavors. First impression is heavy on malt and reminds of ale. A licoricy note is there and one expects but never quite gets any bitterness. On the whole a stongly flavored yet balanced brew.

A very dark brown with dark red highlights and a frothy white head that lasts well.  In the nose I get loads of caramel and sweetness, with a bit of dark fruit.  Taste is much the same:  sweetness but not overly so, and surprisingly there was no detection of alcohol notes whatsoever.  On the tongue this borders on syrupy but straddles the line well:  a lack of carbonation is offset by a smooth drinkability.

12 oz bottle from trader joe’s.  i’ve had it on tap and thought it was really bready and full of flavor, but this bottle really left me feeling like a full sail LTD 1 dunkel would’ve been more satisfying.  sweet dark lager flavor, alcohol well hidden at least.  medium thin mouthfeel but very nice carbonation.  sort of one dimensional.  by no means bad but i don’t believe it deserves such a high score, even if "dopplebock" is fun to say and makes you feel snobby.  i’ll have to try it on tap again before i know if this whole thing is just a case of the green bottle blues, but i’m going with my gut for now.

Bottled in a pint glass. Germans give good head. The head on this was thick, rich and off-white. Dark reddish-brown, no carbonation to note. Sweet, carmely nose and flavor. A hit of anise on aftertaste. Good stuff.
Had the beer at a friends. Not bad, a little too much flavor. I am more of a pale lager drinker.

tap at the Yard House - Pours reddish-brown with billowy head.  It has an very malty aroma.  The flavor is mostly of caramel malt with some toffee notes in there and a hint of alcohol.  It’s full bodied, but easy enough to drink.  Good stuff.

On tap at Barca on Capitol Hill in Seattle (have also had in the bottle before) into and English Pint glass.  Pours an amber reddish brown with a thin off-white to tan head.  Aroma brings a lot of sweet carmalized malts and apples to the nose.  The flavor is incredibly smooth with a lot of hints of the nose - heavy carmalized malts tossed around with apples and sugar.  A toffee and raisin hint kicks in during the body which moves into a lightly alcohol finish.  Medium bodied to syrupy.  Was really not roasty at all, for a doppelbock, or for how the market it.  This is one of those solid drinking beers for whenever you need something easy and dependable.  Probably Spaten’s best.
Dark brownish red in the glass. Nose of dark roasted malts and carmel sugar. Good carbonation. Nice rich malty flavor with pleasant, subtle alcohol warmth. Love this stuff!!!
Had this a little while ago on draft.  I remember it had dark appearance to it and it had nice palatable taste.
Pours dark brown, reddish when held to light. Strong alcoholic smell. Light carbonation, little head. Smooth, faint taste of alcohol. Dominating malt, no hops detectable.

Poured to a dark brown with hints of ruby red, thick tan/off-white head that lingered and then reduced to decent lacing. Aroma was mild, but noticeable malty sweetness, with a combination of dark fruit and hint of nutsty toffee. Taste was pleasant, and not overly sweet. Had a nice, smooth finish, although I was a little surprised that the alcohol never made itself known in either the smell or taste.

Modest off-white head on top of a dark reddish-amber (nearly black) color.  Fairly light, predominantly sweet malty aroma with a hint of raisins and hops.  Sweet, malty flavors with hints of dried frutis (mainly raisins), a surprisingly dry/hoppy finish for this style of beer.  Not too sweet, not syrupy, pretty much perfectly balanced.  The flavors were great, but I just wanted more intensity.  Still, a prime choice and reasonably priced.
Reddish brown with a huge light brown head. Slightly carbonated with a distinctive rasiny aroma. Rough mouth feel with a malty sweet taste and aftertaste.

Bottle pours a nice clear lusterous mahogany.  Medium sized tan head but the lacing is spoty and coarse.   Aroma is of chocolate malts, leather, brown sugar and vanilla. Flavor is more of a slightly bitter woody taste but with enough sweetness to even it out.  Some coffee notes and earthy lightly roasted malts as well.  Fine light carbonation and a slightly metalic finish with the alcohol showing through a bit.   Medium bodied.  A good example of one of my favorite styles.
Sweet is the main flavor. Pretty red brown color. I enjoy their Oktoberfest---but wouldn’t buy this again.
Dark ruby red color with a fluffy head with a sweet yeasty aroma. Strong malt flavor with just a hint of coffee, mollasses and toffee. Sweet and heavy palate. A fantastic beer.
Dark reddish brown with some lacing on the head. Mild fruit with large amounts of sweet malt on the nose. Malt is strong on the flavor, with some light hops and medium bodied weight.

450th German.  Green bottle - ugh!  Nice double spade, at least.  Aroma is sweet, syrupy, sugary bock maltiness.  Light fruitiness.  Have to give it due, it’s potent.  Pours a rich dark ruby with a short, lacing tan head.  Strong visible carbonation.  Tastes mostly malty, though not syrupy as expected, with grape, red berry, and a little grit.  Crisp, medium-full bodied but finishes somewhat lighter.  Toffee and brown sugar in the dry aftertaste.  Could use additional hoppy bitterness to balance the malty sweetness, and even a little more body, but, hey now, this is still one of the better in style.  It’s not on the level of the Andechser or the Ayinger (nowhere near as complex), probably closer to the Triumphator and the Salvator.  [2006.08.28: 3.7]  

Green glass again, relatively fresh bottles in this sixer, marked 03.2020.  Beautiful deep malt nose with heaps of melanoidin and a little bouillon, hint of wood and woodsy, some fine roast and faint chocolate, red berry background.  Great nose!  Tawny pour out of the bottle and a jiggling off-tan head.  More of the same maltiness, less berry, much more toffee with a slight nutty element; low bitterness with no astringency but a rather abrupt finish, flattish there, but dry and matches the malt profile.  Fullish body, medium-heavy, hint airy but mostly average carbonation, some cola sour/ashy character in the finish.  Still really like this one as the days start to cool down.  [2019.08.31: 3.7]

Color is dark amber with near-white head. Aroma is faint - some malt, some fruit, mostly yeasty. Flavor is a balance of malts, spicey hops, alcohol, and hints of something sour (not objectionably sour - perhaps not the freshest sample). Also slightly roasted, almost savory, flavors.  The beer feels cloying between the middle and the finish, but finally finishes somewhat dry. The body is heavily carbonated (even after a vigorous pour to release most of it).

Re-rate 1/4/2008: 50cl bottle. Poured a deep, clear, dark brown with amber/red highlights and a medium-sized tan head. The aroma was bready and very sweet with malts. There were also hints of caramel-covered fruit in the aroma. The flavor followed the aroma: very sweet and malty, very light level of bittering hops, and unexpectedly fruity. The fruit character really made the beer taste almost like a strong, malty, brown ale - but it was not objectionable, just unexpected from a German lager bier. The mouthful is full-bodied and well-carbonated. The carbonation was high enough to feel spritzy on the tip of the tongue, but creamy towards the middle and back of the palate. Overall, a more pleasant experience that I remember from last time (previous rating was a total score of 3.3 - Aroma, Palate, and Overall Impression each received an extra point, resulting in a new total of 3.6).
The Price and the flavor make this probably my favorite beer. I find myself craving it at times. Very rich with low carbonation

This had no head.This was the reason why I didn’t smell anything ,I believe.The color was a dark brown.The taste was quite heavy.The commercial description is accurate.It does have a "rich roasted malt flavor".Not much activity in the beer,so it almost tastes a bit flat.Good beer,but not my style.

Bottle courtesy of Daalamar: Poured a deep burgundy/brown color beer with a huge foamy head with great retention. Aroma of banana is really dominating and greatly enjoyable. Taste has also some definite trace of banana bread with a very nice presence of sweet malt. Alcohol is very well hidden and sadly the body is a bit too thin. Apart from that , this is a very good example of a style that I don’t have a chance to enjoy often.

I was on the fence buying this beer.  But nice roasted aroma left me wanting to drink this beer.  The taste was great!  It had a nice mix of hops, malt, malasses and a nice caramel flavor.  It is a higher alcohol % but hard to tell cus it doesnt over power the beer at all.  The 6 pack was gone shortly after!

A subtle surprise.  Flavorful hoppy aroma, a decent body, yet the high alcohol content and dark brown body do not make the beer seem overly alcoholic.  Decent head and dry finish. Provides a gentle dopple.

Very dark brown body with no head to speak of.  Smells hoppy and malty with a hint of yeast.  Not as strong a taste as one might expect.  You notice a little more taste on the aftertaste.  Somewhat sweet, as well as sour with hop and alcohol notes.  Not bad, Drinkable.  But for the price, there are things I like better.

12 oz bottle. Poured a deep reddish brown color with a thick head.  Aroma was very malty with a thick, molasses scent and some light, crisp notes.  The taste had a lot of activity, very nice on the palate with a lot of malt, hops, molasses and caramel flavors.  Finished nice and clean on the palate with a great after taste! I will definately get more of this in the future!

Pours deep ruby with tick off white head which dissapates to thin film.  Aroma is molasses, dark fruit, and alcohol.  Well carbonated but smooth mouthfeel.  Flavor is of semi-sweet molasses, toffee, tart-dark fruit, and alcohol.  As beer warms up a slight smoky roastiness appears.  Roasty molasses and alcohol for the finish that warms the stomach.  Overall a totally decent doppel.
Bottle. Pours dark ruby, cream head. Aroma is malty, tangy molasses, sake, caramel. Flavor is malty, molasses, caramel, soy sauce, and vanilla.
Dark, with a thick tan head.  Very malty aroma, with chocolate malt dominating.  Despite the 7.2% content, no alcohol is noticable in the flavor

Aug. 8, 2006; 12 oz. bottle.  Regal ruby color. Faultlessly robust raisiny/sweet taste is accurately presaged by a prominent aroma of dark fruit and red wine.  Didn’t particularly care for this on the first try a couple of years ago, but am glad I waited to rate this.
Pours a dark brown with fruity aroma.  Sweet from beginning to end.  Flavors of dark fruit and malt.  Little hops, sweet finish.  Good beer, but a little to sweet.
Bottle. Good summer beer. Very smooth taste with a decent head. Goes down smooth with a little kick in the end. Nice malty flavor.

Pours a brown color with a good size light tan head.  Lots of nice lacing.  Good carbonation.  The aroma is toasted malt.  The flavor is roasted malt.  Medium body.    A little dry to the palate.  A good beer.

Bottled.  Poured a clear, deep fiery orange with a couple minutes’ worth of beige head.  Nose was slick and enticing, rockin’ deep fruity malts (plum primarily), smoked toffee, toasty caramel, light wood, and herbal hints.  This came together even better in the flavor department, with a more well-defined rich malty backbone and some alcohol warmth to enhance the flavors.  Toffee, caramel, and woodiness round out the warm finish.  This was very good.
Dark brown.  Smells of rich fruits, some raisins and plums.  Tastes fruity with a heavy, sweet flavor.  Big surprise for the venue I was at.

I saw this in the store the other night and it dawned on me I had never drank it before.  So I thought tonight would be a good night.  Sweet is sweet, malty, and slightly hoppy.  Taste is sweet and rich, some hops, pretty standard doppelbock really.  Nothing special going on here.  Its on tap down the road from me, probably will try that sometime soon.
bottle.  pours deep brown with ample head.  sweet malty aroma.  taste is equal with nose.  palate is solid.  great beer.

Bottle from local grocery. Dark brown. Very large head that dissipates quickly. Roasted malt aroma with a little toffee perhaps. Sweet and malty with very little aftertaste. A bit light bodied. More like a bock than a double bock though.WEAK FINISH.  I was hoping for more from this beer, but is still good. May try another one some time.
Bottle.  Dark brown body, but small tan head.  Caramel and malts are the aroma, with some roasted malts as the flavor along with caramel.  Sweet as well.

2010-07-04. No notes, Just okay, lacks the depth and character I remembered it having on my previous sample. . On tap at Seattle International Beer Festival


2006-07-XX. Bottle. Brown body, impressive tan head. Sweet caramel malt aroma, light notes of toasted malt. Very light fruity notes. Sweet malt flavour with light caramel notes. Medium palate suits the beer (3+). Solid doppelbock, a touch simplistic at times but quite nice.  7/4/8/4/16
Good, strong and malty.  I’ve had this beer at a few oktoberfests (or so I’ve been told).  A strong but deceptively easy drinking uber beer.

12oz bottle.Pours a dark amber almost coke like color with a fast fading light brown head.Aromas of dried fruit aor molasses and malt .The taste of raisins come to mind but not too sweet with a nice balance.A very good beer for it’s style.
Una cerveza muy dulce, parecida a la malta peruana aunque esta sabe mas a caramelo. No es mi estilo de cerveza favorito pero debo decir que estuvo muy rica y que la disfrute.

pours out a nice golden brown with a bubbly head that vanishes quickly. Very smooth malty taste with hints of maple syrup and nuts. Has a high alcohol content but you cant taste it. A really good doppelbock.

pours a beautiful rich reddish dark brown with a small tan head and little lacing.  Doesn’t really smell like much but maybe my sense of smell is off today.  Tastes creamy and nutty and caramel sweet.

This one is tough, because it isn’t my favorite style. It pours an attractive dark color with very sweet, carmalized malts dominating the palate. Think molasses. The problem is that it goes against my style preferences, but I am trying to rate this within the style, and I think that it does well in the style. The flavor is solid, with no off notes, and it is fairly complex. Although much too sweet for my palate, it appears to be otherwise well balanced.  I’ve updated my rating to reflect my comparision to Newcastle and Dogfish Indian Brown.

Bottle. Aroma is slightly hoppy, with malts dominating. Some citrus/flower notes, but nt distinct. Taste is mildly hoppy, with very strong malt tones, with slight notes of coffee.Carbonation issatisfying for this beer. Definitely a repeat buy.

Glass-clear ruby; smallish soapsud head fades quickly and leaves no lace. Not an auspicious beginning. But then, the aroma is like a fanfare of angels... incredibly rich sweet malt, cherry, nuts, pollen, oatmeal, muted and attractive grassy/barnyard notes. Soft honey-maple malt flavor is profoundly deep and meaty, like an endless French kiss. Savory, herbal musks complement the illusion: licorice or anise, cinnamon, turmeric, tobacco. The palate is as smooth, firm, and mouth-fiiling as Pamela Anderson’s left breast. Fine, tingly carbonation dances on the tongue. Gently bitter aftertaste tastes of stewed fruits and, faintly, chalk and tangy sweat. Each sip is better than the last. A magnificent brew, immensely satisfying.
Pours a deep dark brown with a medium cream colored head.   Nice full aroma and great taste, very fruity but the aftertaste is toasty. Mouthfeel is not watery at all.

Bottle, poured a dark brown or light black. Thin white head with little lace. Aroma is of raisens and something with scents of cola. Carmel is heavy is taste, sweet malt, and raisens. A nice brew but not something I’d have to have again.

4.0 18 (05.13.06) Sampled at DiCarlo’s Spring beer tasting event. Bottle. Poured clear dark brown with small off-white head. Soft carbonation.  Toasted malt aroma. Medium-to-full bodied doublebock that starts with moderate malt sweetness and toffee and fruity flavors. Finished with light malt fade. Very sweet malt but not cloying. An excellent doppelbock beer.

Clear amber color with a thin off white head. Sweet malty aroma with some lighter roasted malt. Flavor is sweet malts mixed with other subtle malt varieties. The rich and sweet dark malt flavor is dominant here. Overall really nice flavor although a bit on the sweet side for my taste.

A nice looking beer.  It pours a dark cola color with just a hint of foam that doesn’t last.  Aroma is sweet malt and has a nice caramel hint.  First taste features a nice little zing in the back of the throat.  Not really much malt in the flavor despite the aroma.  There is some over ripe fruit in the flavor and the caramel shows up.    Both of these add to the sweetness.

Was looking forward to this, but another case of ruining a beer with a green bottle.  Aroma was skunky.  Poured a beautiful dark brown, small off-white head.  Flavor had a nice sweet malty finish, but was ruined by the skunkiness.  Nice medium body.  Will rate again if I can get it in another type of bottle.
An awesome flavor,a wonderful beer.  Full bodied, even better when at near room temp.
Bottle.  Poured dark brown with substantial, pebbly beige head.  Little aroma, nice caramel flavor.

Just an average to below average doppel if you ask me. Poured a standard brown color with a head from the carbonation (disappeared quickly). Mouthfeel was thin and carbonated. Aroma was hard to pick up and the flavor was a little light with some green bottle European import special-ness going on - v. mild skunk and a grassiness that wasn’t a great touch for the style. Finished with some hoppiness. Made a decent beer-soaked shrimp barbecue, though.
Dark Malt, abit sweet, Caramel, very easy drinking for the style, one of the first Doppelbocks I tryed, go back to it quite often.Good brew
Possibly my favorite winter brew...  Deep color; caramel & chocolate finish.  Spaten delivers...again.

On tap at the "Taste Of Cincinnati 2006" festival - A tad molassesy (but aren’t all doppelbocks?), but a fine representation of the style, with deep richness and an interesting "chewiness". I like it!

Sweet malty nose. Clear dark amber-brown color with a medium, diminishing light tan head. Flavor starts rich caramel. dark fruit and toffey finishing with a mild bitterness and a hint of alcohol. Medium bodied and creamy with soft carbonation.

WoW! i had no idea this was going to be this good! I bought this at Gigante expecting something below average. The aroma is almost nonexisting and a little like wet rusting metal and coffe.  It pours a dark deep amber with an off white head, that dimisishes into noting pretty quick, the carbonation is good though. IT tastes of Sweet malts, vanilla slight vegetebels, potatoes and chocolate cream. To me the ABV was perfect on this one. It could have used some more head and some dried fruit flavors. Finishes a slight vinegar with creamy milk chocolate and caramel. Not bad at all, and a big surprise for me. Light and very easy to drink.

One of the first beers that really turned me on to great beer and started my path onto beer geekdom. I hadn’t tried it in a few years, so I figured I buy a bottle, sit down to rate it and see if it’s held up these past few years. Aroma is malty sweet, with caramel notes and brown sugar the strongest part. Appearance is a nice dark chocolatey clear brown with a nice tannish head. Mouthfeel is full-bodied, a bit sticky from the sweetness but I still enjoy it. Flavors are really nice with roasty maltyness that brings out caramel notes, some vanilla and toffee also. Overall, an extremely enjoyable beer that I’m glad to say was just as good now as it was when I first got into beer and that’s a good thing.

Bottle (330ml - green).  Poured clear bright mahogany with a large foamy tan head.  Lactic malty roasty aroma, yeasty, sweet, hint of fresh-cut rhubarb, a little vegetal; dry.  Taste is roasty, sweet fresh wheat and cereal grain, chocolate malt and dry hops to make the finish fairly balance.  Good creamy average body, grainy, longish finish, excellent, sophisticated doppel.
dark red roasty malt nose and flavor. Slight sweetnes and very crisp. A very good doppelbock

Deep brown/garnet colour, thick off-white head.  Sweet toasty/bready aroma, rye, molasses, light floral noble hops over the whole sweet mess.  Smells fantastic.  Nice malty complexity, but still clean.  Flavour is also sweet and toasty, light caramel, some molasses and a rye-like sourness.  Long lingering sweetness.  Full bodied, nice mouthfeel.  Much more hop flavour than I have encountered in most doppebocks.

Poured from a 12oz bottle a mahognay color with a tan head. Aroma was of rich dark malts and dark fruits (raisins/figs) with a bit of caramel. Flavor was full of roasted malts and caramel with just a sight hint of hops in the finish.

Draft.  Surly black with a foamy, tan head.  Deep, rich aroma of sugary fig and raisin.  Lots of tempting dark malts in the nose.  This was served way to cold and became really spectacular right around cellar temp.  The body is full and chewy, really playing up the 120L with more figgy plum character.  The dark fruit is sweetened with some sugary toffee and cocoa chocolate.  Long, smooth finish is quite appropriate.  I forgot how good this one was!  A little more fullness in the body and this could be truly great.
Nose of blackberry currant, licorice and roasted malt. Pleasant port flavor with chocolate and walnut notes reminded me of a swartzbier. Robust body.

500 ml bottle poured a clear brown with a large lasting tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, dark fruit, toffee and hints of molasses. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of toasted malt, raisins, dates and some molasses with a smooth lingering sweet finish.

Bottle. Pours a brown/black with a tweak of a head.  Scents of soft, malty fruits.  Flavors are rather thin and not so pronounced.  Sweet, but not the sugary backbone I prefer.  Far from full-bodied, this fell short for the style and was watery in general.

Nice syrupy sweet aroma, deep amber colour with a fluffy white head that dissipates to a thin persistant one.  The flavour is also deep and malty, sweet, and just a little hoppy.  Smooth and just a little bittter.

The bottle poured a clear, rich mahogany colored beverage with an average sized frothy off-white head that was mostly diminishing but left good lacing on the glass. The aroma was full of sweet caramel and roasted malts with a subtle note of port lurking in the background. The body was full with a creamy smooth texture and soft carbonation. The flavor starts off full of sweet caramel and port. As the long finish begins to kick in, there was a decided alcohol warmth in my chest and as the caramel and port sweetness diminished it was replaced with a light bitterness. This one was very drinkable.

First memory of this beer is some stupid bartender bitch saying they don’t have it on tap anymore because it’s out of season.  It’s a lower end dobblebock.  super malty and sweet.  alcoholic catches up with you.  unspectacular and uninteresting.
pours dark brown with a reddish hue...as expected, no head...aroma of dark fruits, heavy sugar and caramel...flavor of raison, sugar, caramel, and alcohol...average palate
a sim rate: (bottled from D’Agostino’s NYC) Smells like sour feet (thanks suture for pinning down that smell). Tastes very sour and strong. Bitter, licquoricy aftertaste. Not particularly pleasant.

(D’Agostino’s, NYC) Nice color.  Unpleasant aroma and sour taste. 
Didn’t like it.
Very deep, dark amber pour.  Complex, but not as much as other doppelbocks, maybe a better beginner beer.
on TAP flying pie a very nice dark brown with a nice creamy white head. It has a caramel sweet and roasted toffee tast. Good overall.

16 oz. bottle.  Pours very deep, dark amber.  Deep red when held to the light.  Clear with a big, >1", thick, creamy tan head.  Head gets smaller after a few minutes, but stays around.  Very nice lacing.  Aroma is of sweet malts and a little bit of spice, getting hints of plums, raisins, grapes.  Flavor is bitter up front, a little bit sweet, and deep, roasty, toasty, smokey in the finish.  Tiny bit of alcohol warmth.  Solid, medium mouthfeel, good carbonation, silky smooth.  I’m still pretty new to this style of beer, but this is a really good one.
GERMAN BEER IS THE BOMB!!! This is one of my all-time favorite beers.  This with a good sausage, sauerkraut and mustard... heaven.

Nice dark brown/red pour with creamy thick almost white head that laces the glass.  Semi-sweet light malty aroma.  Flavor is ok with a classic German malt tinge, a little scotchy that lingers on the palate.  Nice looking beer, that fails to deliver the bold taste and smooth finish that I prefer.

Very dark, brown, clear appearance.  Nice, coarse lasting head and antique white lacing.  Aroma is slightly malty, but muted.  Crisp carbonation, but it tends to get in the way of the flavor.  This medium bodied beer has a thin flavor intially, but the flavors seem to hold back and then deal themselves out slowly.  This is really nice as I get towards the bottom of the glass, but I would prefer something a little bolder (perhaps an American bias???).  The flavor consists of some raisin, plums and alcohol (not to the extent of a Thomas Hardy, though).  There is some hops in the aftertaste that tends to dry the palate.

Ruby pour with thin, receding head. Nose is filled with malts. Sweet and roasted. The alcohol and a hint of hops comes through in the aroma as well. The flavor is a fruity sweetness complimented by some hoppiness and alcohol warmth. Certainly, not as complex nor flavorful as Celebrator, but certainly enjoyable. Sticky mouthfeel from a medium to full body.
Rich flavor and nice thick body.  Poured a dark reddish brown with an off-white head.  Taste is abundent with malts, caramel, toffee, and brown sugar.  Excellent brew from Munich.

Dark carmalized red-brown.  Thick syrupy and low-carbonation.  Caramel sweet and roasted toffee.  Really malty with hardly any hop presence, athough their is a decent alcohol bite.  This a good Dopplebock, but not my favorite.
Dark brown. Small, dense, off white head. Aroma of roasty, burnt malt, banana, clove, and toffee. Same flavors. Full, balanced body. Solid doppelbock.
love this one green bottle black brew DARK very dark one of my favorite doppelbocks!!
Clear dark brown color with a creamy light brown head. Sweet dark malt aroma. Sweet dark malt and light caramel flavor with some light roasted malt in the end.
Nice caramel body with a large, light brown head.  Malt (roasted) and caramel dominate the aroma.  Light bitterness in the palate, sweet however.  Mollasses in the body, maybe some toffee accents.
Clear deep ruby copper color with a small tan head. Sweet toffee flavours with a bit of that dusty aged taste.

Bottle. Rusy brown color, nearly opaque, with a quickly dissipating tan head. Sweet aroma of sticky brown sugar, tootsie rolls, dates, and berries. Sweet flavor of malts/caramel, but sticky and simple.  Comparing to Ayinger is a tough matchup, but this is much more boring.
pours out of the bottle mud brown with a tan head. smells of coffee and chocolate malts. tastes of citrusy hops, sweet malts and alcohol. goes down easy. flavors slightly watered down. quite good.
Had this one bottled.  Rich dark brown color, thick thick head, notes of coffee and chocolate.  Outstanding, especially for a bock.

Nice sweet malty caramel taste and aroma.  I plan to use this beer (or possiby Celebrator if he can find one near where he liives) to introduce a friend of mine in another state to the world of good beer, because I think this style would have a very universal appeal.
Bottle : Pours nice dark brown withc tant head.  Very malty aroma and taste with full body.  Taste is slightly sweet with light bitterness

On tap at Stubbie’s.  Light brown in color with a tannish head.  Flavor is a rush of chocolate, sweet malt(as in malted milk balls), and molasses.  No detectable hop presence.  This is a delightful beer, reminds me of chocolate milk.
on tap-pours a tan head.  Color is dark brown with red tint.  Aroma is dark malt.  Taste is sweet, malty.  OK carbonation.

Pours dark red body. Overall, a very full body beer. Head is a nice white color. Although it doesn’t last long at all. Better taste during the middle of the beer. Alcohol apparent the warmer the beer gets. Very satisfying.

Poured dark red brown with decent sudsy head, faded fast with no lace.  Aromas were ripe dark fruit, alcohol, malt sugar, citrusy hops, caramel and chocolate.  Wonderful full-bodied complex flavor with strong roasted malt, toffee, dark fruits, peat, earth, butter, port wine, scotch, yeast, grapefruit hops, herbs, and alcohol.  Wonderful thick chewy mouthfeel.  Well balanced malt and hops in a strong, full-bodied beer.

Pours a very dark ruby color with a more than adequate antique lace colored head.  Nose is raisins and roasted malt.  Taste is a buttery toffee, toasted maltiness, and hops.  Mild hop bitterness remains on the palate along with a slight alcohol warmth as it goes down.  Very very good.
pour looks like cola.....this beer is sweet sweet nectar and goes well with pizza...the alcohol is adds to the overall experience...... nice

Not much aroma. Good tan head. I’m not a big dopplebock fan but this was pretty tasty and highly drinkable. Malty sweet but not overly sweet. I didn’ttaste much roastiness but I’ll order it again to see if it’s in there like the description says..

Pours a dark brown amber with red highlights and a light tan head that fades quickly.  Aroma of roasted malts.  Flavor has a very strong roasted malt presence, coupled with brief cameos of coffee and caramel.  Too strong for back-to-back drinking.

Pours an expected brown with a nice thick lasting head.  This beer is a tasty thirst quencher, but is lacking in flaovr and aromas that would be expected for a doppel bock.  Tastes like a marzen with slight hints of chocolate.  Alright but no depth or character.

A standard in many respects, I have grown less fond of Optimator over the years.  Wonderful aroma and a great appearance that can be used to judge all sorts of colors.  The flavor, however, becomes cloying and ruins the palate.  Drinkable, but only, maybe, one.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pilsner glass Optimator looked a reddish brown color when held up to a light. There was a tan head of about an inch with large bubbles in it.
My 1st whiff was beer! Must be some hops in there. After the 1st sniff all I could get was the malt and a very slight metallic smell.
The taste was malty and a bit sweet but not overly so. If you let it sit in your mouth too long you’ll get a metallic taste. The 7.2% ABV is not noticeable, so, this Doppelbock can sneak up on you and go Boo!

The mouth feel was a bit thin for something that is supposed to be full-bodied. It is smooth and very drinkable with sufficient carbonation.

This is the first Doppelbock I ever had. I had it on tap at the Village Corner in historic Stone Mountain Village, GA. I must say that I prefer it on tap. I plan on hitting the VC ASAP and writing up a review of Optimator on tap. I think it is better that way, let’s see if I can tell why that is...

A nice, roasty nose, caramelly and nutty.  Light mouthfeel with good carbonation.  Very roasty flavor with a long evolving finish that was smooth and had some definite weight to it.  Nicely rounded, a warming beer.

We took the kids to the Nine Inch Nails show in Cincy Saturday night.  On the way down
we stopped at Mecklenburg Gardens.  I had one of these from the tap before dinner. 
Next to perfect nose of butterscotch and caramel.  Pours a dark ruby brown.  The large
creamy tan rocky head is mostly lasting with fair lace.  The fruity & sweet flavor is
pleasant and very malty, though deftly complex.  The full body is creamy and soft.  It’s
been a long while since I’ve had such a wicked doppel.  I recommend the Hungarian
Goulash.  Hats off to the owners of this fine establishment, we all left very happy.
I enjoyed this beer.  Dark amber and easy on the palate.  This is my first dopplebock and I like the sweet malty finish.
A good mid-level doppelbock.When you can’t find Salvator or Aventinus, a decent substitute, though on a par with Sam Adams Winter Lager.

From a 12 oz. distinctive narrow neck green Spaten bottle with a bottling date on front label that I believe translates out to 08/03/05. Made a good appearance, poured a deep amber with a nice foamy pale tan head that reduced to a minimally sticking thin lacing. Had faint aromas, a toasted sweet caramel maltiness, a dark ripe fruitiness and whiffs of sweet alcohol. Medium carbonation and a smooth semi-full bodied body mouth feel, there is a lightness to it and good drinkability. Had a dark ripe fruity taste, raisins mostly, a toasted maltiness in the background, a slight, sweet alcohol bite on the tongue and a crisp fruity finish with some metallic notes.

Full bodied doppelbock with a smack of powerful hops and rich flavor that does not repeat on the palate.  Goes well with a medium-full bodied cigar.  Slightly sweet finish, yet balanced in its own malt complexity.

ooh man this stuff was gross. smelled like bud. tastes very sour and watery with little malt or "bock" flavors to speak of. finnished with a metalic grassy flavor that reminded me of a crapy lager. i cant imagine how this beer is so highly rated. i can only hope that i got a bad one, either that or i dont know what good beer taste like, cause i really hated this. had to pour it out.
Pours a deep garnet into a stein.  Head quickly dissipates leaving no lacing.  Bread and roasted caramel aromas.  Well balanced with sweet and bitter chocolate finish.  A little lively.  Nice.
Bottle.  Dark chocolate, molasses and hops aroma.  Opaque dark brown color with small head.  Dark malt flavor with mild astringent finish.  Nice and well balanced but fairly weak for the style.

Deep amber honey in color with a malty nose. Not real complex, off dry, ballanced with a flavorfull finish. Alcohol is well hidden. Overall an enjoyable brew of mellow character. I do recommend trying it.

Vegetably, dry, puny aroma. Taste is not much different, with only a hint of nice rich bock taste... mostly just sour grain and green pepper. Pour is dark umber with a pathetic head, and palate is too fizzy. Very dissappointed with this.

Sweets arrive at the fair.
The sun has set.
Nothing is seen in the sky.
the hand on my shoulder fills the room.
Sweet grains. Sweet Grains.

I was happy to enjoy a Spaten Optimator at the Spatenhof which is the downtown Munich outlet for Spaten beers. This is a very well done example of dopple bock, and one that can be found in a number of US markets both in bottles and on draught. It can actually be found year round in the US, but I really enjoy this one during the cold, winter months, as a rich, hearty, malty lager to sit and relax with. 

Spaten Optimator pours to a beautiful, bright, chestnut color with a thick and creamy head, and a moderate amount of carbonation. The nose on this beer is rich and sweet with lots of big sweet malty, nutty, and toasty aromas with hints of peppery alcohol. The palate is rich and full on the tongue, with lots of big sweet malt, toast, and nut flavors, on a firm, polished body. Optimator finishes with more sweet malt and toasty flavors up front, then ends a bit cloying with more sweet malt, and a peppery alcohol burn that lingers. 

This is an delicious, very welll made example of dopple bock, and is a personal favorite of mine, though there are other examples that I enjoy more. I enjoy the fact that this beer, along with Paulaner Salvator is one the most accessible German dopples on the US market, and is a very good introduction to the style. It isn’t the most impressive dopple bock I have sampled, but the Germans have set the bar very high on this particular style, so at the very least this beer can be called excellent. 

Optimator is a wonderful before or after dinner drink, and its sweet and toasty character makes it an ideal desert beer. At the Spatenhof, this beer was a phenomenal match to a dessert of Weissbier Creme, which was a delicious custard made with Franziskaner Weissbier served with fresh whipped cream, fruit and berries. It was to die for, and the sweet and malty Optimator really cut the tart wheat flavors of the weissebier cream, fruit, and berries.
Solid beer all around...nice dark brown color with a sweet malty aroma.  Excellent taste that isn’t too over the top with sweet malt...slightly bitter and nutty as well.  Very drinkable.

This beer is what I thought beer would taste like when I was a kid. Te color is fantastic, with little to no head. The aroma is very sweet, but subtle. The taste is to die for. It hits tha palette with many flavors, sweet, bitter, and amooth. Very malty, with a great after taste. Tastes good cold or at room temp.

Bottle.  Lagery corn aluminum aroma.  Black with a small white fading head.  Very german flavored for lack of a better word; slightly metallic, sweet, corny, malty, winy.   a bit canned lager tasting.  Nice lacing.  A bit too malty and sweet and I don’t like that corny/metal/lager note that stands out.  It’s richer in mouthfeel than lager, but that corn-metal sticks around for a while in the finish, overall a somewhat unpleasant beer.

I ordered this on tap, but they brought me a bottle, instead, even though th ebeer menu spcifically said it was on tap.  They didn’t even offer to bring me something else.  Oh well, I drank it any way.  This is the first doppelbock I’ve reviewed.  Lots and lots of malt.  The head was light-brown, firm, with great lacing.  Sweet malt is almost overpowering, but good.
dark brown, clear pour, a little head. aroma is all roasted malt. big nice sweet malt flavored with a slight twinge of alcohol in the finish. pretty tasty.
One of my favorite "every-day" beers.  Pours a very dark brown with a nice tan head.  Smells of malts and caramel.  It has a strong malt flavor and covers the palate nicely.
Pours a dark brown with a thick head.  That’s okay though, it’s okay to be thick headed.  A bit sweet and sour, it goes down smooth.  A great find at my local beer store.
Deep transparent chocolate color with a thick tan head. A hint of molasses in the odor Thick lacing on the glass as the head recedes.Carmely tastes of brown sugar.

I have had this beer before, and it was badly skunked. This time, it was wonderful. Deep red-brown with a thin light brown head. Smells of roasted malts and sweet-and-sour; perhaps caramel. It goes down smooth and just a little fizzy. Tastes of dried apricots and malt. Quite tasty.

The first time I had this beer, I didnt enjoy it because I was so un-used to this style, but now I enjoy it alot. Rich tastes of dark fruit and dark sugar candies. Strong malts makes this a perfect after dinner beer.

beer pours a really pretty deep brown with heavy ruby notes. head is tan, retains well and leaves good lace. nose is sweet and bready, with overtones of caramel and cola. flavor is sweet and rich - a thick and heavy maltiness barely balanced by a lightly roasty tang, and a couple of IBUs. pretty cloying, and becomes more so as you drink it.
Had Bottle and Tap over 2 days. Believe it or not I liked the bottled better. Sweet fruity taste up front that mellowed out to a hearty, smokey taste. A German beer with oomph.
"Poured brown color with a huge head which disappeared very quickly. Aroma wasn’t strong at all little malty smell. Tasted of carmel and malts. Mouthfeel was thin and very carbonated."
Bottle from a sampler pack had a nice clear brown color with a slight red tint. Small head with minimal lacing. Taste was complex yet balanced. Nice roasted chocolate and dark bread aroma. Very nice.

Apparently I don’t agree with the masses (either that, or I’m not a beer connoisseur), because I really hated this beer.  It had a bitter fruit taste that just didn’t sit well at all.  The alcohol content was nice, but thats about it.

Lovely reddish brown color. The head delivers exactly what the nose promises and the palate is rich and rewarding. Mouth-feel is comfortably medium. Alcohol is well masked. Balanced as well, in my opinion, as any of the -ators. Delicious brew.

On tap at Old Munich Biergarten in Bradenton, Fl: Pours dark brown with a medium light brown head. Has a roasty chocolate aroma and flavor is malty with a smooth light bitter finish. Very nice to drink this on tap.

Enjoyed this beer with LikeBurning the same night at the Flying Saucer.  Something to behold, heavy on the wine taste especially at the finish.  Still my favorite beer up to this point.  Incredible malts bring flavor throughout the mouth.  I think I want a person to follow me around and hand me one whenever I thirst.  That’d be really pleasant.

This dark brown beer with no head was served to me in a small brandy snifter at the Flying Saucer.  If a beer could be dry like a wine this one would be.  light chocolate and other sweets abound in the taste, with malt bringing them all together.  Wonderful on a cold winter night.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour with an offwhite head.  Aroma is kinda yeasty.
Nice malts to this,  chocolate and caramel flavors in it.  Good thick mouthfeel, too.  I liked this a lot.

Draught at Tyler’s in Durham, NC. Served in a half-liter Spaten glass. Clear Mahogany color with thick tan head. Malty alcohol nose with caramel, milk chocolate, and licorice flavors. Slightly sweet with hefty mouth feel.
Beautiful red color that is murky and also  golden. Serious lacy head for style. Very malty, with hint of chocolate and bananas. Mild bitterness, smooth fisnish and caramel cream aftertaste.

,re-rate 12/10/10 - bottle. Pours a crystal clear deep amber/brown color with medium sized light tan head. Aroma is full of chewy malts, deep cherry notes, tons of toasted caramel, notes of oak, vanilla bean, peat. Flavor is very malty, just dripping with chewy malts, caramel, fair amount of oakyness, touch of roastyness and vanilla. Finish is slightly sweet but not overly sweet or cloying. Palate is nicely full. This is really a great brew. 

Dark brown/ruby red color with big off white head. Aroma is malty, hints of cherry and chocolate. Flavor is malty, smooth, hints of cherry and roasted malts, mildly sweet finish with just a hint of bitterness.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown with an off-white head that quickly dissipated. Sweet caramel malts in the aroma mixed with fruit (prunes & raisins). The flavor was much of the same with caramel, fruit, and some light citrus. Full body, creamy, and sticky. Coffee/caramel after taste. Very enjoyable.
Pours a nice deep golden brown color.  Aromas of rich dark malts, chocolate, fruit, and a hint of smoke.  Flavor is rich with a lot of flavors to be found, chocolate, dark fruit, coffee.

Pours a murky brown with rivulets of German wheat and yeast. Nose is malt sweet of gingerbread, butter, and cinammon. Palate is even, medium- to full-bodied and silky smooth. Flavor is malt characters with a distinctive roast undertone that molds an incredible smoothness that makes this thoroughly enjoyable. Yes, as others feel the need to point out, Celebrator is better, but for a widely accesible doppelbock Optimator never disappoints.

Tap, Ashley’s, Ann Arbor. After trying Ayinger Celebrator, this is so boring. Nice look too it, kind of leather brown in appearance with small head. Malty grapeAlmost pastey mouth feel if that makes any sense.

Malty flavors dominate this dark brown ale.  Aroma is all malt with not hop presence at all.  Nice roasted flavors with just enough bitterness to offset the sweetness of all the malt.  A very pleasant aftertaste of yeast and amlt lingers for a long time.

Paid $1.49 for a 12-oz single bottle of this at Whole Foods, Charlottesville. Pours clear dark brown with a huge tan, frothy head. Smells of roasted malts, toast, and light caramel. Flavors of toast, chocolates, molasses, and some toffee round this one out. Finishes with a smooth, rich bitterness of some chocolates that linger for quite some time.

Pours dark amber with a thin tan head.  Aroma is of sourdough bread, molasses, figs, prunes, plum, and a bit of roasted malts.  Flavor is predominantly molasses, dark fruits, honey, and sweet bread.  Very good taste, but it’s not as complex as Ayinger Celebrator.  Excellent on the palate - creamy, smooth and warming as it goes down, lively carbonation.
