Although Celebrator is a better doppelbock, this one aint bad.

Bottle - Pours a nice dark brown with a moderate head that evaporates fairly quickly.  Aroma is sweet with dark fruits and hints of dark roasted sweets.  Taste is sweet with nuances of chocolate, caramel, hints of molasses.  Alcohol seems to become more prevalent towards the end disturbing the beers otherwise solid consistency.  Very good.

Tap. I’m coming to find that no mater how hard I try, I just don’t care for doppelbocks. Not that this was an unpleasant experience, but that smoky raisin flavor just isn’t for me. This one was still pretty drinkable, extra points for smoothness.

Sweet malt aroma, with treacle, hops and fruit, clear ruby, pours a huge, firm, toffee head, leaves some very nice lace.
Wonderous malt flavour, plums, cherries, nuts and raisins. Oh so sweet, well balanced, quite complex, silky smooth. Fantastic!

This peer poured with a small creamy off-white head.  Very beautiful dark brown, but not opaque color.  Nose is heavy with malt, and honey.  Flavor is sweet, with roasted malt taste, caramel and molasses and very light coffee taste.  Wow.  I do like this, very much.
I really like the Optimator.  Strong and thick with malty aromas.  Too bad I can’t get it in SC.  C’est la vie.

bottle.  Pours very dark with thick head.  Aroma is malty sweet with some alcohol.  Burnt molasses predominates with a bitter alcohol finish.  Represents the style very well but I have to be in the right mood to enjoy a doppelbock.
Bottle.  This was good stuff, but the alcohol came on strong towards the end as the beer heated up.  I think it’s a good beer, just not really my style
Pours a dark brown with a sweet molasses aroma.  Wonderful Taste!  Caramel taste with a bit of molasses and a slight hoppy bitterness.  Smooth drinking beer.  Great beer!

Had a bit of a cold when I tried this, so might re-rate later.  My first impression though was buttery and malty. Could feel it warming after a couple drinks.  I can definitely tell this is a well made beer, I just don’t know if I like Dopple bocks.  I need to sample this style more widely.

Pours a  dark brown amber with an average size tan head.  Aroma is molasses, slight roasted malts and caramel.  Flavors of the same.  Rather smooth going down.  Creamy malts with maybe a slight hit of hop bitterness.
offered as a porter alternative, not too bad. Pours dark with a beige head. Malty with a faint chocolate taste. Overall not too bad, not the best.. just somewhere in between.
Not bad, and holds up well to the cold. Definitely not my first choice for a German dark beer.

bottle. thanks Derek. dark copper-red with a tan medium head. aroma is earthy with yeast, light fruit, malt, and caramel. sweet, sticky malty flavour. medium-body. tasty caramel and faint chocolate and toffee notes. pretty good. I’d like to find more of this style.

bottle. Pours a rich ruby hue. We’re talking full on blood red here. There’s a small whispy white head. The aroma is of caramel and thinly of bread. Tastes like apples, yeast, grapes, and just a bit of hay. It seems like something unidentifiable is missing , but it is definitely drinkable.

Thanks for sharing Derek!
Ruby-brown liquid fills the glass, while a frothy and beige head keep everything at bay. A peaty punch in the nose is followed quickly by a very nice prune/plum aroma. Throw in some roasted malts to finish it off. Fruity, earthy tones, with peat and some sweet lingering caramel malt flavours. Smooth mouthfeel, carbonation is just right. True to style, and a good example. Thanks again Derek!

Draft Growler from Party Source, KY. Pours clear brown color with a large  creamy off-white head  that is lasting with excellent lacing. Good roasted malt aroma. Medium to full body with smooth texture. Heavy sweet malt flavor and light bitter long finish. Very good brew.

Deep clear mahogany with a medium tan head that lasted halfway through the glass. Wonderful malty aroma, followed by a luscious feel in the mouth. Sweet, roasted malt flavor with a hint of caramel. LIttle hop bitterness or flavor noted, and the malty flavor, not cloying, lingers. Very enjoyable.
Really was excellent, tasteful, nice and thick head.  Creamy flavor without harshness, more sweet than your average dark.

Pours dark brown with thick creamy sticky lacing head.  Sweet aroma of candy, caramel, brown sugar.  Thick, creamy malt flavor and palate with sweet brown sugar.  Sweet finish that lingers to make you want more.
I haven’t had a malt character like this in a long time. The mouth explodes with malty goodness.  I get a nice alcohol warming in the back of the throat. I would drink this again.

Dark brown with a thick 2 finger head, with mild lacing.

Nice malty/nutty smell with some brown sugar and some dark fruits. 

Taste is roasted malts, nuts and caramel. There’s just enough of a hop presence to keep it from being overly sweet.

This is a really good Doppelbock. Went really well with the Schnitzel I had at the resaraunt. I might have to actually look to buy some of this to have at home.
Strong beer, very dark and kinda thick, I really enjoy it, slightly hard to find, My girl even enjoys it. Sweet aftertaste and just the right amount of carbonation. Sold at whole foods locally.
Pours a dark brown with a moderately sized white head. Taste is rich and malty with a reminder of the high alcoholic content.

Only my second dopplebock after the Celebrator....  this beer doesn’t really stack up to Celebrator, but there is a nice toasted chocolatey flavor which is very pleasant.  This is good stufff.  I do believe I like it better than the Oktoberfest.
Deep reddish color, good head, great malts. Bitter hoppy finish, understated malts, a little chocolately, sweet.

Ok I had trouble smelling this one so I couldn’t give it as high a rating as I would have liked.  It was light hops, with malty undertones and there was a subtle sweetness to it as well.  The body was brown with a white head that lasted even though it was thin.  Flavor was light hops, floral, smooth, with another flavor which I could not identify though it seemed familiar.  A very nice beer indeed.

[bottle] Pours a brownish color, with a small head. Aroma is interesting, and backs up the flavors well. Tastes very malty, with some nutty and fruity hints as well. Palate is quite nice, overall-  very good.

Appears a dark reddish brown with a 1 finger tan cap that slowly fades. Tiny spotty lacing have a bit of a hard time sticking.
Smell is super malty, nutty, caramel, and sourdough.
Tate is equal to the aromas and measures up nicely.
Mouthfeel is sweet, with dark fruit and mild sourness balancing out this malty mix. Very smooth.

Bottle.  Poured a nice rich brown with a medium tan head, nice lacing.  Great roasted malt and caramel aroma.  Medium bodied on the palate, just the right amount of carbonation.  The taste was initially sweet and rich, hints of sugar cane, molasses, dried fruit and alcohol with a malty, mild bitter taste on the finish.  Quite good, I enjoyed a couple while watching Sunday NFL games.

(Bottle) Rich creamy biege head crowns dark ruby brown body. Very nice lacing. Aroma of malty sweetness and molasses. Smooth rich sweetness, bitterness a little extended. Really grows on you with each draw of the glass. Excellent.

Bottle.  First, I need to say that I had no idea that it was a green bottle until I poured it!  Nice dark brown with just a little head and lace.  Nose is of malt, raisins, hints of caramel and caramelized sugar.  Nice aroma, smells like a great beer.  Taste is a perfect mix of noble hops and roasted barley malt - fits perfectly on a humid September evening as it is not too much or too little, but just like the baby bear’s porridge.... just right and great!  Mouthfeel is even better than all the rest.  Perfect carbonation (because it has more than most doppels) and a nice crisp medium body.  This is great beer!
The saucer had it labeled as "spaten dunkel"  I guess this is the beer. cloudy brown, nose of fruits and alcohol.  Tastes like rum rasins, bannans, and plums. Malty. Very good. on tap

There is a very smooth force at work here, the flavor seems dulled.  Raisins, faint alcohol, and honey are the most intense...but it is still all pretty light.  Very light vanilla, too.  Body is nice, and not too sticky.
on tap at tap room-warren N.J.A deep,dark color,with a malty and nutty aroma.Flavor is a chocolate,roasty flavor.A very good doppelbock.

Pours deep reddish brown. Aroma is of brown sugar and raisins. Flavor is raisins and chocolate maybe a little caramel in there. It goes down smooth..and that might be a problem for me. This is found at almost every liquor store in town.

12 oz bottle pours dark brown with a creamy offwhite head.  Aroma of raisins, chocolate, caramel, and a bit of plum.  Flavor is caramel and chocolate sweetness along with a bit of raisin.  Palate is smooth and creamy fairly full bodied with a nice dry fruity finish.  This is a pretty nice doppelbock for the price.  I liked it.

Dark like a doppelbock should be.  Raisiny dryness.  Remarkably little alcoholic pepperiness despite above average content.  Surprisingly smooth and drinkable, which makes it exceedingly dangerous and oh-so delicious.

Had at KC Biermeister meeting. Dark maroon color with an off white head. Aroma is caramel malt, dark fruits, raisins, plums. Full body, creamy. Taste is caramel, malt, vanilla and some noble hops.  A bit hot. Pleasant.

Reddish brown color with creamy tan head.  Cinammon and brown sugar in the aroma.  Decadently sweet palate that lingers but doesn’t sicken because of a wee bit of hops in the body.  Great for a macro.  If this beer intrigued you, move on to the Ayinger, also easy to find.

Brown with a ruby tint. Pretty good head and lacing. Whitish brown head that stayed for a little while. Malty, fruity, alcoholic. Nothing out of the ordinary here. not much here. A light sweet malty flavor with a little chocolate in the background but I can’t find much else. Watery with moderate carbonation. Nowhere near as strong as a dopplebock’s mouthfeel should be. This was not very impressive to me. I had both the Ayinger Celebrator and Samichlaus in the same weekend, and this one impressed me as being average, almost bock-like in its maltiness, certainly not up to dopplebock standards.

12oz - Aroma is nutty, roasted carmel malt, and a touch of toffee. Pours a deep brownish-red with a medium head and good lacing.  Flavor is sweet malty goodness.  Carmel, roasted nuts,and  toffee.  Palate is creamy and smooth.  Not many dopplebocks in ratings to compare, but a tasty brew none the less.

I had always heard such great things about this beer. I’ve also noticed that Spaten hasn’t been making very good beers lately. This one pours a nice deep red color but with very little head. It’s got a malty aroma with not much else to speak of. The flavor is strong and malty with no alcohol burn to detract from it. It really doesn’t have much character. Not a bad beer, just overrated.
Ah, the pleasure of richly roasted malt topped off with nuts and just the slightest flirtation with caramel...deep and dark, rich and lively.

Fimne dark red brownish body with a thich cream head.  Aroma is a pretty heafty malt smell, slightly caramelized and a hint of pasta.    Flavor is sweet and slightly roasted.  A taste of plum and nice wheat pasta comes towards the end.  The mouthfeel is smooth and pleasant.  A fine brew.

Bottle: Dark copper, brownish, moderate beige foamy head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Malty aroma, brown sugar, wheat bread, slight fig/date. &nbsp Semi-sweet dark bready/malty flavor, some soft dark pitted fruit as well. &nbsp Big body, moderate mouthfeel. &nbsp Long lingering finish, coats the tongue well. &nbsp Nothing fancy, but quite solid for the style.
full, rich, dark, chocolatty flavor.  Pours a dark amber/brown with a medium sized creamy head.  MMMMM good beer
Bottle. Dark mahogony color with an off-white head. Caramel and malt aroma, with a bit of dark stone fruit. Caramel and malt flavor with a bit of noble hop spiciness. Easy to drink.

Poured a dark brown color with a small amount of offwhite head.  Aroma is fruity, plummy, and yeasty like kneeded dough.  Flavor is dominated by yeast flavor with some roasted caramel undertones and dark fruit flavors.  Overall, i found this to be a bit unbalanced and i didnt enjoy the yeasty taste to it.

This beer suprised the heck out of me.  I have been seeing it on the shelves for a long time, but never really bothered to check it out.  Well, I have found a new favorite everyday six-pack beer.  Beautiful head and dark color.  
Beautiful lacing.  Aromas of roasty nutty caramel.  Flavors were similar with some spiciness.  Much roasty malty flavor.  Great beer.

Bottle. Drank from the bottle, so I can’t really describe the visuals. Smells of malts, alcohol, and plums.  Very smooth palate, nice body. Not too thick or too watery. Definately tasty and something that I’d drink regularly.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a light tan head. Nose is sweet and malty with some light chocolate and caramel. Very smooth and creamy on the palate. Chcolate, plums and raisins stick out with some malt hints and caramel.

Drank it in Germany and found out that Safeway carries it in California. This is a good thing. 
I liked it from the start and just continue with it. Not like you can get really good German beer just anywhere.

I’ve had this in 12 oz. bottles and on tap.  This was probably the first high quality beer I ever had, and it’s stuck with me ever since.  The color is a dark brown with a thin, ephemeral head to it.  Aroma is of a sweet nuttiness (a simple aroma, but great nonetheless).  Taste is sweet, nutty, toffee, and a little warmness.  Nice slightly thick mouthfeel, but thin for the alcohol content.
pours a reddish brown color with a small tan head, aromas of carmel malts and roast, the taste is carmel, sweetness, toffee, and alcohol, not bad, very drinkable.
Very dark mysterious brown pour. Roasted notes, refreshing taste. For 7.2% mild but lasting mouthfeel. Creamy and sweet with just the right amount of bitterness. A winner.

A very nice looking dark brown/red beer, not to much head, bud that does not matter to the taste, which is medium bitter, hoppy, very refreshing. The aroma is very nice too, yeast, and rich. In all a very nice beer, one I would buy again.

Quite simply one of the best beers I have ever had. Great for those evening get-togethers at the local bierstube. Great roasty-caramel flavor with hints of spiciness. Palate surprisingly thin and light, perhaps too much so. Otherwise a fantastic beer.

Aroma is caramel and toffee and somewhat toasty. Chocolate brown color and has a decent head. The flavor mirrors the aroma. Sweet tasting with lots of caramel and toffee. Strong alcohol kick as well. Maybe just a little to much kick. Palate is thinner than expected. Pretty good overall but not as good as I had hoped for.

Pours a deep brown with a light-tan head.  Aroma is very toasy, sweet, and bready.   Flavor is swee and roasted, caramel mals give way to chocolate malts, a very nice bitter section, then a somewhat grassy finish.  Palate is very creamy and satisfying.  A very good example of the style.
bottled, dark brown w/ biege head. aroma of caramel, roasty flavor w/ hint of chocolate.

On Tap at Flying Pie (Fairview): This was an overall great beer.  It is a clear, dark brown color with sticky lacing.  It also has a small off-white head.  I noticed more sweet malts than anything, kind of hard to identify (cola?).  Lots of carbonation with a slight metallic aftertaste.

I’ve only had it on tap, but served properly, it’s extremely well balanced for such a complex, flavorful beer.  It is smooth and covers the alcohol well.  A pint or half liter of optimator makes the perfect starter for any german meal.  The drawbacks - its lack of versatility and its too heavy to drink all night.

Awsome beer. Love the overallf lavor of this beer.  I can sell this to anyone who would like a great beer with not a huge heavy taset at trhe end.  People who do not like dark beers will like this beer. I want all I can get of this beer.

Pours deep red with a half-finger off-white head. Slight lacing, some effervescence. Aroma has all the maltiness expected from the style. Reminded me of a Sam Adams Chocolate Bock. Raisins and plums and chocolate liqueur. Sweet, toffee-ish flavor at the beginning, with more bitterness than Ayinger Celebrator. The bitterness detracts from the brew, somewhat. Ends with alcohol and leaves a taste of chocolate. Not nearly as smooth as the Celebrator, but still good.

Malty, slightly sweet aroma. Grape? Nice dark coloring, with smallish foamy head. Has a nice sharp initial flavor to it, with a mellow balanced finish. Carbonation is pretty negligible. Alcohol is well masked, considering it’s over 7. Wasn’t expecting anything, and I’m now a fan.
Bottle. Dark garnet body with a one finger foamy head. Some grape, dry spice, with a sharp palate. Reminds me of a flat Dr. Pepper. Warming alcohol edge. Nice.
pours a dark brown with little to no head.  a strong carmel aroma and taste is very dominate in this one . has a very sweet and rich flavor that makes this one hell of a beer
Nice smell. First thought: reminds me of the Birra Moretti La Rossa I just had. Much better than their pils i just had. A solid doppelbock.
Good flavored beer.  Rich caramel and roasted malt flavors dominate.  Deep brown color.  Still a step down from the Ayinger Celebrator Doppelbock (for German beers) in my opinion.
Brown color with caramel flavor.  Very smooth nothing outstanding as far as bitterness goes.   Thick but not very full as far as alcohol either.
Big fluffy head, body is rusted brown. Light malt aroma. Taste is molassis, brown sugar, and caramel. Medium to full bodied. Clean, bitter finish. Not bad.
Light caramel aroma with a light brown head.  A mild roasted and caramel flavor.  Some bitterness but not too much.

Rerate. Sampled on draft at Olde New York in State College PA this beer poured a dark ruby-chestnut color with a large dark tan head. The aroma was sweet, malty and had notes of molasses and ripe fruits. The flavor was sweet, tangy and very malty with ripe fruits and a tough of caramel. The mouthfeel was thick. Nice.
Great beer to grab a six pack of on a weekend. Great thick beer, with loads of roasted flavor.

Out of a bottle, aroma slight yeast, caramel, molasses, roasted malt.  Fills the glass nicely,deep dark brown thin off-white head.  Flavor is even keel, nice roasted malts and yeast mix well.  A smoothness fills your mouth with a subtle bitter sweet taste.  I originally had this on tap years ago and I loved it. Still a solid performer in my book.

Near black, when held to the light the glass shimmers with reddish hues.  Thick port like aroma. Plums and molasses.  Thin head sits for quite some time.  Creamy texture.  A good doppelbock, but not the gold standard.
Pours a deep brown w/ ruby hues and a medium head. Aromas of roasted malt and yeast. A nice creamy feel w/ roasted malt and a finish of smooth bitter sweetness.

sweet aroma consisting of carmalized sugar, yeast and hints of dried fruit.  the color was a nice dark brown with slight head that reduced to thin ring fairly quickly.  the flavor was exceptional.  yeasty  along with fruit cake and slight hoppy bitterness at the end.  the finish is a combination of bitter and sweet as well as a might bit fruity.  the mouth feel was nice a creamy.  nice roasty malt character as well.  an exceptional beer.  the flavor just kept on developing as it warmed.

I could sense a sweet caramel and a slight nutty flavor (?). Same with the aroma...sweet caramel.  Overall, it was decent, but I wouldn’t go out of my way to get it. It’s not as good as Ayinger Celebrator, in my opinion.

This dark brown beer poured with almost no head, eliciting a strong malt aroma. The flavor is of caramel, with a very thick mouth feel. If one is in the mood for a "heavy" beer, this one is very satisfying.
good head, sweet,i highly reccomend a taste. color was average. esy to drink more htan one

Aroma:Light fruit....
Appearance:Brown-orange,good withe head....
Flavor:Fruit,caramel and vegetable flavor...
Nice Doppelbock with rich sweet caramel and roasted malt flavors and aroma.  Unquestionably this brewery’s best product.  But falls well short of outstanding.

OK, not quite a Celebrator, but quite a delightful doppel bock.  Balance of malt and caramel.  Beautiful clear reddish brown with a good head that fades to lacing.  Disappointingly thin mouthfeel. // Lacks the complexity and intensity of a Celebrator.  Too sweet, not enough coffee / chocolate / espresso bitterness.  And alcohol too obvious.

Clear brown ale with a nice light moka head. Aroma of sweet malt, caramel and light molassey notes. A bit of cardboard (bought in Rochester at World of Beer, maybe bad storing). Good sweet malt with herbal notes, smooth alcohol, and light hops in finish. Oily mouthfeel, and rich. Very nice.

Optimator is everything you look for in a d-b. Warm, almost spicy malt aroma, medium, long-lasting lilght-tan head on a nice amber-hazel brew
Nice malty taste, with a hint of could it be nutmeg? Long slow aftertaste of malt and unsweetened chocolate.
The mouthfeel is thick and rich. This is really what I think of for a cool-weather German beer.

I gave it a low rating for appearance because the bottle is so plain- it looks like something they would sell at the 99 cent store. I had high expectations for this beer, since from my limited experiance German beers are quit tastey. Well, it let me down. The main thing for me was its high alcohol content, which made the flavor a little too strong for me. This paired with that darn bitter hops and well i just dont like the taste. I was expecting Beck’s type beer, but a little thicker . Boy was I wrong.

This remided me why I did not like it when I lived in Munchen.

Nice dark brown pour with a carmel  malty aroma.  Head is off white and diappates fast with very little lace.  Taste is overly sweetened malts with a bitter sweet mollases aftertaste.  

Not my choice for a doppelbock.
Pours brownish-red with beige head.  Great aroma of roasted malt.  Lots of malt in the aroma carrying through to the flavor.  Nice hop balance on the back end.  Chewy.  Nice Doppelbock.

Aroma is wonderful: malt all the way, with a light roasted malt influence; fresh, warm bread and coffee.  Appearance is dark reddish brown, translucent if held up to the light but opaque otherwise.  A small head develops on the pour that dissolves fairly quick, leaving a wafer-thin layer of foam on the beer for the remainder of the glass.  The flavor is like the aroma, sweet malt with a hint of roasting that floats right on the edge of detection.  A slight bitterness (very mild hops and again roastiness) surfaces after you swallow, and then disappears.  The palate is full and creamy, with mild carbonation that manifests itself in exquisite tiny bubbles.  An exceptional beer, and a great example of the traditional doppel.

Pours a dark, clear, mahogany. No wait, its a dark ruby red. Catches the light nicely. 1/2 inch tan head that dissipates and leave virtually no lacing. Smells like you would expect a doppelbock to smell: sweet and malty, malty, matly. 

Tastes of dark malt, burnt malt flavors. Sweet and (again) malty. Molasses flavors with a light bitter finish. Feels thick on the palate. The taste kind of slides down the back of your throat like a raw oyster. Warming as it goes down.

Quite drinkable to me, especially when the weather gets to changing up here. Smooth enough to have on a regular basis and a solid doppelbock.
En fût chez American Flatbread, VT. Caramel, malt, céréales, sucre candy... Très corpulente. Houblon de soutien. Très intéressante.
Deep red-amber color.  Thick pale amber head.  Smells of caramel and maple syrup.  Taste is sweet and medium bodied with caramel dominance.

Deep red in color with a thick amber head. Strong, sweet aroma with raisen, malt, caramel and a hint of vanilla. Big bodied with a clean, sweet roasty finish. Full flavors of alcohol, raisen, some earthiness and some spicy hops. Very nice.
Unusual color.  Great aroma.  Great robust flavor.  The finish and after-taste are a little strong.  This one gets better as it goes on.
ah -- the double shovel.  Dark and tasty.  a full flavor brew if there ever was one.   I always look foward to drinking this one.

500ml brown bottle.  Pours brown with red hues in the light...completely transparent...small off-white head is basically non-existent.  Chocolate, toasty aroma...somewhat insubstantial.  Drinks with some thickness...carmel flavors dominate, with a bit of tobacco thrown in along with some roastiness...finishes with a balancing hop bite.  A pretty rich beer.

Medium-brown colored with a red cast and a creamy, off-white head. Aromas teetered between lightly malted and doughy yeast, with a splash of soy sauce. Flavor started sweetly malted, receding to reveal a yeasty sourness and a hint of hops. Medium-bodied, but a little watery in the end. Not bad at $4.99 for 6.


Kenwood Liquors, Oak Lawn, IL
dark amber color with a  lasting white head.   unique flavor, caramel and malty.  smooth, sweet finish
Definitely not on par with Celebrator.  Not even in the same league.  Dark color with a white head.  Nice flavor with a dry roasty finish.  Easy to drink.  Pretty nice.

Tastes strange,  subtle hints of caramel, and toasted malt. Astringent alcohol flavor is too evident.
I’d say it’s no more than a pretty good malt liquor. In fact I would say it’s no different than O.E. 800 and a Twix bar.
A very common ghetto meal, all in one container. Man, those Germans are brilliant innovators. 
Served well with meatloaf and Camel Lights.
light nutty aroma.  very dark color.  tan head.  very full flavor.  i taste nuts, roasted grains, and chocolate.  fairly sweet.  very good beer.

Poured a very dark, almost opaque brown with a medium-sized white head. Nutty, roasted malt in the nose; flavor is rich ... roasted malts, caramel, maybe a touch of raisin and apricot. Nice lingering sweetness in the aftertaste. Excellent.

Bottle: a Doppelbock ehh?? Well has a light nose that is nutty and some soap aromas.  Head is fluffy and thick while sitting on a leather brown beer in a mug. A complex flavor that is made up of lot of little ingredients mainly of nuts, malt, hazel, raisin and other sweet dried fruit.  A roasted persona is also delivered through out the drink.
Poured a dark mahogany color with a medium tan head.  Flavors and aromas were sweet, malty and of dark fruits.  Medium bodied.  Warming sensation but rest of the alchol balanced and hidden.
This beer gives great head!!  It just lasts, and lasts, real frothy.  Real malty, nice and sweet, but not harsh, excellent level of carbonation.  Very drinkable, and extremely enjoyable.

Ran across this at Epcot a few weeks ago.  Enjoyed enough to go back for a second round (but three would have put me over the edge).  Richly malty, and overall pleasantly tasty.  Somewhat alcoholic but not overpowering.
Favorite beer.  Just keep coming back to it.  Especially: easy to find!  Great kick without strong taste of alcohol.  The malts really come through.
I dig this double bock.  It’s definately the best I can find at stores with relative ease.  Great appearance, nice malts, and not as sweet as some others out there.  Keep it up Spaten!

Deep ruby/mahogany color with medium loght-brown head. The aroma is very malty, with meladoidins apparent and some roastiness. The body is chewy with malty richness and more melaboidin caramel character. Very rich. The alcohol is hidden nicely.Not as big as some doppelbocks I have had but still very enjoyable.

Aroma is mild and wavering of dark caramel, slightly roasty toffee, dark cherry notes, and touches of molasses. 

Clear ruby-copper color up to the light, amongst the shadows it lurks as chestnut brown. Thin tan cap delevops late after the pour, surmounting down quickly to a very thin collar. Minimal spotty lacing which melts away.

Flavors are nice, starts a bit slow and wet but builds to some lightly chewy and medium richness of slender roasted caramel and toffee. Drops of sweet dark fruity things. Nice sticky finish of sweet caramel malts lingering.

Feel is about medium with a thicker sticking finish, a bit subdued and slim. Not as thick the whole way through nor as creamy as I would’ve liked to seen. This seemed just a bit weaker then I imagined it would be. Expectations sometimes are never met. Still good, just not great; so I’d have this again.

Nice thick light brown head.  Aroma is kinda acidic and has that sort of doppel fruitiness.  Nice brown - reddish color.  High alcohol content but its masked well.  Strong malty taste.  Feels nice in the mouth and goes down smoothly.  A decent doppelbock.

Color is a dark chocolate color but with a hint of red. Aroma is a bit winey but very good overall. Taste is nice and smooth with a lingering biterness and sweetness which hides the stronger alcohol content. Still, a bit winey for me. Like a weak barley wine. I won’t get it again, but for doppelbock lovers I would give it a try.
Beer poured with a small head. Very dark brown with a reddish hue. Lots of aroma & flavor

A heavy malt scented head that quickly fades.  Strong roasted malt flavor and bold taste are exactly what you would expect to find from a beer as dark as the Optimator.  My overall impression for this beer increased by two points alone just because of the Arnold accent you can use when saying the name...I’ll be back:)

Draft in an ice cold tall mug at Daanen’s Delicatessen in Hayden, Idaho. Tell them not to give you a frosted glass or shop their bottle selection while the beer warms. Big head. Poured out of a fresh keg. Dark brown. Light roasted aroma comes through. Flavours of wheat, yeast and roasted nuts.
Pours caramel-burgandy in color with a lacy, foamy head.  Lacks depth in the palate and aroma, but the little that is there is quite good.  Very easy drinking.

Zis ist one ov zhe best Doppelbocks brewt. A vunderbah aroma unt flavor dat has flavors ov many kinds. Perfect ist der balanceink vhich makes me easy drinkink zis bier.
Earlier Rating: 1/4/2005 Total Score: 4.3
Perfectly balanced beer with a great flavor complexity. Many distinct flavors roll across your tongue as you drink the beer to it’s finish, leaving you wishing you could afford just one more.

Beautiful in the pour, dark brown with a large creamy tan head.  Aroma is good with notes of sweet dark malt and fruits.  Flavor is excellent, deep and complex.  Malts, molasses, caramel, dark fruits and rum.  A little bitter on the end.  Mouthfeel is right where its supposed to be..  full and rich but not cloying, enough carbonation to keep it lively.  Man this hits the spot after a long day at work.  Its already on the shopping list to buy more next trip to the bottle shop.   Excellent!!

Bottle poured dark brown with a good head and little lacing.
Very light aroma of malt.
Flavor is just a bit to sweet for my taste.

Rich, dark brown with a creamy tan cap, this has a bready aroma with deep scents of caramel and toffee in the nose.  Smooth and full-bodied, this is sweet yet strongly roasted, caramel and coffee coming through in the center.  Well balanced hopping keeps it all from becoming cloying.  Nice malty finish.  Time for another.
Freshy fruity aroma, backed with a little bit of dusky malt. Decent lacing on thin off-white head. Quite still. Rich and meaty. Great burnt barley flabor that lingers on palate. Complex and deep.
Awesome beer that hides its low alcohol content quite nicely.  Not for the faint of heart, this one packs a not so subtle punch.
Kind of fruity. Real good though. Especially if you like fruity beer. Smells like my dog on a rainy day. But dogs are supposed to be muddy and this beer is supposed to smell that way.
Pours dark ruby with a big off white head. Big raisin, plum aroma. Hints of alcohol linger as well. Taste is sweet and malty with plum notes. Smooth and rich. Good doppelbock.
Only from the bottle. Smells like something wet and left out for a while.  Hearty, like sweet bread.  Bit of an aftertaste.
Nutty, malty aroma.  Beige head, dark brown color.  Malty, rich flavor.  Slightly bitter aftertaste.  A very enjoyable beer.

Bottle (aged for 10 months). Pours a clear brownish amber, with a nice full head.  Aroma starts sour, dusty, and stale with a roasty, spiced earthly background. Maybe some slight skunkyness, but nothing bad at all.  Flavor is a nice molasses caramel roasted sweetness, with a thin but effervescent body.  Aged well, rounded out the sweetness.
Really enjoyed this one. Had it on tap at a local pub. Well roasted flavor with some sweetness.
A dark amber appearance with a great head that fades slowly and that’s it. No smell, no real taste. Carbonation spice and medium-light mouthfeel. Some malt in aftertaste. Nothing offensive
Dark ruby/brown in color. Aroma very light malt. Flavor is malty with some dark fruits. Prune/fig? Was a little dissapointed.

Bottle:  Malty molasses aroma.  Pours a dark transparent orangish-brown with a small white head.  Extremely light malt up front, just a light caramel.  Decent malt finish with molasses.  Light hops in there too.  Finish gets sweeter with caramel as it warms.  Decent, just not as flavorful as other doppelbocks.

i dont have a stein so i stuck this into a duvel glass.i got a nice head with a very attractive red body.the aroma gave me malts ,carmel,and candy.i was impressed with the taste.nice balanced flavors of malts,hops,yeast,and figs.its alot like a belgian quad.this is very good.

at first taste                                                 I thought!! ooww what did I buy 
I addmit the first taste sucked’ but then your dieing for some more!! well it’s my sixed taste and I say its preety good beer!! roasted malt flovor’’ very smooth texture’ cant stop drinking it’’ love it .
This is a really decent beer that I had on tap.  Nothing too special though.  I wasn’t sure what style it was before I looked on this site, but there are much better dopplebocks available out there.
A very deep, yet clean mahogany body with  little head. Very strong caramel character with some chocolate and a bit of spice. This one really began to grow on me as the glass began to empty.

When I found out that this was a dopplebock I thought good because I lke dopplebocks and hoping it would be like my fravorite beer, celebrator.but no . but still a good beer. poured a light granet color with a light tan head. aroma, malts, yeast, chocolate, some alcohol, and a nice sweet sourness, hints of toffee. flavor, roasted malts, dark fruits, maple syrup, molasses, raisins.

on tap.  this is one of my favorite brews at the local BierStube.  pours a reddish brown with a quickly disappearing head.  rich malt flavor but yet not too sweet or overpowering citrus like so many German brews.  a solid doppel!
Very dark appearance, heavy full-bodied beer. Head dissapated quickly, first taste noted of caramel or molasses flavors. An outstanding German beer, Prost!
Nice reddish brown dark color with a spicy malty aroma. Very full in taste with malt and spice. Neither watery nor too strong. A great find.
This was a Christmas gift.  The color was a rich dark hue.   The head faded quickly.  There are hints of spices and plenty of malt.  The beer grew on me.
A clean white head sitting on a black, opaque brew.  The head faded quickly. Good body, nice aftertaste.

If the bottle was brown this would be the perfect beer. Pours a gorgeus copper color with an enourmous creamy tan head that rises about an inch above the rim before settling into a landscape of montains and valleys. Aroma is sweet and full of malt, malt, and more malt. Big bursts of fresh wort fill the nose. One smell and you know exactly how this beer will taste. Flavor is sweet with outrageous malt character and some subtle hops flavors in the palate. Finishes with a kick of alcohol and a sweet malty goodbye.
A spaten tanker glass from tap. Twas HUGE! Dark plum/amber colour. Smooth dark fruit(raisin, plum) with some spice and a bit roast. good doppelbock.
This was my first time having the beer.  It was good.  Full bodied with a deep dark color and rich roasted malt flavor.

Talk about your pleasnt surprises...  Pretty dark ruby; large, beige, frothy head.  Nose bready; dark fruits and malt.  Flavor bready, plum, alcohol.  Thick enough but too sticky for my tastes.  Not bad for such an inexpensive beer.

Mild aroma of malts and a deep brown color. The head was creamy and white, but thinned out and left a thin layer that worked its’ way down the sides of the glass. Very smooth taste, hints of cinnamon and maybe licorice.  Not the heaviness of a stout, but has the fullness of one.  After having 2 light lagers, this was a great change, adding fullness and complexity to my rating session.
Dark brown and minimal head.  Nice dark flavor. more rasin than carmel and smooth with cinimon and spice hints.  A very easy drinking beer with some decent flavor.

Bottle. Brown foam, dark brown color and ok lace. Highly malty with caramel, very little hop flavor, this has a dense viscosity. Nice heavy beer in the German dopplebock tradition - this guy packs a punch!
Very nice beer, very flavorful. A little on the lighter side for a Doppelbock but still strong. Cooked a little sausage, peppers and onions in this and it was wonderful.
Doppelbock’s aren’t really my thing.  That being said this one was pretty good.  The taste had a really strong raisin quality to it.  It went down pretty easily.

Slight re-rate based on inconsistencies.  Still, it’s one of the better widely available doppelbocks, and for  $5.99, it’s going to be a good call.  Medium to dark amber, moderate to heavy viscosity and rich chocolate and caramel malts.  There have been several times when I’ve had this one when the flavor hasn’t been consistent and it’s been somewhat muted, taking on a more bubblegum flavor and deviating from the malt onslaught that I enjoy about this one, and hold it to each time.  At its best, this could be a 4.5 as a result of its fine use of caramel and chocolate malts to sweeten it to a brown sugar-laden liquid bread.  I need to see this remain consistent before I move my rating up again.
bottle. that nice sexy brunette color... toffee and nutty aroma... flavor pretty ordinary.... sweet with a slight tang in the finish
A deep red beer with a collapsing off-white head. The aroma is sweet with notes of alcohol, hops, and berries. The flavor is dry with notes of roasted bread and hints of alcohol.
Brown color with a beige head. The taste is sweet malty with light nutty notes. Finishes a little to quick.
Dark red-brown color, light sweet fruity aroma and raste, medium body, light dry finish.
Alcoholic aroma. Rather dry, alcoholic and sweet. Lots of carbonation. Even a bit sour in end and aftertaste. Boring.
Brown coloured. Malty aroma. Fruity, malty and sweet flavour with caramelly notes. Good beer, but slightly boring for a Doppelbock.
Yum! Not the best in it’s category but very drinkable. Had a great malt taste with a bit of a dry finish. Felt very thick and sticky.
great complex nose, fruity and tart yet malty and dry, tan/brown body, sweet apple ciderish bock flavor, mild roastiness, rolling mouthfeel, not only is it good, it’s the cat’s pajamas.
Reddish amber, small beige head. Aroma of malt. Hugely malty flavor, caramel and roastiness. Not much hop presence. Full body.
Dark brown hue.  Very roasty, caramel dominated flavor.  Enjoyable.  Decently thick mouthfeel with a sweet finish.  Very nice.

Red/brown color with a medium size tan head. Sweet malt aroma with hints of
caramel. Flavor is mostly sweet malt and
caramel with a touch of hops on the finish. Rich, thick mouthfeel.
Really strong one, nearly out of a beer description, but it’s ok really dark and sawer.

Bottle.  A nice ruby brown, deep and dark.  Beige head that moves on quickly.  Aromas of malt and caramel.  Feels rich and full in the mouth, with flavors of molasses and an overwhelming smoke.  It’s dry and when you swallow, you catch the bitter bit towards the end.  The dryness makes you ready for another taste, the alcohol warms your throat.

Pours into my Celebrator glass a nice deep red-brown with a nice looking foamy head. Looks just as good as any Dopple, in my opinion. Smells strongly of molasses, sugar, and nice gentle, noble hops, some roasted vegetables. Smells like a Dopplebock. Initial taste is quite pleasant. Smooth and creamy across the palate, but not so much so that it bogs down my tongue. Rather delightful, with tastes of molasses and chocolate, coupled with a nice balancing bitterness. To me, this holds up with some of the better beers I’ve had. Definitely drinkable and enjoyable, as the finish does not linger and the alcohol lets you know it is there. A very nice beer.

Bottle. Really odd "Two Deathly-pale Shovels" logo. Pours dark carmel with lots of short-lived tan head. Pleasant roasty malt smell. Some floral notes, a bit of pine, and a hint something that reminds me of a marsh. (In a good way.) Nice smooth dark malt and carmel tastes. Clean on the palate. No linger between tastes. Very pleasant and smooth.

Bam!  This brew will hit you hard and mercilessly...and thats a good thing. Sweet and caramel malty the alcohol content of this brew is apparent in the aroma, and flavor. Warming, but not overdone, the giant-headed bronze beast has a sweet lingering malty aftertaste. A slight bitterness makes itself known at the mid-point. Nicely done!

Floral notes and caramel to the nose from a brew that pours red-brown and has a thin off-white head that laces poorly.  Flavor is candy apple, caramel, malt, plum, and raisin.  Creamy/oily mouthfeel, medium body, much lighter than other Dopplebocks I’ve tried.  Overall OK but there are better examples out there.

Hands down the best beer I’ve ever had. Nice long lasting flavor that lingers in your mouth long after you have finished the beer. Deep rich dark red color with caramel colored foam, wonderful taste, whichever ingredients were used in this beer it is the best, no wonder Spaten has been making beer since 1397.

Pours a brilliantly clear ruby-amber color when held up to the light, otherwise a drab deep amber.  It is topped by a frothy tan head that is held up by a medium-low carbonation.  The aroma is a bit lighter than I was expecting, it is malty and bready with notes of molasses, caramel, and a light sweetness.  The beer is malty sweet with a smooth finish that has a hint of dark malt character reminiscent of chocolate.   The beer is quite a bit more tasty than the aroma suggests.  Somewhat light on the palate, though only in so much as I was expecting it to be a bit thicker, it is actually about medium full in the body.  In the end this seems to be lacking a little bit of malt character, though it is quite tasty, it just does not distinguish itself enough from a "standard" Bock.
Very dark reddish brown color.  Small tan head.  Aroma is sweet malt.  Medium  body with roasted malt and chocolate flavors.  Smooth finish. Classic German dopplebock.
The whole of this beer is greater than the sum of its parts: thin-bodied but smooth, sweet but not cloying; crisp but not hoppy.

12oz bottle: Pours a dark red in the glass with a tan head. Has an almost molasses aroma to it. The taste has a vague hint of coffee and sweet malt. I’m normally not a big fan of dark beers but this is a good one.
Red in color. This brew really sneaks up on you. Great for saturday nights, and football games in front of the telly.

Very little hop aroma in this dark ruby/brown brewr. Smell is of unfermented wort, like homebrew before you pitch the yeast. Nice and sweet like it should be, with a full mouthfeel. Boy is this thick and roasty malty.  There is a nice complexity here....chocolate, caramel, and toffee notes.  Slight, very slight hop bitterness on the finish that just keeps it from being cloying.   And reasonably priced to boot.  This isn’t my favorite style, but this  is a nice example.
tap. dark reddish brown color and thin.  nice sweet taste.  goes down nice and smooth.  good.

In the 0.5L bottle. Pours a reddish dark brown to black much like a coke. Beige head. Aroma of sweet caramel and molasses. Heavy, high gravity sweet malt flavor. The head disappears pretty quickly into the beer. This is really good stuff. I wish that it had just a kiss of the hops, though. The molasses flavor is just a little too sweet without a good hop balance.

Appearance: dark, chestnut brown, light- reddish at bottom, with a thick, full 1" toffee-toned, slowly settling.
Aroma: mild and dry, nutty, but assuredly unfolding with malt.
Taste: here’s where it’s happening: enormous malt, good, chewy mouthfeel, warm, delicious, generous with flavor. Swims in the mouth with vigor. Nutty, malty, warm, yet still clean and well-behaved. A nice, if tame, doppelbock.

I haven’t rated this yet?  Roasted, sweet malt aroma.  Brownish bronze color.  Taste is sweet up front with a slightly bitter and sour finish.  Some chocolate, butter, and citrus in the flavor also.  Like others have said, the body is thin, but it makes it more drinkable on this hot summer day.  An all time favorite of mine.

Bottle.  Sweet brown sugary caramel nose.  Slight roastiness in the aroma as well.  Transparent mahogany with a light tan head.  Sweet and malty to start with hints of chocolate and banana later on.  Rather thin.
Tap.  Reddish brown in color.  Nice head.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee.  Taste is roasted grain.  Not quite as smooth as Celebrator.  Some hops noticable.  A little thin.

Appearance is a dark brown with some red showing when its held up to the light. Aroma is dark fruit and nuts. The flavor is slightly sour and it hides the alcohol very well. I taste bitter chocolate, sour grapes, and caramel. The body is a little thin but its still quite tasty.

Draft at Yeoman’s Road Pub in Tampa. One of my least favorite Doppelbocks. This one is just too thin to me. Also lacks some of the more robust flavors that stand out in other doppelbocks. Not as roasty and malty.

Minimal aroma.  Pours dark reddish brown, uniform color.  Small creamy off-whtie head.  Tastes mildly sweet, toasty, trace of fruit.  Alcohol is perceivable.  Body is nice, not too carbonated but definitely not flat.  Finish is earthy, with a mix of sweet and bitter.  Pretty easy to drink.
Reddish brown, no head, with a big malty, spicy aroma. Heavy palate, bready, toasty milky flavor, with pronounced notes of fruit. Crisp, slightly earthy hop finish.
Ruby red cola color,minimal head. Malty roasty nose and roasty semi dryish taste with a malt edge. Not as good as the Salvator but not bad at all.
This beer smells like skunk, but actually turns out to be quite a tasty little beer.  Worth a try at least.
This is a heavy beer. Nice dark ruby body, light on the head. toasted flavor and quite a kick.
Not too much head on this brew. Has a really nice dark color. Nice roasted flavor.Some sweetness is noticable along with a hint of alcohol. Very nice bite to it. Overall very good.
Pours dark brown with an attractive head...smells very sweet of chocolate and alcohol...tastes very sweet and very toasty...mild alcohol finish...

Poured an attractive dark burnished brown with a nice light smooth head and excellent lacing.  Aroma was of crisp, grassy hops, followed by a nice balance of hopped bitterness and roasted maltiness.  A bit thin in the mouth, but full of warming, pleasant flavor.  A really well-balanced beer.
Deep brown with decent head. Nice malty aroma. Sweet malt flavor. You don’t notice the alcohol at all. Not as complex as some double bocks.
Dark brown in color with a nice tan head. Roasty malty flavor. Full bodied beer. Dark and rich in body. Excellent beer. Well balanced beer.

The old double bock stand-by. And only if everyone were optimated. Refined malty aroma, with munich malt hints and conditioning effects noted as well. Big malty flavor, munichy and some hints of chocolate. There are better double bocks, but none are so readily available when you have a craving, and no matter how you cut it, this always comes up good....

Pours a dark brown with an off white head. Malty aroma. Taste is sweet with that roasty nutty molasses flavor. Good alcohol presence. Mouthfeel is full and round. Pretty good but could use more complexity.
Poured dark with a little white head and has a coffee aroma, This is too sweet for my liking, I didn’t enjoy this much, I could only drink one.

A bit sweet and heavy, but almost too good to be available in a six pack. Rich dark color with a coffee and molasses aroma. Very malty, slightly alcohol flavor that ends with a bit of hop. Great beer.

12 oz. green, longneck bottle. No freshness date noted, but none should be needed at this ABV. Poured out a dark amber, light brown color, with a short lived, tan colored head. It slid back to a thin ring of foam around the rim of the glass. Aromas are of easy roasted coffee, the kind you used to have on Saturday mornings.
Slight yeastiness, along with maltiness galore. It has the appearance of a fine, dark rum, as it is very clear. Tastes are of roasted malts, dark honey, some fruity notes, mainly figs, and dates. Very aromatic, and the aromas change as it warms slightly.
Medium thick mouthfeel is deceptive. Coats the tongue with maltiness, but never cloying. Finishes semi-sec, and with a note of hops in the final draw. A well made, if mainstream doppelbock.
Hides it’s alcohol very well. Deceptively drinkable.

Reddish brown body is the color of cola with a fizzy beige head that is not around for very long.  The aroma is roasted cracked grains and dry fruits mixed with powdered chocolate.  The taste is sweetly malty, fruity (figs, raspberries, and apple), musty, and faintly smoky.  The flavors don’t meld together quite well and mouthfeel is one step on the harsh side of creamy.  The alcohol is not well covered, but is not strong enough to be a distraction.  Hop bitterness is well in check, and only presents itself in the dry aftertaste.  A good deal at under $2 for a 500 ml. bottle at Green’s on Buford Highway.

This pours a very dark brown with a small off-white head consisting of cheaper looking bubbles that die off quickly.  There is very little lacing.  The nose is sweet and the alcohol is quite prevalent.  The mouthfeel is somewhat thick and syrupy with mild carbonation.  The taste consists primarily of a honey sweetness with a light nutshell/roasted aspect.  With very little bitterness, the malts and alcohol keep it interesting enough.  It’s very filling.
Standard bock aroma of caramel and malt. Full bodied and sweet.  Any sweeter and it would be hard to drink.  Flavors of malt, wood, and caramel.  Yeast aftertaste.  Good.

bottle-pours deep crimson amber with small tan head-rocky.  arom is sweet and maltu but a tad cardboardy.  flavors are sweet, earthy, bready with some diacital.  This one held up ok due to the high abv, but it still maybe pretty old.  a good doppelbock.  fizzy mouthfeal.

This is a strong dark redish brown with an off-white head.   Malty aroma and noticable strength.  Flavor is malty and a bit smokey and the alcohol is noticable but not overpowering.  There is a small sourness to it and you can definately tell it’s a strong beer.

Caramel malt aroma. Deep red color with huge, off-white head. Smooth with a fairly high alcohol presence. Very enjoyable with a great, easy drinking palate. Under carbonated. Would be better if it had some extra bite from carbonation.

Bottle into small plastic tasting cup, Humulus Lupus @ Jak’s Tap (Chicago).  I don’t know why this was at a summer beer tasting, but oh well.  It’s good, but I have liked all doppelbocks I’ve ever had.  Smelled malty and yeasty.  Brown with a reddish tint, some light brown head.  Taste was delicious: milk chocolate with some unsweetened chocolate (bitter), hop bitterness on the end.  That makes it sound more complex than it actually seemed.  Fruity coffee at the beginning of the finish, which lasted a good time.  Soft carbonation in the mouth and smooth.

Pours a dark brown/red color with a quickly dissipating head.   Bready aroma with roasted malts.   Very rich taste with some chocolate, vanilla, malt and coffee.  The alcohol is noticable and lingers well into the aftertaste. I had to knock off a few points for it’s flat appearance, but that’s about it.  This one will warm you up.

The body is the cola/ruby mixture. There’s not a lot of head. The smell has a bit of blanched corn and brown sugar with a slight bit of prunes. The flavor brings in a bit of toffee and chocolate. This was one of the beers we passed around the table at 5 Season’s July 1st party in Atlanta to celebrate the Georgia’s newly raised ABV limit on beer.

Pours dark brown.  Aroma of malt, prunes, and some almond.  Tastes very malty, with well hidden alcohol, and a very smooth, malty finish.  Some sweet brown sugary and pruney flavors set in as it warms.  Nice solid mouthfeel.  This is an excellent beer.
Sweet alcohol nose. Dark brown color. The flavor is rich and smokey with some sweet bitterness. A pretty good beer.
Dark Coloring.  Not a very bold beer, but very good flavor, definitly worth trying out.

Very dark almost black in color with a medium tan head. Smells like something you don’t want to drink. Has a sweet malty roasted fig taste with spices. Not overly impressive right away, but gets better with each swig.

Had a hint of skunk to it when first opened, but after it settled there was a coffee/toffee aroma.  Very good dark roasted taste.  I had this with some bagel bites and they complemented each other well. Very impressed with this purchase.
a dark beer with a medium tan head.  a subtle coffee taste, that doesn’t taste as strong as it is.  hey, it optimated me.

A strong pungent aroma of a classic bock cailbre beer. Deep cola like copper/amber appearance. The flavor is quite strong and very malty. This leads to the mouth feel being impressivly heavy as the flavor lingers longer than a typical schwartzbere. I would highly recommend this with grilled foods and smokey barbeque.

Bottled, filtered? Dark reddy brown with thick malty head. I have been hanging on to this for a while and the Germany Holland game seemed appropriate. So much flavour with a spiciness, cloves and vanilla notes with underlying caramel toffee notes. Sipping beer that lasted the match. I enjoyed the beer anyway.
Dark amber. Light froathy tan head on the pour. Smell of fruit and chocolate. Taste of hops. Bitter fruit taste. Tangy. Taste of caramel and roast. smooth on the palate.

Dark brown, hazelnut. Thick slightly tannish head. Nose of caramel, alcohol, roast malts and bitter hops. Anise and caramel flavors. Slight smoke. Roasted malts. Some fruits. Fig or plum. Thick bodied, malty palate and a bitter finish of alcohol.
Nice thick tan head, malty aroma with hints of hops.  Very smooth, somewhat thick to the palate.  Lots of caramel flavor, very sweet.  A pretty good beer.

Pours a dark leathery brown color with not much carbonation; head that is a creamy pale brown.  Smells like a sweet toffee with a bit of chocolate.  Tastes semi sweet like licorice with some bitterness; prunes.  Not as sweet as paulaner salvator which is too sweet IMO.  Creamy mouthfeel that sticks on the tongue.  This is a great beer that I could drink every week.

I found this beer to be quite interesting. An amalgam of bitterness is how I describe the taste. Quite pleasant, but initially a little caustic. Body is a translucent chestnut, looks good.  The taste grew on me, very good.

clear dark brown, off white head.  aroma of toffee, red liquorice, jelly candy, wood and alcohol.  mild soy flavour.  quite sweet with some mixed dried fruit notes and buttery flavours.  some earthy bitterness.
Reminds me of a less-complex Celebrator. Pruney alright but it’s without the chocolatey bitterness. Not at all bad though and worth my $1.90 easy.

Nice pour of dark brown malt fizz.  There was more carbonation and yeast than expected, both of which helped me identify this more in the Belgian Category.  Are we sure there isn’t some Candi Sugar in this one?  There doesn’t appear to many any smokiness found in others of the style - rather a fig/prune presence dominates.

pours a brown mohagany with a off white head. malty cookie like aromas with chocolate and mabey figs. sweetish malt, chocolate, dark fruit and nuts. drying bitterness balance toward the end. almost too sweet. full bodied leaving a sticky feel in the mouth. not my preferenc but it does fit within the style snugly.
Plump earthy figs dabble with caramel, but don’t use enough to elevate complexity...Burnt notes appear in the end and mix with slight oxidation...A competent but complacent bock...Thanks Kimchee!...

Sweet chocolate with almonds and subdued plums, raisins and dates in the aroma. Ruby brown with tan head that recedes to cover. Chocolate and dark fruit sweetness with balancing roastiness. Earthy, sweet and malty. Effervescent mouthfeel. Medium body. I find this to be a rather restrained example of a doppelbock. It’s a decent beer, but doesn’t have that over the top flavour explosion I’ve come to associate with the style. Bottle (enjoyed with MartinT, mr_kimchee, Oakes and Rastacouere).

Bottle enjoyed with Kimchee, tiggmtl, Oakes and martint  Thin light brown head, fully diminishing over a medium brown body. Aroma is loaded with peat malt, you feel the barley. It’s pretty well blended, chocolatey with notes of several dark fruits lie dates and figs. Taste is very earthy, leafy even with smoked tobacco suggestions. The focus seems to be really kept on peat malt. Obviously very malty and rather sweet, like a dusty toffee sponge. Low carbonation, medium bodied. While not astounding, this remains a satisfying beer, nutty and peaty, but I love rich malt and obviously doppelbocks and while I prefer this over salvator, it doesn’t bring me close to the big smile a celebrator does once again.

Personally I rank it just behind Salvator and Celebrator.  Malty, syrupy and full candied body roasted  taste.  Like it should be; fyi, for those lighter beer drinkers.  Have one for desert or your sipping pleasure.  Heck,have two.

Tap- One of the best beers I’ve had in a while.  Dark, rich head, chocolate malts, with a hoppy, clean aftertaste.  This beer has perfect balance, making it easy to drink several, although could be dangerous because hardly noticed the alcohol at all.  Wasn't quite as good when I had it later out of the bottle, but still very good.
Deep rich brown-ruby color. Little to no head out of bottle. Very smooth and satisfying.I really enjoyed this one.

The BEST beer PERIOD. It is definitely for those who like a STRONG, RICH beer. 

The taste will definitely over power those who prefer a light beer.

Salty Brew. I went through a serious German beer phase. For months all I would drink would be Hacker-Pschorr Dunkel Weiss, Schneider Aventinus, and this brew. This brew is the drinkingest doppelbock on the planet. Pours a nice deep brown hue. Lovely off white head.Smells like it’s gonna rock the mouth. Salty, malty and sweet all at once. Has that characteristic carbonated touch in the bouquet that all bottom fermented beers i’ve tried have. Tastes like a thick carbonated soy sauce. Mix this with a caramelly thickness that rounds out the alcohol well in the back of your palate and you have this brew. Very drinkable. Go get a sixer....wai better in the pint bottle than the sixer get a pint bottle.
Rock-it!
G-rat
A sweet, kind of fruity taste; malty in both aroma and taste.  I wasn’t terribly impressed, but it is good.

bottle 12 oz. Very dark, clear amber/brown with mahogany tint. Good straw head that fell rather fast. Aroma of cooked amber/caramel w mild hops. Flavor is of cooked caramel/chocolate malt with light European hops. Has that European bottled beer flavor. Medium bodied. Somewhat bitter, herbal, slightly sweet malt flavor. Wasn’t very impressed at first but went well with roast chicken and brown rice w broccoli rabe.I  kept sniffing the empty glass. Would probably rate higher if I wasn't so new to its flavor.

[bottle] Pours a deep ruby red with a very thin and quickly dissipating head. Aroma of malt and caramel mixed with a touch of apples. Initial taste of sweet malt mixed with a finish of cloves and bitter. Very interesting taste with a warm alcohol finish.
Garnet in color.  Tan head.  Aroma is malt, caramel, maybe some dark bread.  Medium body.  Somewhat sweet malt to the taste.  Decent stuff.

Bottled.  Pours clear, dark brown.  Smallish, off-white head; no lacing.  Liquid is clear, "merlot" colored in glass, dark brown with red enough to put it somewhere between cherry and mahogany.  Aroma freshly poured is strongly yeasty like dough with very sweet caramel malts and light cloves.  As beer warms, it smells like bananas foster and cloves with intensely malty aroma bringing out the caramel from bananas foster(alcohol too).  Drinking this was very nice.  Medium body, sweet front of caramel malts, soft carbonation and a strangely bitter, semi-dry finish dominated by cloves.  Nice duration, there just long enough to make sure you get to examine it and gone.

just retried this at a local german restaurant. much better than i had previously rated. great, thick head, made a nice beer to look at. solid dark beer. solid malt taste. consistent flavor. this is a good beer.
Dark Amber/Brown color, little head, aroma was slightly of hops, and caramel.  Tasted of Caramel, Not nearly as good as Celebrator, but a good substitute.

Rating 200.  Bottle, 3/30/04.  This pours a deep mahoganey brown.  Ample head is mostly fading to a stable halo with very little lacing in my freshened Duvel glass.  Aromas of prune, lightly roasted malts are thoroughly presented over a nutty, maple base.  Flavors of brown bread, plum, hazlenut.  Simple, but quite tasty.  No real bitterness.  Not very sweet.  Palate is a bit thin, wet, but not cloying or overly sweet.  This is a great beer in its simplicity.  Elegant like an everyday wine.  As lagers go, this is one of my favorites...but, what's with the green bottle mine came in?
This Doppelbock was so filling and strong that I only needed one to feel a buzz.  It was malty with a hint of fruit.  A great beer.

I think fellow Iowa City beer-meisters Heemer and HeyKevin pretty much hit it on the head in their reviews below. I was also disappointed in this. My little beer-loving soul made a tiny leap for joy when I walked into the beer room at John's today and saw cases of this on display. (Has this ever been available around here?) I managed to calm down enough to refrain first from springing for a case and then from picking up a six pack, choosing the cautious route of going with just a single bottle at $1.79 for sampling purposes. It's too sweet, not cloying like Sam Adams Double Bock, but just a hair's breadth away from that unpleasantness. It has a pretty good full mouthfeel, the kind you expect from an authentic German beer, but the taste just wasn't all that pleasant. Like Heemer, I think my first thought was also how nice it would be to find a cheaper version of Ayinger Celebrator. But the money spent on Celebrator is worth it. If nothing else, this beer has increased my appreciation for Celebrator, as well as for Kulmbacher Eisbock and Aventinus Weizen eisbock. As I think Heemer and HeyKevin note, there is indeed a certain sweaty sock smell/taste or sourness here that is a bit difficult to identify. Is it in the malt, the yeast? I notice this in just about everything by Spaten, though, even in their relatively more satisfying Oktoberfest-Ur-Marzen. It's a distinguishing characteristic about Spaten and an unpleasant one at that, not unlike a slightly skunked fake German beer like Becks or St. Pauli Girl. I'm glad I tried this, to satisfy my curiosity, but this isn't worth the 10 bucks a six pack it's going for at Johns. (Side note: at the same time I picked this up I also got a single of Capital's WInter Skål, because of the good things I've read lately about the beer and my own inability to remember exaclty what this tasted like. I was surprised to find that I liked the Capital bottle better than the Spaten doppelbock. Go figure.)
Dark amber color with smallish head. Aroma was yeasty, nutty and malty. Flavor was a sweet malt with caramel. Very well balanced with a nice mellow hop finish.

Nice malty beer that is on the sweet side. Roasted notes with caramel, coffee, light chocolate and dark fruits. Light dryness in finish. Alcohol is detectable in the flavor but in low quantities. A good doppelbock that was a bit more mild than I expected.

Bottle pours a dark coke like garnet with a small tan head.  The aroma is of slightly roasted malt.  The flavor is sweet and roasted with some sour fruit accent in the lingering finish.  The palate is rich and fairly carbonated.  Overall, a pretty good Doppelbock.

I was let down by this one. After reading reviews and raves, I thought, great a cheaper way to get something along the lines of Celebrator. While this is good, it is not of the same quality. From a bottle. Had a biege head that slowly dissapated. Aroma has flowers, malt and slight sweat socks. The flavor starts out very sweet, then mellows out. The malt seems less pronounced as you go through the glass. This is a very good dopple bock, but probably a little overrated.

Heavy brown in colour with thin frothy brown head that is short lasting with great lacing on the glass. The nose is full of alchol, caramel malts rich in the nose. The taste is rich in alcohol and malts. Alcohol vapour are quite present. Malts! Great! Medium body with sharp and vapourish in the tip of the tounge. Overall, Great.

Dense light tan head of very fine bubbles.  Reduces to a thin creamy foam.  Great lacing with minimal carbonation.  Interesting earthy aroma of wet oak, malt and biscuits.  Creamy roasted malt flavor that is a little thick and syrupy.  Finish is creamy and smooth with a sweet malty finish.  A very good dopplebock if you like the style and it is relatively cheap for the quality.

Deep cola color, medium head lasts all the way. Plenty of carbonation. Aroma of grass and sweet butterscotch. Alcohol is present in the taste. Smooth mouthfeel. Finish is a bit astringent. Not bad overall.

This beer is considered a dark beer but is a cross between a nice dark brown beer and an amber.  The head was about 1-2 cm and the aroma was nice and sweet.  Taste was also nice and sweet with a rich and creamy feel to it.  The beer was not very stout compared to say English stouts but was not really a true doppelbock either.  Aftertaste was full but nothing unique. A good pick up, especially since other Spaten beers are normally not for everyone.

May tend a bit toward the "mass market" for doppelbocks, but still rates very high, and has long been a favorite since I began my ratings in 1994; Very malty, sweet, alcoholic and with a moderately strong palate bite; Mild hops presence balances the malt to some degree, but the sweet maltiness is still the salient flavor; The only complaint is that the sweetness is possibly a bit too sugary; The flavor finishes about the same as it starts, with perhaps a bit more hops kicking in and is modestly sharper on the palate; The beer's color is mahogany with an orange hue; The head is somewhere between off white and light tan and has average retention
Slightly earthy toasted malt/alcohol aroma.  Big head that fades quickly, rich brown.  Rich malt, nicely bitter.  Somewhat sweet finish.

Pours a light reddish brown with a thin biege head that doesn't last. Aroma is sweet, smokey, and earthy. Caramel, brown sugar, dark fruits, and nuts on the nose. Nice mouthfeel, There's a little hop bitterness along with some roasted malts and some honey sweetness. Eventhough this was a good beer it seemed a little rough in a few places. It seems to lack the in quality that Celebrator or Maximator achieves.
This is a good, solid double. Nice malty, smokey flavor, slightly sweet with a fruity finish.

rich, smoky maltiness that isn't overly complex but is quite drinkable; doesn't compete with the likes of Celebrator or Maximator, but one or two are quite nice. Hellofva winter snack that could be served as main course.......

Deep dark brown in color, nice sized head that left no lacing behind. 
Sweet, with caramel malt and dark fruits dominating the palate, and a nice light hoppiness in the finish.  
A little too sweet for my tastes, but stil a good beer.
Mild chocolate aroma.  Malt flavor with a chocolate finish and a bit of alcohol in the finish.  I haven't had a doppelbock in a while and I don't think I'm too fond of this style.
Strong chocolate flavor, definitely a heavy malt.  Loved it you can find at Trader Joes, Cost Plus.

12 oz. green bottle: pours a transparent red-bronze.  Quite a pleasant aroma of hazelnuts, white grapes, wine (chardonnay), and sour raisins.  Roasted nut flavour with some good, thick caramel palate structure.  A slight bitter honey coats the tongue.  Rounded fruits, red apples, cherries, and plums finish off a solid Doppelbock.

Very unimpressive... I can't help but compare it to Ayinger Celebrator; and in so doing, this brew is very disappointing. Too much chocolate/coffee flavor, not enough hops to balance, and watery with a thin quickly dissipating head and meager carbonation. I expect better from Spaten.
Poured a dark amber color with a small head.Had a slight malty/raisin aroma to it.It had a taste of raisins/plum and a hint of nut to it.Pretty smooth mouthfeel.Not Bad
Dark mahoganey color with a small head. Aroma is malty with touches of chocolate and rasins. Smooth and malty, hints of plum and rasin. Some hops are evident in the finish. Nice doppelbock

Medium brown/Dark amber colour, medium-sized slightly yellowish head. Very moderate bitterness, sweet, yeasty. Strong flavour but not too intense. Reminds me of a stout. Paid $1.89 for this 25 oz. bottle, quite satisfied.

Rather large frothy head when poured; dark amber/brown color. Aroma is not particularly strong but flavor is full.  Starts sweet and crisp with a weak, somewhat bitter aftertaste. One of my favorites.

Pours Dark amber with good size head.  Aroma is weak.  A little sweet.  Taste, while not very bold, is good.  Starts very sweet with a good balance in hops.  A little acidic.  Finish is dry, but not very strong.  A small aftertaste.  A good beer, but needs more to be a favorite.
You could get hooked on this beer, but then you'd get sick too. Very nice sweetness and rich flavor, only downside may be carbonation that takes away from overall effect.

This is a good classic Doppelbock that just needs a little more assertion to be world class. Good deep color with rich ruby highlights. Sweet maltiness and an alcohol presence provide the rest. This could hide the alcohol just a little better to suit me. Just a tad coarse. Good beer nevertheless.
Not a bad doppelbock. Less flavor than an Andechser but not bad. Pours brown with a thick tan head. Light on the flavor and the alcohol becomes more present as it warms.
Thick dark beer that had a sweet taste.  You can't miss the alcohol but, you may have to wait before it show up.  Good over-all beer.
I don't like the taste of this beer. Too bitter. A lot of caramel flavor. Its like drinking a fermented candy if you can imagine that!. Very disappointed by this beer.

Dark brown, relatively clear appearance, good head formation. Bready malty aroma, dark fruits and alcohol. Rich malty palate, a little sherryish. Alcohol strength is certainly apparent. Sweet and fruity throughout.

Clear dark brown color with a quickly dissapating light tan head.  Not much to the aroma, mostly sweet roasted malt, reminds me of peachy chocolate.  I dislike the peach aroma, as I think it's the alcohol.  Thick mouthfeel.  The flavor has a winey chocolate thing with little hop bittering.  Peachy alcohol in the finish.  What I dislike overall about this beer is the fuity effervenscence.  Make it taste like Celebrator!

Not usually a fan of Spaten beer, I was surprised by the Optimator's sweet flavor. As others have noted, the alcohol comes through in the finish. If mass-produced German beers aren't your thing, try  the Optimator and you might be surprised.

Malty aroma. Pours with a rich head, however it is gone after a minute or so. Very dark, almost opaque beer.   Somewhat thick in body, leaves a malty sweetness on the tongue.  Slight hints of fruitness with very little bitter taste.  Overall I'd say excellent.
This is the first actual bock I had.  It's not a bad beer.  It tastes a little mediciny, though.
Very great dark beer equals a nice appearance, rich, slightly sweet flavor and plenty of head, which is even great tasting.  Very easy on the palate, a 4 star German beer.
Full bodied, roasted malt & chocolate flavored. Nice rich aroma and deep brown coloring.
Rich malty aroma, dark brown in appearance, rich hoppy flavor, not bitter. A great beer.

poured a dark brown with some garnet hues and a small creamy tan head. Nice sweet malty aroma. Medium bodied with a taste of sweet roasted caramel malt, toffee, and chocolate with somemhints of dark fruit. nice and creamy and very drinkable. A most enjoyable dopplebock.

Sweet flavor with a slight toffee nose and a very slight coffee finish. Light bitterness.

Aroma is all malt.

Dark appearance, thin head, very little lacing on the glass.

Smooth, creamy mouthfeel.

In the USA, Optimator has "Malt Liquor" printed on the label in fine print. Sorry, but my dead homiez won't share in this.

Great sweet perfectly roasted malty brew(one of my favorite german beers)Nice off white head w/some lace.First impresion was oh another dark german beer but the taste of this one will change your mind.Nice medium mouthfeel/very smooth/great malt/nice touch of hops to end in a slightly dry finish.Nice deep brown.This was pulled from the case so the green bottle didn't have a chance to affect this one.Very nice.

Perhaps I approached it with too high of expectations, but I was not overwhelmed.  A nicely malty front, with good color and enough clues to spark interest.  Creamy palate, but thin body.  Caramel and nut flavor, suggestions of chocolate, but nothing to really hold my interest.  I'll have to give it another try some day.
At first this beer seemed rather bland, but as i drank more of it, I noticed hints of choclate and coffee behind it already sweet malty taste.  Not a lot of hoppiness to it but still was great.

This beer is like an old friend..its been a while..
The beer looks fantastic poured into my mug..great frothy off white head atop a dark red /brown beer..very impressive.
As would be expected the malt is very evident in the aroma..also slight coffee and chocolate accents ..very inviting.
MM i like the taste of this beer..its slightly sweeter than many doppelbocks..but I believe it to be well balanced by the astringent after taste..and the dark chocolate flavour.Not the greatest but one of the best in my opinion.
Feels pretty comfortable on the tongue not too carbonated at all..smooth.
Overall a very very drinkable doppelbock..I have had better tasting Doppels but none as drinkable as this .
NOTES..This was my very first doppelbock..way back in 2001..LOL seems like a life time ago..my first real taste of German beer other than bloody Becks. It has fond memories for me..I first tasted it on a camping trip to the Oregon High Desert..me and the wife went to get over a terrible tragedy in our lives..I drank this out of the bottle ( 8 of them) It helped me forget for a while..like I said It's and old friend..

I had been passing on this just by appearances - the green bottle being part of what turned me off. So I finally picked up one and I was very pleasantly surprised; now I would go back for the sixer. A very decent doppleback, big brown sugar malt profile, enough bitter to balance and provide a satisfying finish. My wife even liked it.

How can you not love the Optimator?  Other than Salvator, it's the shit when it comes to German Doppelbocks.  Malt forward with milt hopiness to add depth and balance.  Bread in the glass!  Candy sugar brown with hints of clove, molasses, lots of carmel,and body that makes you think you're drinking a velvet painting of Elvis.

I was very surprised by this one.  Poured out very rich dark brown with a medium tan head.  Very spicy hop aroma with hints of smoke.  Flavor was rich and Smokey with mild hints of coffee, but only mild with slight tracings of caramel.  Smooth and balanced with creamy essences across the palate.  I really enjoyed this beer!  Not too rich, not thin!  I will definitely be drinking more of this one, and if you like dopplebocks then so should you.
Not so impressive head, but a nice dark brown color.  Smooth and malty but not quite what I was looking for out of a dopplebock.  Still, that being said, it was a good beer.

Aroma: Rich crystal-choco malty tones with pleasing alcohol sweetness.  No hop aroma perceived.  On warming, there is plum, black current, then turning towards dried fruit, & I think I just want to crawl inside the glass!

Appearance: Very dark brown with ruby highlights & clear as one can tell.  Low tan head that persists & is creamy.  The carbonation is very fine & well-done.  Yum is an understatement!

Flavor: Rich semi-sweet choco-malty with hints of tobacco hop flavor.  Residual crystal-like sweetness approaching cloying but steering clear at the finish.  Definite alcohol warming.  A very faint acidic-fruity sherry character denoting of oxidation: I am impressed that this should be so well preserved from Safeway (well – I did grab from the very back of the shelf).  Bittering is enough to support the malt for the style & is not obvious.  On warming, the malt flavor slides more towards a light blend of molasses & not overtly heavy; even later this matures to raisin with a hint of diacetyl which I am willing to accept.

Mouthfeel is generously full & round with a nice creamy texture, moderate carbonation, & a hint of grain astringency that in my perception complements the delicate balance & supportive of the dominate malt signature.

Overall, this is another of my favorite styles & it is well represented in Spaten as oppose to Paulaner which has thinned over the recent years.  Truly a meal into itself, but I shall save some to have with my dinner…maybe :o)

Outstanding!
This brown doppelbock has a short-lived head, smooth malty sweet flavor and a malty, somewhat dry finish.

One of my overall favorites for Doppelbocks.  Smooth and creamy with a hint of something sweet that conceals the higher alcohol content.  Wonderful brew for sitting by the fireplace and staring out at the snow as it warms from within.  Spaten did well with this one.

Wonderful deep brown with a frothy cream head with some lacing. Deep nutty caramel smell. Tasted quite light, a little sourness in the flavor but quite smooth and inoffensive. As it warms it becomes a little more nutty and hoppy. Nice beer for Spaten. I enjoyed this one a lot.
coca-cola like colour and a slight alchoholy taste.. head disappeared fairly fast. i was expecting a bit more from this, it was a tad on the bland side.
Huge brown sugar malt aroma on this brew.  There's also a slight sour hint of vinegar.  Medium heavy body has soft carbonation and is extremely smooth.
